description:
Second best general purpose Korean food restaurant in the City. Just behind Han Il Kwan and Jang Su (both tied for 1st). 

Bonus - they are open real late. Korean makes the perfect late night snack!
author: Art W.

description:
Maybe what I ordered wasn't the best choice... coming from LA to SF and I needed my korean food fix!!! This was not it. The sides were awful and suspicious looking, the soup was wayyyy cloudy with no meat and not the flavor!! 

I ordered galbi tang (beef short rib soup) and I got beef slices like brisket....

The soup tasted like kalguksu which is potato based....

Awful. The decor was nice and everyone else seemed happy.....
author: Claire S.

description:
True Rating: 3.5
Here's the breakdown:

1. There may be a wait. I went at 8:45pm on a Friday night and probably waited about 15-20 min. When you come in, there is a clipboard where you can write your name down. Make sure to find this clipboard because no one will greet you to mark you down.

2. The internal design is hip and cool. They have neon lights and a projector that plays k-pop videos.

3. The food is okay. As a Korean, I can say the food here is below average compared to Korean food in Korea but average-to-above average in USA. I got Pollack Roe Soup and it was meh. There was plenty of egg but the soup base wasn't refreshing (my fellow Koreans know what I am). My non-Korean friend got Soon Doo Boo and really enjoyed it though. 

4. The service is mixed. This is a Americanized Korean restaurant but the service is closer to a Korean restaurant. You have to call the waitress if you need anything since they won't check up on you. They don't greet you when you walk in. It didn't bother me since I'm used to this culture. However, they did forget one of my orders so we just cancelled it. The server who waited our table was kind and respectful.

5. The prices are fairly-priced/on-the-cheaper-side. Soon Doo Boo was $10, Pollack Roe Soup was $13. Prices range greatly from $8 appetizers to $30 shared dishes. That's a pretty good deal for SF.

Overall, I would recommend this place to non-Koreans or Koreans who haven't tried true Korean food from Korea. It is a really hip place to go on a weekend with some friends. It's fun and the crowd is young. Don't expect to get quality food or anything, but for the price, it will be worth the trip.
author: Shin L.

description:
Fun, lit place to go with a group of friends. Great place to go with a group to casually eat and drink a bit! Everything here is quite expensive, but hey, it's a prime location in SF, so can't really complain. For food, I had the kimchee fried rice with chicken and dukbokki with ramen. Both were quite good. The dukbokki was VERY spicy though, so if you can't handle spice well, maybe try asking them if they can make it less spicy. Portions were quite small for the price. 

In terms of drinks, we ordered plain soju and beer to make somaek and had lots of fun making the soju bombs and taking pics and videos of those haha. The drink was also quite yummy. We also got the mango soju cocktail and enjoyed that. Again, quite pricy, but enjoyable and tasty.
author: Erica T.

description:
This is one of my favorite Korean restaurants to go to in SF. Sure SF doesn't have good KBBQ, but there are some pretty solid Korean restaurants with delicious Korean food that isn't BBQ too! I usually like to come here after work since it's not too far from work. It's definitely a great hangout spot because the restaurant is pretty big and can accommodate for large parties. The restaurant doesn't get too crowded (or at least the times that I've been there), so you're almost likely to get seated right away.

My friends and I came here on a Friday night because I was craving Korean food. We decided to do family style and ordered dishes to share among 4 people. We ordered the Galbi, seafood pancake, assorted spam and sausage stew, creamy tok bok ki, and fried chicken wings. Everything was so mouthwatering and delicious. The stew was pretty spicy, but I couldn't stop eating it. The prices are pretty reasonable for the portion sizes.

Notes: The restaurant is located near the Tenderloin, so I don't recommend driving. It can be difficult finding parking since it's a busy area. There's a large TV/projection that plays K-pop music videos. There are two separate restrooms for women and men. The service was food, but it was hard to get the staff's attention since they had many other tables to cater to.
author: Sylvia H.

description:
Good Korean Restaurant in SF!

A group of 7 came here on Friday night around 6:30. We waited for about 20mins and got seated.
We ordered bossam($23), creamy ttokbokki($15), fried chicken wings with spicy sauce($16), sea snail with veggies and noodle($19), assorted sausage and spam stew($28) and beef brisket soup($13).

Bossam - 4/5 steamed pork belly served with lettuce and kimchi. Everyone loved making saam with pork belly!
creamy ttokbokki - 4/5 more on a sweeter side but good.
Fried chicken wings - 5/5 KFC was pretty good compared to the korean restaurants in inner sunset.
Sea snail with noodle - 4/5 huge portion and chewy sea snail
Assorted sausage and spam stew - 4/5 good stew to warm you up in a cold sf night.
Beef brisket soup - 1/5 bland and flavorless. Skip this one.

They project k-pop on a side wall. So my non- korean friends enjoyed watching it while enjoying dinner.

Good ambiance, good service and good food but nothing special. I think this place is good for late night drink and food. If I am in downtown area and crave korean food, I would dine here, but I would not come all the way from sunsets to dine here.
author: Clare L.

description: My coworker recommended this place to me several times if I liked Korean food which I do! This spot is pretty big for a korean joint restaurant with many options on their menu. My favorite is their glazed chicken because it's oh so crispy and flavorful. Their side dishes are also really tasty, ask for refills!
author: Lisa W.

description: Pretty much one of the few enjoyable Korean eateries in SF (other than Han Il Kwan). I was so spoiled by Korean food in LA. I love the vibe of this place, from the music videos playing on the walls to the neon sign and modern seating. My go to order is their soon dobu soup. Their banchan is limited, but each have great flavors that really complement the tofu soup - their kimchi is the perfect balance of ripe and fermented. The soup itself is hearty and has a lot of vegetables and beef. I'm so glad their takeout includes side dishes. I would say it's a 3.5 in the world of Korean food, but a solid 5 for Korean food in SF.
author: Fiona Y.

description:
This place is perfect for big groups with the loud music and Korean vibes going on although it can get crowded. There was a bit of a wait when we arrived at 7pm on a Friday night, but eventually got our table for six.

We went family style and ordered the Assorted Spam and Sausage Stew with Beef ($28.00), Beef Kimchi Fried Rice ($12.00), Fried Chicken Wings with Soy Garlic Sauce ($16.00), and Chicken Gizzard ($12.00). Of course you can't be at a Korean spot without some soju ($11.00), so we had 3 bottles of that too. The plates were all pretty good portioned and had us all stuffed by the end of the meal. For all the food and drinks we had, it came out to only $31.00 each including tip.

Highly recommend the fried chicken as you just can't go wrong with Korean Fried Chicken --double fried and super saucy! Any of the stews are also perfect choices for groups to share.
author: Cindy Z.

description:
Great portions at a fair price! Overall ambience is casual and spacious. 

Popular spot on weekends but weekdays usually have no line even for dinner! Everything I've tried here has been decent but nothing stood out a whole lot about this place. Which isn't necessarily a bad thing! If you're craving some good Korean food without having to pay close to $20 for it, this is the place! I'll definitely be coming back for a casual meal :)
author: Mandy H.

description: This place is great for authentic Korean food. They play k-pop on the wall using a projector. I loved their spicy pork.
author: Madhu J.

description:
Came in on a Friday night around 7pm and just in time to beat the crowd. We got seated right away for a table of four. The interior gives off a hipster vibe and they project KPOP music videos on one of their walls for entertainment. It definitely adds to the dining experience! 

My friends and I ordered Japchae, Dumpling and Vegetable Soup, Seafood Pancake, BBQ Spicy Chicken, and Dukbokki with Ramen. The service was great and quick. The price seemed reasonable and the portions are enough even for sharing.
author: Michelle S.

description: A drunchies or pre-game kind of place-- I honestly would only come here if I was desperately craving some late night korean bite or with a big group looking to drink before heading out. We came here late Friday night and there was a bit of a wait (as to be expected). The food is not great, and a bit perplexed and why this place is so highly rated. I ordered the dobukki with ramen which was too salty and my boyfriend got the ramen which was a good, akin to a ramen bowl you'd make out of your college dorm kitchen.
author: Rene C.

description:
Their yookgaejang dish.... Oh...my...goodness.... No. Just no. How can you mix 12 different Korean ingredients (if not more) to have it taste like NOTHING?!?!?!?!? Burned ash was the closest thing I could think of to compare... Wowza. I truly wish their cooks taste this dish before they serve to their customer next time, because if they did, they would have not brought it out to our table with a clear conscience. 

Giving it a 2-star instead of 1 as an overall average because their Tonkatsu was a ok and should deserve its 3-star rating. Yes, I'm a fair human being like that. You're welcome.
author: Lindsey O.

description:
The food here was decent. We ordered the seafood pancake, soy glazed chicken, rice cake with ramen, and tofu soup. There were all quite yummy dishes. The rice cake was nice and soft, but I wish there was more. As for the chicken, the fried shell was amazing! So crispy on the outside and tender on the inside. Seafood pancake wasn't too special but it was still good. As for the tofu soup with beef, it had great flavor, next time I would like to try the seafood version.The price range per dish was $12-$15. 
Soju wise we tried mango, lychee, peach, and calpico flavor. The calpico flavor was the winner for us. It didn't have too strong of an alcohol flavor and it was delicious.
When it comes to service, it was very fast when there weren't many people, but as the place got filled, the service got slower (to be expected). But I definitely would come again to hang out and eat delicious food.
author: Leanna L.

description:
Great for late night spicy bites. We had the spicy chicken with cheese, fried chicken wings, and the spicy tofu soup. 

The spicy chicken and cheese were my favorite. The cheese compliments the spicy chicken very well. Wait for the cheese to melt then dip the chicken in the cheese. WINNERS!!!!

All were great and I look forward to returning to eat again.
author: Teresa L.

description:
Ate here last weekend right before our doll up show. Service was extremely quick yet good...we were in and out in 45 mins.

We ordered the spicy wings. Very good, crispy, comparable to the ones in korea. Also ordered the seafood pancakes. They were generous with the seafood in there. 

Cute decor, love the brick walls with the screen projector, showing all kinds of kpop music videos!!

Good Korean food. Glad i stumbled upon this place and I will be back.
author: Caitlin P.

description:
707 has great Korean food that suits many tastes, even vegetarians. Their bibimbap and soup offerings are solid. Vegetarians can find satisfying dishes as well.

The food is relatively authentic for downtown SF, and the prices are reasonable as well. They're open until 2 AM which makes them not only a great late night option but also very close to what you would find in Seoul. 

All in all a place definitely worth a try.
author: John L.

description:
This place is all in solid and convenient Korean food.

They make excellent Korean wings (highly recommend -- best I've had), good tofu soup, and good steamed egg and apps.

The service and interesting ambiance (kpop music video streaming) make the place a frequent dinner go to for me!
author: Amy G.

description:
707 Sutter is a Korean restaurant that has been named 707 Sutter as that is where it is located. Granted that this eliminates the headache of identifying a name and building a brand around it, it makes it difficult for regular folks to figure out what cuisine is being served. Anyway Yelp to the rescue. 707 Sutter popped up at the top of the list when searching for Korean food in the Nob Hill area so I decided to give it a try for lunch a couple of days ago.

The restaurant looks a little run down but is pretty big. For the lunch service only the right hand section was open as there were not many people dining in. I was quickly greeted at the gate and shown to a table in the front and handed a regular menu which had a one page insert for lunch specials. The menu is typical of Korean restaurants and includes  Kalbi, Galbi, Bulgogi, bibimbap, japchae, sundubu etc. 

I decided to get the sundubu or the soft tofu soup with beef. After ordering I was quickly served four different types of banchan and ten minutes later had the piping hot sundubu in front of me. There wasn't a lot of variety in the banchan but the kimchi was really good. The sundubu was also great. It had a great depth of flavor without being too spicy or salty. Overall I was pretty happy with what I got.

Most of the lunch specials were around the $10 mark so they were about 20% cheaper than Zzan their nearest competitor in the area. Service was fast and efficient. This was not the best sundubu that I'd ever had but it was pretty good and definitely much better than what I had at Zzan a couple of days later. I look forward to returning and trying some more stuff off their menu.
author: Ahmad J.

description:
We ordered the vegetable tofu stew / soon doo bu, and for as red as it was, it lacked spice! And just had zucchini and mushrooms - would have liked the vegetable option to really go in on vegetables you know? It was decent. The kimchi pancake was realllly good, the usual greasy Korean pancake taste but the kimchi flavor was lacking...
Def want to return and try some of their many soup/stew/noodle soups options!
author: Farrah N.

description:
I've been here a few times at different times of the day. Always pretty busy but also always have seats. It's a good place to chill with friends. 

The food here does not disappoint. The wings are so hot! Temperature hot + Spicy hot. Yum! And the portions are huge - I've never finished the plate of wings on my own. We've also tried bi bim bop with beef, the soft tofu soup with chicken, and the kimchi fried rice with spicy pork. Everything's tasty. I love the process of adding a fresh egg in the soup. I like their cocktails too! They are very fruity and not too strong. 

Service is kind of lacking though. Waited forever to get the check and waited again to get the card swiped.
author: Iris H.

description:
Atmosphere: 5
Hip and relaxing, I love the projection of KPop music videos on the wall.  There wasn't any wait when we got there at 8:20PM Thursday night, but there were nearly all full.  It's a bit loud inside (because of people chatting) - must be the acoustics in there.

Portions: 5
My fiance ordered a soft tofu pot and it's the standard stone bowl size what we've become accustomed to. My bowl of beef brisket soup was huge and I wasn't expecting that when we ordered rice to go with our soups. Mine definitely didn't need it since it has some glass noodles in it already.  There is a lot more broth than stuff in the soup, but the ingredients were well balanced and each bite had beef in it.

Flavors: 5
The soup tastes like it's made with broth so it gave the soup as a whole more depth.  It was delicious and I could've drank more of it.  The beef brisket was super tender and there was a good mix of vegetables in the soup too.

Overall, I want to go there again. There are other traditional Korean dishes that I want to try. The flavors proved to be authentic and delicious and I highly recommend it to anyone!
author: Jennifer L.

description: This is overall a great Korean place to hang out and have drinks at late night. They have projections on the wall playing k-pop music videos. Their food are above-than-average, including most korean BBQ dishes and snacks.I went here a few times all at late 11 PM, and order soju (Korean wine). They have the most delicious self-made fruit-flavored soju in the area. I also want to highlight the seafood pan cake that contains the crunchy squid in the pan cake which tasted amazing.
author: Yanzhong L.

description:
I am not sure why this place is so highly rated. To be honest I don't think a lot of the dishes are authentically Korean and/or they are just poorly made

I ordered the "spice brisket soup" which I think is meant to be yukgaejang. It came without key ingredients like the gosari (fernbake fiddleheads) noodles, and I think I only had half an egg.  Actual soup to contents ratio was way off. I'm not nitpicking I received a huge bowl of actual soup and barely any of the actual ingredients.  It was basically a huge bowl of just spicy water with nothing else in it.  Did they just decide to give me all the soup left in the pot and call it a day?

This is a standard Korean item and they couldn't even get that right.
author: tony t.

description:
Had the spare ribs (pretty good), fried vegetables (kind of sweet for my taste), fried sausage with vegetables (really didn't like it)  like a polish sausage sliced and pan fried in sweet sauce with veggies.  
The chicken skewers were decent, and i liked the seafood pancake a lot.
Coworker really liked the veggies, so i wont say its not a good restaurant, just that i wouldn't go there again.  I would try something else.  San Francisco has too many good options to return here for me.
author: jason m.

description:
What I got:
Beef dumpling soup
Spicy Korean chicken wings

What I thought:
Probably one of the better korean joints in the city. Place is pretty spacious and relatively clean.

Food wasn't bad either. The beef dumpling soup was pretty spicy. It had a bunch of veggies like kimchi in it as well as tofu, beef dumplings, and I THINK there were beef slices in there too. It was hard to tell cus the slices were so thin. I don't think I'd order this exact soup dish again. It was okay, but I saw other orders around me that looked a bit better. This soup is enough for two people to finish.

The korean wings were pretty bomb. Maybe a tad too saucy though. One notch down would have been perfect. They weren't too spicy at all. Just the right hint of heat.

I would definitely make a comeback. Korean wings are something I would get again and maybe try a meat dish next time.
author: Tony V.

description:
Came in on Friday at 7 pm expecting a tasty and fun dinner...only experienced mediocre food & even more mediocre service.

+ The main thing going for the restaurant is the interior. Beautifully decorated, big projector showing k-pop music videos. 
+ Side dishes: barely anything given, some options tasted stale/not fresh and generally, not delicious
+ Stir fried octopus: Nice spicy flavor, not much octopus honestly and this dish was $18 so I was expecting more
+ Stone pot bibimbap: The decent part of the meal, plenty of veggies included

- Service: Quite slow and one very rude incident that soured our meal. We asked for an add on of noodles to the stir fried octopus after the server asked us if we wanted any, to which my friend and I both said yes. Dish arrived, no noodles were present, so we flagged down a server and let him know we never received the noodles and it was fine, but could we not get charged for it? He said, "The noodles should be on the top of the dish, you won't have to dig around for them." Okay, thanks for letting us know, but this doesn't change the fact that we didn't find any. I would have expected a few statements such as: "I'm sorry, let us remake the dish for you" or "Sorry about that, we won't be adding on the charge for the noodles". Instead he made it sound like we should have known immediately that there weren't noodles. Noticing faster or slower wasn't going to change anything as we were going to let him know regardless that we didn't receive what we ordered, which seems to be a typical course of action when eating at a restaurant. When we looked confused, he replied, "I'm just making a statement." To which we were completely baffled. His condescending and aggressive tone was really nothing I've ever experienced in customer service before and I was appalled. I didn't know schooling customers to cover up for your mistakes was a part of being a server. Then he disappeared to the kitchen, came back and stated, "The server said you two didn't want noodles, so that's why there weren't any." Really? You went back to ask for "confirmation" and then came back to prove your false point? I was genuinely stunned. Then, when the check came, he came back, and just like I knew he would, he apologized for what happened earlier because...it was time to tip and he realized that his actions may have impacted this crucial moment. 

Truly a disappointing experience for us and I won't be returning anytime soon to experience such rude service again.
author: Annie D.

description:
i love this place! i always went to zzan because i didnt know about this place but im glad i got to check it out! It's very spacious and clean, had really friendly servers, and had good korean food!

We had boodae jjigae and jokbal and both were amazing. I've never seen jokbal come out by itself (only 6 sauces, not veges or garlic!!) so i asked the server and he brought of some more vege side dishes for us. But other than that, the jjigae was amazing and the side dishes were really really good too. Felt like i was in korea again. Their beer was cheap too! Only $15 for draft sapporo. 

im so glad more korean places are opening up in the bay!! and they actually have legit tasting korean food! xD

i will definitely check this place out again.
author: Yeonhwa S.

description:
At the time I'm writing this review, according to my check-in history I've been to 707 Sutter 15 times. But to be honest, I think it's more accurate to say that I've been here twice that count (30 times)... considering I never remember to check-in whenever I end up stumbling here for some drunchies. 

TLDR; 707 is lit. Not because they have amazing Korean food - let's be real, there really aren't any legit Korean restaurants in Downtown SF (or maybe I just have unreasonable DTLA Ktown standards) - but because of the atmosphere. It's a place that is great for any occasion - pregaming, postgaming, casual dining, or just grabbing a drink. 

Why? One, the restaurant is spacious and offers numerous tables to accommodate both large and small parties. Even when it gets packed, the wait is never too long (20 minutes tops). Two, they have a wide selection of alcoholic drinks to cater to guys (beers/soju) and gals (flavored soju). For the gals, I highly recommend ordering the yogurt soju. It's *so* delicious that you will find yourself ordering more and more pitchers, and before you know it the yoju will get to you. Three, I love how this place is always full of life, with a large screen projector playing an awesome selection of Kpop music vids. So atmosphere-wise, this place deserves a 5/5.

The food here is aite - a 3 at best if you're sober, but *most definitely* a 5/5 if you're a tad bit intoxicated. 707 has the perfect menu to fulfill all your drunchie needs. Want something soupy? The budaejjigae (Assorted Spam and Sausage Stew) with ramen definitely hits the spot. Craving carbs? Can't go wrong with the Kimchi/Seafood Pancake or Dukbokki. Need something fried? The Fried Chicken Wings (comes in spicy or soy garlic sauce) is finger-licking satisfying. 

Definitely come give this place a try; I guarantee you won't be disappointed!
author: Cindy L.

description: I'm giving this place 4 stars purely for the spicy chicken & cheese dish. In my opinion, this is the only standout dish. I haven't found that many Korean places in SF that serves this delectable gooey, cheesy concoction. The chicken itself is not spicy, but the sauciness of it complements the cheese very well.
author: Charissa S.

description: Solig place for korean food. Their renovated interior makes this place a great spot for the younger crowd! My friend and I come here for their pork back bone soup which can be shared for two. This is also one of the few places in downtown that serves bossam! After the broth is almost done, make sure to add some rice and nori to the pot and mix in with what's the left of the soup! You'll thank me later
author: Sui N.

description:
I only had the fried chicken and it was quite good but not spicy at all for me. I don't know much about Korean cuisine but to me spicy means you're sweating and struggling to eat more than one wing at a time.  

The chicken has a great crunch because they use a lot of batter which I like, and the sauce is flavorful if overly sweet. 

I would order it again if in the mood for fried chicken wings. I imagine it goes great with beer. 

My order was takeout and I was served promptly etc. I will be back and I'll be sure to ask for more chile next time.

*Update:
I came back for the kimchi fried rice and wasn't disappointed.  I've been making this dish for years now, -recipe handed down from a friend- and I was pleasantly surprised to see theirs is basically an almost-as-good as my own!
The kimchi fried rice comes with the option to choose what kind of meat you want in it, and I would list them but as soon as I hear "spam" that was it.  It seems they really stole my recipe, but I'm not mad because it was homey and delicious.
Probably, ordering the kimchi fried rice and the chicken wings together would make a great combination.  So, until I get my fried rice stand up and working, I recommend you check this place out.
author: Henry A.

description:
I really enjoyed this food.  I got noodles with vegetables and smothered it with gochujang. 

Did I mention I'm a gochujang junkie?

The crisp vegetables, chewy noodles, and spicy sauce gave my mouth a textural flavorfest that it was craving.  I really love this dish and it was done perfectly.

The banchan presented when I sat down was a nice treat, ample and varied.

If you like videos while you eat, they have a large projection on the wall showing beautiful people singing songs.
author: Sondra H.

description:
The sides and the drinks are pretty good. Seafood pancake was huge and complex it a bit bland. Cheese corn is excellent. My friends also enjoyed the aloe soju and egg soufflé.

Buuuut I go to Korean places for the meat, and the meat was disappointing. The bulgogi stew and skewers were just ok, and the galbi dish was shockingly small and kind of bad, for short rib.

So yeah, go to chill with friends, but don't expect a satisfying meal.
author: Serena J.

description: For the most part this place was delicious. The only reason it's not getting a 5 star is because I absolutely bulgogi and the one at this place was not very good. The flavor just seemed off compared to the dozens I have tried. Besides that, we had the galbi and bi bim bop bowl. The galbi was phenomenal and the bi bim bop was good but not excellent, that too was missing some flavor. The service was excellent and the restaurant itself was beautiful. The atmosphere was great as they were playing Korean music videos on a projector screen, pretty cool. I'd recommend this place!
author: Erica C.

description: The food here is decent, though I do have to say that when you look into the portion sizes, you're actually getting pretty small amounts for the prices you're paying, e.g. the bowl for the spicy brisket soup is massive for $13, but the pieces of brisket and noodles are actually scant. It's mainly just a large bowl of spicy broth. For $18, you can get the classic ham hock dish (jokbal), and it's deliciously gelatinous, but it doesn't come with any wraps and just the four dipping sauces. Dolsot bibimbap comes in beef, pork, or chicken and is about $14, but again, the stone bowl is quite small. Service here is great, and food comes out really quickly, so if you're hungry and drunk, 707 will do the trick. It just might be a little tough on your wallet.
author: Danny C.

description:
I was introduced to this place by friends.  Typically we are looking for a place that is open late and can accommodate groups of 10+.  707 can do both. 

I've tried a number of items on the menu including the soft tofu soup, corn cheese, spicy chicken with cheese, and seafood pancakes which are all solid choices.  But, one of the most notable items on the menu is the fried chicken.  The chicken is hot and crispy with a tangy sweet and spicy sauce.    

With the super nice staff, multiple soju options, and K-Pop being projected onto the wall, 707 has become a staple for me and my friends on late nights.
author: Mitch T.

description: I have previously heard that most people come here for late night food or to eat and drink with friends. Therefore, I didn't have that high of an expectation for the quality of the food. But I was pleasantly surprised when I went for dinner (~5pm). For Korean food in downtown SF, it wasn't that bad. You can ask for refills on the small dishes.  My recommendation is to get the gamja tang and share. It's definitely for 3 people (2 if you're super hungry).
author: Ellen K.

description:
707 Sutter does the classic Korean dishes well - be it seafood pancakes, gyoza or bimbimbap.  It is only outshadowed by its cross street rival Cocobang in the korean fried chicken department but that's more than made up in my view by the less cramped quarters and nicer decor.

There's generally always a space available so you don't have to wait a long time to be seated.  Soju here is pretty good and affordable as well.
author: Mark C.

description:
Ahh, I actually prefer this place over Cocobang nearby. I prefer the korean spicy wings here and the line is much shorter.

I love how they play kpop videos here in the background. It adds to the dining experience.

My favorite items here:
-chicken wings
-cheese corn
-tofu soup
-dukbokki
author: Alicia L.

description:
Quick service and great food! My friends and I were CRAVING Korean food (especially bibimbap) and almost every place was closed for President's Day. We were thrifting at a nearby Goodwill when I found this place through Yelp! They were opened!!

The service was really quick and the waitress was friendly. The atmosphere is quiet and peaceful while music is playing in the background while you eat. Portions are fit for one person (not family)
author: Catthy N.

description: Excellent food, super service. Waiter very knowledgeable of the menu and friendly. Enjoyed the Korean music videos being played.
author: Cyndi T.

description:
Spacious and central with friendly staff. There's something about the layout and space that doesn't make it feel as cozy and cocobang, but because it's bigger, it's easier to get seated. 

The food is solid, no complaints. Soju, beer and chicken as you would expect. Always have to get the rice pinky with ramen dish. Great location near Union Square.
author: Young Y.

description:
Wait kind of sucks regardless of the good food.
Needs some proper queue management tactics.
author: Noni P.

description:
I've been here a few times and enjoy the food for the most part. I usually get the seafood tofu soup and it's been pretty consistent except for the last time I was here. It was so thick that I couldn't enjoy it. My friends also ordered tofu soup during this visit and had a similar experience..

Besides the food, the service is great and there's plenty of place to sit.
author: Mehak D.

description:
The creamy teokbokki kept me coming back. Solid spot and open late. 

I came here after the Ashanti and Ja Rule concert. We wanted Korean that was nearby and this came on the radar. 

Definite highlights are the sweet/spicy wings. They are a good portion for the price. It's a great entree to share with the table. They are crisp and saucy on the outside but juicy and tender on the inside. Super hot because they're freshly fried so be careful! 

The other dish that is extremely memorable and unique was the creamy teokbokki (Korean rice cakes). It was recommended to me by the waiter, who was very kind, polite and knowledgeable. He said it was his favorite. And it's definitely mine at this spot! It's reminiscent of a sweeter version of carbonara! It was creamy with egg and bacon! I've come here twice and both times I got it. 

Everything else I ordered was up to par, neither extraordinary nor disappointing. It was enjoyable for sure :) if I'm in the neighborhood, I'll be back! 

ig: @carte_du_tina
author: Tina Y.

description:
Always order pork feet
Large Budae jjigae
Corn cheese
Peach Suju
The huge screen for Kpop songs is one of my favorites in here
author: Yoli X.

description:
Overall pretty decent and solid Korean food. Is it out of this world? No. Are the K-Pop videos they project onto the walls intoxicating yet over-stimulating? Absolutely. 

I've been to 707 Sutter 2 times and had no complaints or raves. Decent bets are the Seafood and Kimchi Pancakes and the Dol Sot BiBimBap. It's convenient for this area, and hits the spot if you are in desperate need for Korean food ASAP.
author: Alisha R.

description:
Korean food is one of my favorites and boy do I have this craving. The challenge is finding a Korean joint in the city that's good and doesn't break the bank. On a recent night, I joined a friend at 707 Sutter as it was SUPER close to my apartment. Glad I did!

When you walk in, you add your name on a clipboard and wait for someone to seat you. The staff was efficient and friendly, nothing really worth noting. The place could probably use a little more color: grey walls and minimal art. The focal point for sure would be the Korean television being projected on the wall. I feel like that's the norm for authentic and hip Korean places. KPOP played in the background as everyone enjoyed their meals. 

For dinner, we started with the Fried Chicken Wings with Soy Garlic Sauce for $15. Price seems a little steep but do it! You won't be disappointed! You get 10 HUGE wings doused in this flavorful sweet sauce with a nice hint of garlic. The wings weren't soggy, still had lots of crunch to it and full of meat. HIGHLY RECOMMEND. My meal was the Dol Sot (Stone Pot) Bi Bim Bop for $12. If you like Bops, you MUST get the stone pot. Keeps the food hot and crisps up the rice nicely. This bop includes a variety of veggies including braised spinach, shredded carrots, sprouts and your choice of chicken, beef, pork, seafood or vegetarian. Coupled with the gochujang sauce, it's a meal that will leave your taste buds happy as heck! 

Overall, a nice successful evening. The meal was a lot more reasonable than other Korean joints in the area and the food was good. If you're close by, come check them out!
author: Rockne H.

description: Nice Korean restaurant opening till late. Budaejjigae was pretty authentic yet saulty... I am not from the area but it seemed popular and had a variety of Korean dishes!
author: Amanda K.

description: Came here for a second meal ( I know- we eat a lot ) and a place to drink soju!!!! We ordered spam fried rice, the seafood pancake, fried chicken (soy garlic) and peach soju! We were immediately seated and service was quick and easy. Banchan here is unlimited and my two favorite banchans were a mayo seaweed pulps and the soy sauce potato! The fried chicken WAS AMAZINGGG. They had super huge wings and drumsticks and they were super crunchy and jam packed with flavor. The chicken also came with picked daikon to help ease the flavors to eat something else :) 10/10 would come again!!!
author: Darlene D.

description:
Disclaimer- this is the only Korean restaurant I have ever been to, so I can't compare it to other Korean food. However, I have been here probably 10 times and loved everything we have ordered. I usually go with a good sized group of friends, and we share everything, so I have tried quite a few things from the menu. My favorite is the kimchi pancake, their spicy wings (be warned that 10 big wings come in an order. This app could easily feed 4) and the stir fried glass noodles with kimchi. I also like the variety that comes in the complimentary appetizer/snack thingy they bring you after you place your order (fun fact for Korean food newbies like me, it's called banchan, and it 's yummy and freeee!) 

The environment isn't fancy or trendy, but they do have a huge screen playing Korean pop music videos, so those are fun to watch. Service has always been fine. The people who work there seem to stay busy and try their best. If you're in the hood and looking for good full service Korean food, 707 is definitely worth a visit. Don't forget to order a pitcher of nice cold beer to go with those spicy wings!
author: Liz M.

description:
I thoroughly enjoyed 707 Sutter. I went for late lunch, which was not to busy.
I ordered the KimChee Pancakes, and the Bibimbap to go, with a Hite while I waited of course.
The food came out fast, and was delicious.
Can't wait to visit again.
author: Alex A.

description:
Recommendation: Yum! Everything was delicious and it really felt like an authentic Korean experience

We came in with no reservation and even though we had 5 people, we were seated at the large round table very quickly. Korean restaurants typically serve a few small plates of free appetizers prior to the real appetizers or entrees, and 707 was no different. There was also K-pop music playing in the background and a projector displaying the associated music video on the wall, which definitely helped add to the vibe.

For an appetizer we ordered the spicy rice cake with fish cake and vegetables and opted to get the ramen noodles added. It was delicious, with chewy rice cakes and lots of flavor! 

We then moved onto our entrees. I ordered the dumpling soup, and it was definitely one of the better soups I've ever had. The dumplings simply fell apart in the soup and the broth was simple but full of flavor. I particularly enjoyed the strong taste of onions in it! 

One of my dining partners ordered the seafood pancake, as we have in the past. As always, it was also very delicious, with a healthy portion of seafood baked in and cooked to perfection. We saved a few pieces for reheating the next day and even then, they were awesome!

All in all I was really satisfied with 707 Sutter. It lives up to everything in the surrounding area too, making this area a perfect place to try and find dinner on a weekend! So many options (Ryoko's, Sanraku, 707) that I know of and I'm sure more that I have never tried. I'll definitely be coming back!
author: John B.

description:
You've probably heard that they play K-Pop on a projector on one of the walls. Cool vibes, but honestly thought the food was kind of meh. 

Korean Chicken had good sauce, but was a little dry inside. I've had better Ko. Fried chicken in Oakland. Kimchi pancake was also mediocre. Better kimchi pancakes in Hayes Valley. Could have used more butter. Bibimbop was could have also used more meat. Why are they skimping out? We order something with octopus -- I just remember the octopus being chewy/rough af. 

Overall, for the price, I was pretty disappointed with the meal :(
author: Vasiliy M.

description:
8/31/16:  As random as random can be, somehow I ended up at a Korean restaurant with a trendy downtown name that normally would be associated with bars lined with $3k cognac bottles, possibly the brainchildren of once-celebrity chefs, and definitely big dollar bills....

But... it's just straight up Korean.

Sure, they did their best to fulfill the destiny associated with their name, like an Alice must be an Alice, and a Bob is always a Bob.... 707 must.......... be scorched in darkness, with random films being projected onto the walls, and of course, most importantly hot young Korean girls to serve you.

The food?  Surprisingly they got some of the more scary stuffs, which would be quite impressive given their location and... again, their name....

1. Banchan:  Probably one of the least impressive spreads I've seen.  Definitely less than expected given the ultra trendy environment and location.  Just 2 lunchbox-style plastic plates with a total of 6 simple snacks.  3/10

2. Rice cake with cream sauce $15 "creamy tteok bok ki":  Okay.... this was awesomeness!  Think of it as Korean mac & cheese.  You got that chewy Asian rice cake, cylindrical, like non-hollow macaroni, and a great creamy sauce.  Only thing, $15 is far too expensive for some Asian mac & cheese without even a piece of truffle or lobster.  But, if you can ignore the price, it tastes really damn good.  7/10

3. Pollack roe soup $13 "al tang":  So, basically just your very standard tofu soup, minus the tofu but with very very non-standard bursty brainy bubbling things floating around with blue veins.  ROE!!!  Well, I LOVE caviar, and any kind of roe they got at Mitsua... but... it tastes horrible in soup cause it's just hard and all that amazing fishy saltiness gets sucked away.  And again, add to that a very standard level Korean soup, it just ain't that impressive.  They would do far better to just drop the roe in at the very end, uncooked, half raw inside--that would be sooooo much better tasting.  2/10

4. Gal Bi $24:  Well, you know what it is.  In this case it's the fancier, large single bone type.  Very charred.  Meat tastes great.  But it better be damn good for $24!!!  Well, for that price, I think you'd do better elsewhere.  5/10

I suppose I should give them credit for trying to have a real authentic Asian restaurant in the middle of prime downtown restaurant real estate, but I can't say that their food justifies the price.  Girls were certainly cute though.  I'd come for that.

3/5

#korean #galbi #kalbi #sanfrancisco
author: Dean C.

description:
The food was pretty good!

 I got the Seafood bibimbap (not stone,$11) and the flavors of the sauce was good but very overwhelming. There was a ton of red sauce, in which at first I thought wasn't that bad when I mixed it with the rice. Towards the end, my rice ended up being soggy after soaking in the red sauce. There are plenty of different seafood meats. It was kind of hard to see which seafood meat I was eating (i'm no expert either). I shared the bibimap with a friend and it was plenty to fill us both up. Probably next time I'll ask for less sauce or have the sauce on the side instead of added into my bibimbap. 

I also got the corn cheese and I felt that the corn cheese ($7) can be a pass. I felt that it either needed more butter or more cheese because there is some sort of flavor lacking. 

Considering this is San Francisco, I was expected this place to be pricey and expensive but it really isn't. In comparison to San Jose's Korean restaurant food, 707 Sutter is actually pretty affordable/cheaper. After my table got seated, there was already a wait coming out the door. Definitely will be looking forward to coming back here whenever I'm back in the SF area!
author: Diana N.

description: Good selection of traditional Korean dishes. The staff are friendly and the service is great.
author: Joni W.

description:
Had a fabulous time here as food is great, service is fast and well organized. The meat was tender, tasty.
Pricing was good, definitely recommend and I will return.
author: Saebom R.

description:
Good food, drinks, and best of all - prices! I've had soju and the beef bi bim bop here. If you get the bowl version it's only $11, which is such a good deal in SF. Portion was good and the banchan is delicious! We got a mix of veggies, potatoes, glass noodles, kimchi, and tempura. 

I came around 6:30 pm on a weekday and there were plenty or seats. Server was friendly and good came out fast. I definitely will be coming back!
author: Sophia H.

description:
I've always loved Korean food for the minimal amount of oil they use. Many Asian foods from other cultures use a horrifying amount of oil that is sickening to eat! I was indecisive and ended up getting the typical Bi Bim Bop (beef) and it was really filling! The portion was HUGE and I thought I couldn't finish it, but I miraculously did and I have no regrets. Definitely put the sauce it comes with inside yours and let your rice sizzle and become crisp before mixing! It adds a slight burnt but yummy flavor to the dish. 

The waiters are super nice and very attentive. You also can't go wrong with the K-Pop that's pumping through the restaurant.
author: Jenni T.

description:
Cool vibe, I'm entranced by the MVs on the wall. Probably best for my company if I don't face it next time. 

There's not many places in the city where you can get my favorite Korean food - pork bone soup. They have it here, to share, and it's delicious!

Kimchi pancake also on point. Will return.
author: Tyler L.

description:
Very solid Korean food in an minimalist setting with K-pop videos and a largely Korean clientele. Prices are reasonable for the portions. The spicy chicken wings (sauced with gochujang, so they're a bit sweeter, much stickier, and a little more fermented than you might expect, and perfectly cooked) are quite substantial: they could easily be split by a party of 4 as an appetizer. I went twice on a recent trip, once by myself late at night when little else was open after my flight to SFO had been delayed, and again the following evening with friends attending the same conference. 

The spicy chapchae was some of the best I've had in years: very flavorful, delightfully chewy, with bits of vegetable and BBQ pork. Bibimbap was solid but nothing fancy. The panchan varied a bit from visit to visit, but included a number of options including a delicious kimchi, great marinated spinach, and strips of fish cake. Everyone also liked the corn with cheese, a tasty version of creamed corn. 

Service was fast. They have a selection of Korean and domestic draft beers, and highly entertaining K-pop videos projected on the wall.
author: Cage H.

description: I am a vegetarian and had a great lunch. The stirred fried vegetables were heavenly. The Bi Bim Bop with tofu was good and the vegetable dumplings were excellent.
author: Ira C.

description:
Korean food & open late -- pretty good deal.  Upon arriving, it was pretty empty -- but the first thing I noticed was the giant projector on the wall showing Korean music videos (which I loved).

I ordered the wings and the dumplings -- which were both delicious.  Note: the wings are a HUGE serving -- probably enough for two people to share.  I also got to try their kiwi soju -- which was delicious! 

The server there was super polite, helpful, and quick.  The decor is very minimal, but as I mentioned -- they do have a huge wall of Korean music videos, which is super distracting and fun to watch.

I would say this place is good, and a fun spot to hit up (especially since they are open late) -- however, I should also note it can get pricey.
author: Michelle S.

description: Love this place. My favorite Korean pub food. Egg soufflé, corn cheese, spicy chicken with cheese and kimchi fried rice. Good service and food came out pretty quickly.
author: Shirley Z.

description:
Kimchi fried rice- it was super good but didn't meet my expectations. It was very flavorful and the portion was decent. I would get this dish again anytime.

Chicken stew- nothing special about this particular dish. It wasn't good but it wasn't bad either. I wouldn't get this again.

Corn cheese- so far the best I've tried. The cheese is soo creamy and the corn was soft. It was a combo made in heaven.

Japchae- portion and flavor was decent. I don't like japchae in general so I will not judge this dish. My friend said it was pretty good.

Overall, good customer service and the playlist was BOMB AF! I'd come here again.
author: Kathy D.

description: Terribly unkind staff who was being extremely rude to customers asking for the remaining wait time (already waited for an hour), absolutely the worst customer experience I've ever experienced in the city, not recommended at all
author: HyunJun K.

description: Glad to have a late night spot open near work. Solid food. Service is ok. Chicken wings are ok. Short ribs and rice was solid .
author: Justin I.

description: Went here on a Wednesday night around 8pm, immediately sat at a table with 3 people. We ordered the beef bulgogi, glass noodles, beef dumplings, and the seafood pancake. Overall not the best Korean food I've had - the bulgogi was really dry and didn't come with any dipping sauces which was a disappointment. The seafood pancake was really onion heavy too (not my favorite). I would recommend the dumplings and glass noodles! Overall an okay place to grab late night korean food.
author: Ciera P.

description:
We came here after a night out at the Tonga Room & Hurricane Bar (walking distance) and had great late-night munchies.

We ordered spicy rice cakes, spicy pork, soon tofu, and a pitcher of yogurt soju. All 3 dishes were great. The spicy rice cakes were chewy and the portion size was big enough for 2. The spicy pork was also excellent. The soon tofu was spicy, but tasted great. Portion size is pretty big so if you're not that hungry, you could definitely get any one dish and share. The yogurt soju was yummy. It's definitely better for pre-game than post-game (for obvious reasons). A pitcher is big enough for 2 people (maybe 3).

In terms of prices, it's relatively cheap. You would expect this place to be expensive as it is in San Francisco, but the prices are honestly so reasonable.

The service was also great. They play K-pop music videos on the wall and we asked them to play a certain artist and they happily did so. I necessarily wouldn't come here for a proper lunch or dinner meal, but it's an excellent place to grab a bite of food to eat and pre-game or post-game.
author: Jen S.

description:
I always get drunk in this area and am usually craving drunchies but not drunchies that will give me bad shits in the morning. 707 Sutter is that perfect balance - not too greasy but just filling enough to meet your drunk fill! 

Where to start? When you're drunk already or just want get a lil crazy, they offer affordable and really good soju actually and with an assortment of flavors. Bought 3 bottles and got me going for the rest of the freaking night! 

In terms of the food, the portions are perfect, but the food is mixed in terms of taste. I love the Tofu soup and their jap Chae, but wish they offered more meat and cooked it more consistently... But what is awesome is that they are open late and the food comes out fast. I also love love love their service and it's an extra plus that they have a projector playing your fave k pop music! Right on 707 - sounds like a club- but it's a popping late night meal place!
author: Eric Joseph D.

description: Party time. Loud, not great for kids, very ADD. Nice staff, party vibes, food good. F-ck long reviews
author: John M.

description: Excellent ambience with Kpop music. Food is great too, get the spam hot pot and kalbi! They are perfect complements to soju
author: Luffy L.

description:
I love the hanging out environment.  I love the gigantic music videos on the wall.  I love the food.  I love the people (unless they get too drunk).

I dislike the parking situation though.  Uber / Lyft it!!
author: Cary L.

description:
My friends and I were looking for a delicious dish after a sweet night of dancing and 707 came to our rescue. They're open late, they're a lovely sobering and not too far walk from Union Square, and they offer hot Korean food which is so much better than late night diner food. 

It was half past midnight when we arrived and the place was pretty full. It has simple decor, mostly black with a giant projection of kpop videos on one wall. They have a full menu (nothing is limited because it's really late night or anything). We ordered bo ssam and tofu soup. The bo ssam is a boiled pork belly served with garlic, lettuce, radish wrap, and kimchi,  and 4 tasty dipping sauces. I didn't know what any of the sauces were but they were all amazing. 
The tofu soup was average good. It made me cough a lot which I don't think meant it was super spicy, it felt more like the powder in the soup was not completely disintegrated. 

Overall cool spot. Friendly service and inspirational kpop videos on the wall. Gotta love it.
author: Veronica L.

description: The food here is great although theres usually a line around the busy times! The kimchi rice is really good, would recommend
author: Shannia F.

description:
707 is a San Francisco staple. If you and your friends enjoy Korean food, this is a perfect destination for "event" dinners (birthdays, promotions, etc.). There are always music videos playing on projectors in the background.

707's food is reliable. If you have an itch for Korean food, some 707 will do the trick. It's definitely not the best Korean food I've ever had, nor is it especially original. It's just consistently well-done food, which exactly what you want in a "go-to" place.

As other reviewers have noted, 707 is in a relatively large space, so the wait isn't usually a concern and they can easily accommodate larger groups. Getting rowdy and drinking a little too much here feels almost encouraged, making it, again, a great place for a celebration dinner.
author: Patricia K.

description:
Don't be fooled by the restaurant's odd setup of jumbo-tron K-Pop videos in the background. The food here is actually pretty good and inexpensive. I came here with a girlfriend and decided to share some Budae Jigae and Seafood Pancake. The seafood pancake is decent with good amount of seafood although I wish the pancake is crispier. The soup has everything you need really - ramen noodles, rice cakes, sausages, spam and kimchi! 

We were so full afterwards I needed to probably walk 3 miles to burn all the calories I inhaled. It was very satisfying and just what I needed on a rainy and cold spring night in San Francisco!
author: Athena C.

description: Stir fried pork was cooked to perfection. Tender and flavorful. Presentation A. Taste A. Quick service A. Highly recommend.
author: Clayton R.

description:
Tried their lunch box special and it's a great value. Very delicious.  

They've also improved the ambiance a lot.  I like the new look.
author: Anthony F.

description:
Great service, great food with modern decor and kpop videos playing on the wall.

The tofu soup was one of the best in the city. Many places the soup seems to be on the watery side. Here it's very thick and red, somewhat stewy. Great flavor, and they even put mussels in addition to the clam and shrimp.

The service was on point and very friendly.

All in all great experience and I'd come back again.
author: Masa K.

description:
Pretty good.  Didn't think it was great though.  
Nice atmosphere.  KPOP on the big screen. 
Probably other Korean restaurants that are better, but this is a good choice too.
author: Terry L.

description:
Decent korean food but it's the junky, bar food kinda food. For what it was though, the serving sizes weren't too small and it tasted "good."

If you're looking for authentic, high quality korean food, this isn't the place. But it's good for the junky cravings.
author: J P.

description: Great Korean place. Good prices, good portion, good service and atmosphere. We walked in tired and hungry and they brought over water without us even asking which was great. Because we were hungry we ordered too much but still almost ate it all since it was so good.
author: Tim C.

description: Great price, perfect service. One of my favorite Korean restaurant in San Francisco :) I've tried all menu in 707 Sutter, and it's 10/10. Good music choices! ( KPOP videos on big screen) I always go to this place with my friends. Perfect place for drink! If you didn't try SOJU yet, you MUST try.
author: Nicki M.

description:
Out of the three korean restauraunts in the area (707, Zzan and Cocobang) this is definitely my favorite. I think it's slightly more expensive than the other places but the qualify of the food is definitely better than the other places not to mention better service. Sometimes service can be a little slow even when it's not that busy but the food is worth the wait.

707 is bigger than Cocobang and Zzan so the wait usually isn't as long. They also have a wide selection of soju (I tried the lychee one and it tasted okay, wasn't my favorite though.) I tried the BBQ Bul go gi and it was one of my favorites.
author: Cassie Z.

description: I tried their tofu hot stone bibimbap. It tasted very plain. I added so much hot pepper sauce and it still had no taste. It tasted like I was eating white rice. The waiters were also very busy so we had to wait quite a bit before they took our orders.
author: Priscella L.

description:
3.75

After attending an awesome event filled with lots of laughter, beer, oh and new friends, we were famished.  A lot of the surrounding restaurants were closing so we decided to venture out further.  707 Sutter popped up on my list and who doesn't love Korean food especially after a few drinks.

Banchan - the server made her way towards our table at which I made room for the banchan plates... that's it?  I made room, please utilize that space and provide more banchan plates. 
Kimchi Fried Rice - You really can't go wrong with kimchi fried rice.  I just wish the egg was a bit runnier
Seafood Pancake - One of the best I've had.  Not greasy, filled with lots of fresh seafood, right amount of crisp

I could've gone for some meat but this was enough to fill the two of us at such a late hour.  

Friendly service, huge TV's that play Korean music videos of girls dancing that make guys go gaga.
author: Linda N.

description:
Just went here for the first time the other night with a group of friends after volleyball. It is conveniently located on sutter, just blocks from union square! Food was good (felt boring so I got the bibimbap) and warm-- everyone around me got the spicy tofu soup so I apparently missed out. 

We also got some pitchers of beers and some soju, which was great for sharing and hanging out. Also, if you love k-pop get ready to fall in love because they basically blast k-pop and project the music videos on the wall (which is awesome). 

Service was pretty fast and friendly. Would go back.
author: Lai-Nin W.

description: This was like being back in Korea way-back-when.  The jigae stews are so tasty, and they served makulri (rice beer) the traditional way, in a big bowl.  Kimchee fabulous. I'm coming back.
author: Matt B.

description: I love this place every time I come to San Francisco! Now that I live in Hayward, I know when I am craving Korean food late night, I will be able to come to 707!
author: Angela L.

description: Poor service. I went there on Friday 4/6 lunch time. I understand she's busy because it's only one server at that time. I asked for a bowl and she didn't bring it at the first time, so I reminded her. She got mad and said 'I got it here'. After we got the check we were charged 18% tips for four of us. Why can she charged the tip by herself with that poor service?
author: Annie C.

description:
707 Sutter is probably the closest I can get to feeling like I am back in Korea (Hongdae in particular). Stepping inside, you immediately see the big projector screen covering the right side of the wall with Kpop music videos showing. Don't get distracted by it! As soon as you walk in, find the clipboard and put your name down. Then proceed to dance in place as you watch the next ten Kpop videos play. 

PROS:
-Open late until 2am! Yay for the late night owls!
-Lots of food options to choose from compared to other restaurants
-Unique items like creamy ddukbokki and cheese corn
-Good for large groups
-Giant screen playing Korean MVs

I've been here two times and so far, I really like this place. The location is a bit far out for me and prices are slightly pricey but the food is solid.

CREAMY DDUKBOKKI
It's sooooo good. The rice cakes are super soft and not too chewy. The sauce has a bit of a spicy kick but it's not overpowering. I'm not sure what they put in the sauce to make it so addictive but it has a slight tomato-y vodka sauce taste in my opinion. Whatever it is, I want to eat it every single day. 

FRIED CHICKEN
I tried both the spicy sauce and the soy garlic sauce. I highly would recommend the soy garlic over the spicy because the spicy is SPICY! It's literally a whole bowl of gochujang sauce mixed in I think because my mouth was on fire! And I really like spicy foods in general so if you have a strong tolerance, go for it. It was still quite good just that the pain and the tears made it hard for me to go on. The soy garlic was good but not the best I've had in the city. They give the standard side dishes and it's pretty good! We certainly ate everything given before our first dish even came out. 

Atmosphere-wise, it is great for large groups because there is a lot of open space and the bathroom is nice and clean. I haven't been here for lunch but at dinnertime, the lights are always dimmed so sometimes I feel like I'm in a club with the Kpop music playing over the large screen.
author: Diana C.

description:
Good food, huge projector screen playing kpop and music videos, and spacious for bigger parties. 

Today my coworkers and I had dinner here. We loved everything! I recommend the jap chae, seafood pancake, bbq chicken, tofu soup, and bibimbap. You really can't go wrong with anything here. 

The only downside is that parking is so hard to find.
author: Corinna T.

description:
Slushie soju here is mad dope!
Never seem anything like this here in the bay besides when i was in korea. 
Soju gets extra cold! Like a 7-11 slurpee! Yall gotta come try it!
author: Jang W.

description: Soo good. The tofu soup is soo good. As good as my tofu house, but this one is more spicy when i order extra spicy. The price is really reasonable too.
author: Waraporn T.

description:
Overall: a great place for Korean comfort food, friendly service, and a casual hangout.

I came here for dinner and I got the budae jjigae (on the menu it's spam and sausage stew) and fried dumpling. 

When the budae jjigae came out I was worried that there was not enough spam and sausage, but I was very impressed by the vegetables (it made me feel less unhealthy LOL). However, it turns out all the meat was hiding underneath the ramen square. There was actually lots of meat and at the end we couldn't finish it all. I have a low spice tolerance, so I was scared it would be too spicy, but it ended up being perfect. It was very savory, but naturally sweet at the same time. The savoriness came from the spam and hot dogs (duh), while the sweetness came from the onions, green onions, and rice cake. I also didn't think I would like the beans that much, but I really did. It also came with two servings of rice (as it's made to be shared between two people). Overall, it was a great experience eating this.  

The fried dumpling was very yummy and I liked the texture--I thought it was a perfect balance between chewy and crunch. However, it's not super pretty like you might see at ramen restaurants. I also really liked their soy sauce mix. The portion size for this was also very good--it was quite large for an appetizer dish. If you want, you could just order dumplings and eat that as lunch. 

I liked the service as well. The waitress was very patient, and the waiter who brought out the budae jjigae pot would come back to help us stir it and adjust the heat etc.

I definitely plan to come back again, and I hope to bring a third or fourth person, so we can try more dishes (in addition to the budae jjigae!!!).
author: Sao B.

description:
Food was ok, but be warned - it's got lots of salt or sugar or other spices to hide the real taste of the food. We had the ramen + dukboki combo and it was extremely sweet. My wife loves this meal but could barely eat  even a third of it because of the sugar. My beef tofu soup was good but it had lots of corn starch to give it that artificial hearty soup feel. It also had something in it which I believe was MSG. The daenjang cheegae and kimchi bokum bab was loaded with salt as well.

The food is ok, but it has a junk food quality to it.  It's not something I'd eat regularly.
author: Adam K.

description:
The roommate and I ordered delivery for dinner on Sunday, September 6th. We ordered through Postmates a little before 9pm and received our order around 10pm.

*Corn cheese ($7)
*Spicy pork neck soup: large size ($27)
*Bbq gal bi: beef short rib ($24)
*Steamed pork feet ($18)
*Fried chicken wings: Soy garlic sauce & Spicy sauce ($15 each)
*Spicy rice cake with fish cake and vegetables ($11), add Ramen (+$2)

The food was really disappointing. The only thing I really liked was the kal bi. It had a nice char and some good flavor. The corn cheese wasn't very cheesy. Kinda reminded me of creamed corn but not as sweet. The spicy pork neck soup was just salty and not spicy at all. The steamed pork feet were okay, but I found it more gelatinous from the skin than meaty. Out of the chicken wings, the soy garlic sauce ones were better than the spicy sauce ones. But both didn't really satisfy my wing craving though. They were also mushy. I had a couple bites of the fish cake in the rice cake dish. I didn't care much for it as it was just gooey and didn't have much flavor.

My main complaint is that we didn't receive any rice or banchan from our meal. Isn't that standard with Korean food? Since we had some kimchee at home, I just busted out our homemade kimchi courtesy of the roommate's mom. Someone from the restaurant did contact me after I posted a tip, asked my name and offered to give me a free appetizer the next time I ordered from them. (How I'm going to get my free app, I'm not sure as she didn't follow up after I replied to her.) She said she asked the Postmates driver if we wanted rice and he said no, so I guess it wasn't really their fault. But even without the rice, the food wasn't very good.

Since they made an effort to make up for the lack of rice, I'm giving them 2 stars instead of 1. But based on the quality of the food we received, I probably won't order from them again.
author: Elena N.

description:
Came in here last minute because our original choice was too long of a wait.  Luckily we were able to walk right into 707 Sutter, but I can't say I was that impressed overall.

For those from the Berkeley area, this place has a very similar menu to OB Chicken (there's corn cheese, garlic chicken, and ddukbokki!).  However, the food portions are MUCH SMALLER and the pricing is higher.  But taking into account the fact that this place is near Union Square, I can't complain too much.  My share of the meal did come under $20, which is pretty good in SF.      

My friends and I shared the ddukbokki, corn cheese, bulgogi, and soy garlic chicken.  Everything tasted fine, but again there wasn't much food.  Even the free side dishes were tiny.  And the corn cheese?  $7 for that little tiny thing sigh.      

P.S.  My Korean-culture obsessed self appreciates the Korean music videos playing the OSTs of my favorite dramas and the giant Shin Min Ah cardboard figure in the front (time to rewatch Oh My Venus haha).
author: Shannon L.

description:
I came here with a group of 7 and for the most part, we were all satisfied with what we ordered. I ordered the vegetable soft tofu soup - yummy flavor but I wish there was more substance. Hardly any vegetables (only vegetable I encountered were thin slices of zucchini)! The stone pot bibimbap was delicious with the red sauce, and the kimchee fried rice was noted as bland, surprisingly! I was able to try my friend's 'creamy duk bok ki' (spicy rice cake) and that was incredibly delicious!! Portion size was a little small though for the $15 price - she felt like a good portion of her entree was missing =P 

Pretty solid Korean restaurant! I would be back if I was in the area and craving Korean food.
author: Kris C.

description:
This place was poppin on a Sunday night, so there was a bit of a wait, but pretty minimal since there was just two of us. The vibe of this place is super trendy. The lights are really dim, and they've got a projector showing the latest K-Pop music videos. I had never really listened to K-Pop before my visit to 707 Sutter, but it definitely grew on me and the Korean boy and girl bands are pretty frickin awesome. 

On to the food, we had the galbi short ribs which I had been looking forward to the most, but turned out to be my least favorite of the dishes we had. It was still decent, but I felt like it could've been marinated longer. I really enjoyed the soup with spam and noodles though. It was well spiced and a huge portion that could've fed another person or two in addition to my boyfriend and I. Another awesome dish was the corn cheese. I've never had anything like it in Utah, and it's definitely a must if you like a sweet version of Korean creamed corn with cheese!
author: Monica V.

description:
I came here for a birthday dinner with 16 people. The servers were extremely nice and accommodating toward our huge group! They made the ordering process a smooth one and were quite attentive the whole time we were there. 

The food came out pretty fast and it definitely hits the spot if you're craving for some drool worthy Korean food. 

I've tried the cheese corn, bulgogi, and the soft tofu soup with beef  - all delicious and filling! I also ordered a pitcher of one of their soju drunks that tasted like Yakult. BOMB DOT COM. It had the right mix of alcohol and yogurt...and the right kick for you to want more.  

The place is spacious with a lively ambiance. There's also a huge TV screen on the wall that plays Korean music videos - something to entertain you while you're drinking and eating. 

This is a great spot to have a casual good time with friends!
author: Kristal D.

description:
One Star simply due to their seafood bibimbop in the bowl. There was barely any seafood. You get a huge bowl of rice! Absolutely terrible deal at $11. Also, something is very wrong or off with the bibimbop sauce. It tasted like ketchup, very tangy, and unlike any bibimbop I've ever had. I would stay away. 

Had some of my friend's spicy pork. Equally as unimpressive. Again, something was also wrong or off with the sauce. Pork tasted "stinky." 

The spicy tofu soup with seafood was pretty good. This is the only redeeming value here!

Small dishes, while unlimited, was very basic. Just a few of the cheapest items such as kimchi and fish cake. Nothing exceptional with just a small selection. 

Ambiance isn't great either. There's a huge projector on the side of the wall playing annoying K-pop the entire time. Very distracting (yet irritating). It's also a very dark dining room. 

Service was just fine. 

In summary: Not an expensive place, but still not worth it. Probably the worst tasting bibimbop I've ever had. Bowl full of rice and no seafood is awful and a huge rip-off.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Been to this place 3 times now.

3rd time was with a party of 6 people, and it was late and we wanted something good to eat.

I'm not from the area but decided that this was a pretty good spot to hit up. 


First off, we ordered a lot of food. We got scared we weren't gonna finish even half of the food


It was so, so, good, that we finished the entire thing and ended up ordering more food to go.

The meat is so flavorful, soups amazing, rice, noodles, everything is excellent. 

Highly recommend it for a good dinner at night with friends. I'm a minor so I can't drink but I'm sure it's a good place to grab a beer too. Plus the K-pop playing in the background makes everything better
author: Ethan B.

description: The food here is always great. It's the ideal place to get lots of drinks, Korean food, and KPOP music! Though theres always a wait here, they don't rush you out once you finish your meal. Two thumbs up!
author: Daniel T.

description:
Bibimbap pretty good though I've also had better
Soy garlic chicken wings yummy yummy
Creamy tteokbokki - like mac n cheese and tteokbokki made a match in heaven, note to self: next time try their normal tteokbokki as I suspect they make that well too
Japchae soooo good

Service up to expectations, even though we came in near closing

Large interior with K-pop projected on the walls, nice vibes

Will definitely stop by again if I get a case of the drunchies and am in the area :p

They included 18% gratuity for our group of 5
author: Melody Z.

description: An authentic and relatively affordable place to satisfy that Korean craving! Service was prompt and our food came out within minutes (bc we came early on a Saturday night...be prepared to wait for a table if you come later!) Between five people, we shared a kimchi fried rice, fried chicken, bulgogi, a seafood pancake, creamed corn--all delicious btw--and a large pitcher of soju for just a bit over $100 including tip! All of us left with full and content stomachs.
author: Amy C.

description: Hmm, had a late dinner here with friends. Don't remember much due to the soju but the service was on point and the atmosphere was positive.
author: J L.

description: This is definitely my go-to Korean spot in San Francisco on a cozy night. I found out about this place a while back. The restaurant is pretty big and spacious. They have a projector playing from the wall. Korean music blasted with music videos you can watch. All the times I've came here, I've encountered different servers and each and every one of them are really nice and polite. Customer service to me is a biggie. Who would want somebody to serve you with such negativity right? Not only there service is on point, but there food and drinks! Every time I'm here, I always order a jug of yogurt soju. That's one of your must haves here! The dumpling kimchi stew, kimchi fried rice, and their seafood stew is pretty bomb! I definitely recommend coming here. They close around 2AM everyday. On weekends, they're always packed!
author: Tracy N.

description:
My friend and I both got sick after eating here. I've visited 707 many times, until recently I tasted some stale kimchi and bean sprouts. So we didn't eat those side dishes. But we forgot , the soup we had contains a lot of kimchi. That afternoon, my friend and I all got food poisoning from this. 

While writing this review, it reminded me one time I was eating with another friend. We ordered omelette. It suppose to be golden yellow, but they gave us a brown one. We instantly felt not comfortable with the color. My friend smelled and tried it, the egg wasn't fresh at all. Asked the kitchen to remake for us. The second time was alright. 

Also, their food quality is not stable. I order the same dish all the time, how come they don't look or taste the same?? 

The ironic thing is, I was suggesting 707's BBQ short ribs to my coworker. He gave me a "707? I don't trust this place " face. Then I did get sick that afternoon. 

If our food poisoning didn't happen, I would give 3 stars for the sometimes nice food and good staffing. 

Never going back.
author: Rosalind D.

description:
3 1/2 stars

Ambience: KPop music videos were making me uncomfortable. 

Banchan: Weak. 6 tiny dishes. I'm talking ONE bite. 

Food: Order Bulgogi and a side of fries. Dump the Bulgogi over the fries. You're welcome.

Service: Awesome! Friendly and attentive servers.
author: Grace V.

description:
I came here with a group of 5 on a Sunday night at 6pm and the place was full. We waited about 5 minutes and then we were seated.  

The seafood pancake with the sweet sauce was delicious and tasted fresh.
The fried chicken wings were extremely hot and I would have burned myself if my friend hadn't warned me. 
The military pot with spam and sausage does not come with tofu. However it does come with instant ramen noodles. This dish also comes with 2 bowls of white rice. I thought this dish was kind of a disappointment since the server had told us there would be tofu inside.
We also ordered the large yogurt soju and it was enough for 4-5 shots per person. The drink had a bit of blended ice in it, almost like a frozen margarita.

Service here was almost non existent as there seemed to be only 3-4 people workers total. It was basically impossible to ask for anything unless I waited near the cash register.
author: Edward W.

description:
As a Korean whose mother and all siblings of her used to run Korean restaurants, I'm sure 707 offers the best Korean food in the city.

Must haves : soft tofu soup, spam and sausage stew, stonepot bi bim bop, creamy tteokbokki, soy garlic fried chicken wings, kimchi fried rice, and Jok bal... Too many to list!!!!

Drink prices are also very reasonable for DTSF.
I am currently so obsessed with flavored grapefruit soju and it's $11 per bottle whereas many Korean restaurants in SF usually charge about $13. A pint of tap was just $4 so it might be the biggest bang for bucks in that area.

And our server Angie was friendly, accommodating, helpful, and amazingly attentive while dealing with hectic business. Since I have a degree in hospitality, I appreciated her professionalism a lot and would definitely come back!!!
author: Jaewoo K.

description:
I've come here twice, once was mediocre and the other time was amazing. I think your experience at 707 depends very much on the items you order. It's perfect for a large group, each dish can be split easily between 4-5 people!

So what to get?

DELICIOUS
- Chapchae ($11): I've tried a variety of flavors, their noodles are on point.
- Jjol Bok Ki ($11): Get it with the chewy noodles. The rice cakes are so good!

PRETTY GOOD:
- Spam Kimchi Fried Rice. Yum, you can't really go wrong. Runny egg and all. On the smaller side.
- Fried Chicken Wings ($13): A little dry at times but, cmon - fried chicken wings!
- Kimchi stew: huge portions, and so delicious!
- Kalbi / Bulgogi: pretty standard

MEH
- Banchan: but hey, tis free.
- Yuk Gae Jang: had better
- Kiwi Soju. All sugar, no alcohol.
author: Jess C.

description:
This place is awesome! Love the atmosphere - there were a lot of young people (good for large groups) and they project Korean music videos on the wall. It's great they close super late too! Service was quick and friendly. Banchan here is okay, I noticed we didn't get the complimentary cheesy corn as some reviews mentioned. 

Ordered the kimchi fried rice with beef ($10) and my boyfriend got the tofu soup with beef ($10). The kimchi fried rice was SO GOOD! The flavor was perfect and loved the egg on top. The dish also came with some salad with this amazing mayonnaise dressing. It was fairly spicy. The tofu soup was super spicy I actually could barely handle it without downing several gallons of water but my boyfriend loved it.

Overall highly recommend the kimchi fried rice! I'll definitely be back here again.
author: Linda X.

description:
FOOD:
Good & Fast Korean food here!!! My favorite things here are the soju drinks, the tofu soup, some garlic chicken wings and dukbokki.
