The SOJU drinks are really yummy-I can finish a whole small pitcher by myself. I have tried a handful of flavors including peach, strawberry and aloe. My favorite is the aloe since I normally love aloe drinks! Try it-you can't even taste the alcohol but I can slightly feel it later. The TOFU SOUP is really good here and I usually get the mushroom, meat or seafood ones. They all taste good! Must try the GARLIC CHICKEN WINGS-you get about 10-12 pieces so share if you have a group! And the DUKBOKKI here is really good too! Everything is NOT super spicy especially for being korean food. You also get all the side dishes and refills for free!

SERVICE:
Really fast service!! 

WOULD I RECOMMEND IT? Yes!!! Good for groups too!
author: Kelley Y.

description:
Needing a quick takeout dinner in Union Square, I opted to grab some wings at 707 Sutter early in the evening. The atmosphere here is pretty ridiculous with a giant projected screen filling one wall with nonstop k-pop videos and gaudy lighting throughout. I suppose this is intended as a late night drinking stop for food.

Cheese corn - 3/5 - Decent enough, but it's hard to screw up cheese and corn. Sadly, this was the best of the items I ordered.

Spicy Chicken Wings - 2/5 - These were way too sweet and way too gooey while failing completely at having any kick or spiciness to it. There are so many better places to get asian wings around to ever come here for this. That is sad too because it is the reason why I came here.

Kal Bi - 1/5 - I'm not sure if it's because I got it as takeout, but the quantity I received was so small that I have to question how they can justify the cost. That doesn't even take into account the dryness and lack of flavor of the meat. The two bones were completely impossible to chew any meat off of because the skin and gristle were just ridiculously tough.

Overall, this place clearly holds more value as a drinking and late night venue than as a quality Korean restaurant. Unfortunately, that is not what I was looking for when coming here. For kfc or kalbi, I will be continuing my search at other Korean restaurants in the future. "I think not."
author: Mark O.

description:
Great Haemuljeongol!  Drank 6 soju with this seafood soup and still I didn't get a hangover next day.  Must have a secret ingredient.
Servers were attentive, kind and smiling.  Make you feel comfortable.
Foods, People, and Price - all thumbs up!

Won't miss this place when I am in town.
author: Jay C.

description: 707 Sutter - thank you for having Kimchi Jiggae on your menu.  I was in need of my Korean food fix, and it was worth the walk from my hotel for lunch.  707 Sutter is solid, well-priced Korean.  I am pretty sure it is authentic and as good as any I have had even in Seoul.  I only had the one dish, but it was satisfying.  I'll definitely make the trip again.
author: HotCoffee P.

description:
I came here recently with about 10-12 friends and they were great to accommodate our group!

Everything tasted great but we kept ordering more spicy fried chicken wings (sauce on the side), the cheesy corn, and flavored sojus (kiwi and yogurt were our favs.

They also have a projector playing Kpop music videos so u can watch all the pretty Koreans dance it out while you shovel food into your face- good times
author: Mandi W.

description:
Final Fantasy XIII-2 said 6 hours(!) to install = eff this I'm going out for #nesjjaesigsa trichachos.

...Or so I thought, till all the Kboy bands on the video wall looked like Final Metro Fantasy anyway. #nokromo

(^_^) 72. Steamed Pork Feet / Jokbal $18 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/707-sutter-san-francisco?select=g3a7dfIRgFoSs45I5uWT7A)
George Orwell's Animal Farm

(v_v) 9. Grilled Dried Cuttlefish / Mareunojingeo $8 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/707-sutter-san-francisco?select=iIA99OkRxKhoRlRND1b7nA)
Crispy strips good; rest was army boot leather.

Planning to return post #ramenbowlsfortherestofthemonth to try more dishes despite having to endure more Kpop.

And now my thing says 3 hours left to install. Wait did you just say noraebang's still open across town? Ahem! Sweeet Caaaroliiiiine! Bah, bah, bahhhh!
author: Dan B.

description: This place was super cute and the food was amazing. I ordered the BBQ spicy chicken and I loved it! Bothe dishes we ordered were super spicy so be careful! I'm not a cheese person so I was hesitant about ordering it but The cheese that came with it was delicious!!
author: Diana C.

description:
"Lanie?....Lanie...wake up...LANIE. SNAP OUT OF IT!"

*blinks* "Huh?...oh."'

I was daydreaming again. Lamely, I mumble to my friends that I'm 'tired' and go back to chatting with everyone. Little do they know, and too embarrassed to admit, I was actually imagining myself as one of the k-pop girls dancing on screen. With their cute chic clothing and their perfectly straight hair, lip-synching along to a bouncy chorus with perfectly choreographed dance routine.

My mind starts to wander again before I realize I just spooned a still-bubbling piping hot spoonful of tofu soup into my mouth.

"OUCH!"

I rush to put the fire out with a shot full of mango-flavored soju cocktail and hastily spill half of it all over myself.

"YEAH! CHEERS LANIE WOOHOO!"

They thought I was just celebrating the night. They didn't even notice...

~*~*~*~*~*~*

And so is another fun night here at 707 Sutter. This is the go-to place for fun in the evenings with a group full of friends. Get a large pitcher of fruity soju cocktails. Chug a pint of HITE beer. Stuff yourself with hot stone bowls of bibimbap or tofu soup. The atmosphere is loud and exciting!

-Service is slow, but it doesn't matter since you'll be here for a while anyway.
-Food here is pretty consistent and pretty good!
-Plenty of vegetarian/vegan options. Be careful of the "vegetarian" symbol in the menu. They put them incorrectly on some dishes. Sorry, but "vegetable soup with clams" is not a vegetarian item.

If you're not into the k-pop and the loud cheerings of glasses around you, come here for lunch where it is much quieter and calm.

As for me? I'm still pondering the ideas of packing everything up and moving to become the next K-pop star. Auto-tune technology is pretty advanced now isn't it?
author: Lanie L.

description: This place is across the street from the hotel I was staying in in San Francisco. I walked in late night when nothing else around was open. They welcomed me with open arms! Turns out they offer Korean cuisine, and exceptional it was! Everything I had was delicious. The service was impeccable and even though there weee only about 6 or 8 people in after midnight on a Monday they made me feel special. If you're ever in San Francisco anywhere near this location and you enjoy Korean food or enjoy just good food in general, please visit!
author: Ric O.

description:
So happy we did some Yelping and picked 707 Sutter for dinner last night! It got us talking about whether the location moved, would the name change? But in any case...

I was a bit surprised to see how crowded this place was on a Sunday evening. I had walked by before, but never paid much attention. Over half the 30 or so tables were filled, and many Koreans, so that was a good sign to begin! K-Pop music videos are projected on one wall, which was fun. 

As far as food, I always appreciate the complimentary banchan in Korean restaurants. They had seaweed, kimchi, fish cakes, black beans, & sprouts (sorry, couldn't tell you the legit Korean names). We got corn cheese to start, which was crazy good if you love corn & you love cheese! 

I got bi bim bop with spicy pork in a stone bowl (2 dollars more for the stone, but hey, why not? go for it) and it was very flavorful. Friends got a shrimp fried rice in egg omelette and one of the stews (sorry, couldn't be bothered to pay much attention to their food), but everyone was happy with their dish.
 
I think only one waitress was working, but she was friendly and hustled. I will definitely come back to try more items on the big menu.
author: MaryKate M.

description:
707 Sutter is your typical no-frills Korean restaurant. Not really much to see, but you're here for the food, not lavish decorations and 5 star service! However, the interior is quite drab and could use a little update. Their use of the blank wall as a screen for projecting shows is A1.

We came for lunch and there was no wait. Service was very quick and painless. I got the kimchi soon dubu while everyone else got bulgogi or jjapchae. The food itself was nothing spectacular but definitely hit the spot. However, I found the menu items to be a little pricey for what you get. 

Since we were seated by the window on Santa Run day, we were able to enjoy our food while watching the hilarity and strangely dressed drunk santas outside.

If you flip the menu upside down 707 becomes LOL.

Yelp 100 Challenge - 2016 [6/100]
author: Pim Y.

description:
My favorite Korean restaurant in the city so far :-) tried a few other places in the Richmond, downtown and sunset, and we just keep coming back. We usually do one rice/pancake dish and another meat one. We've had kimchi fried rice, omurice (hard to find elsewhere!), seafood pancake, bi bim bap and most of the bbq meat options. The food has just been consistently good. Also tried their yogurt soju and $5 piña colada and they were pretty tasty and strong.

Also love the ambiance here. Pretty spacious, and Korean music videos on the wall :D Arts stuff at the entrance as well.
author: Jaclyn C.

description:
Food: 4 stars
Service: 2.5 stars

I checked yelp before I ordered and some of the recommendations were excellent.

Cheese corn: sweet and savory together. Absolutely delicious! Not worth $7 though. It is afterall cheese and corn, two super cheap ingredients.

Stone pot bim bim bop: Past couple of times I got this dish at other restaurants, the pot wasnt hot enough, not crisping the rice enough. 707 actually had it well hot enough and I had some great crispy rice. Ingredients in it were great, shitake mushrooms, carrots, dicot, seaweed, chicken, all good.

Seafood pancake: great! texture of it was amazing, but seafood pieces weren't big enough. I had little squid pieces here and there with majority veggies. Didn't taste much of the seafood

Spicy pork: Tasty, nothing special
Bul Gol Gi: Tasty, nothing special
Soft Tofu soup: too spicy for my family, wasn't expecting that. Ok flavor. Though they did cook their rice really well, nice and chewy/sticky.

Service: Like other reviews said, non existent. I get that they are busy, but can't they get more workers??? They get enough business it looks like. The only thing I wanted more of was the banchan, they were pretty good. No wonder why they have plates of three instead of little individual side bowls. I'm glad that we had gotten here early enough before the crowds of people, so our food came out pretty quickly, too. The water refills were actually pretty fast.

Setting: It was soooo dark in there to even know what we are eating. Maybe a bit more light would be better so we can see the food. From what I saw in the dark, it looked good, but I still want to see it better.

Not bad though, the food was delicious, but their other things could be changed a bit.
author: Stanley C.

description:
Came here on a Saturday night and there was a wait, but it was worth it.

Food: Everything was good!! We shared the following amongst 6 people and it was a perfect amount.
-Bulgogi
-Short ribs: these were the best!! So flavorful and tender. I'm usually racing for the bulgogi, but here, I'm all about the short ribs. Some of the meat comes on the bone, but the bulk of it is off the bone which makes for really easy eating.
-BBQ chicken
-Corn cheese: funny to have this at a Korean restaurant but it was yummy.
-Seafood pancake
-Beef tofu soup
-Beef glass noodles

Service: The waiter was rushed and working very hard. He was very strict though, constantly arranging our glasses and plates so that they were all the same and in order. We just found it entertaining, but it wasn't really necessary.

Ambiance: K-pop was streaming on the wall. Overall a fun atmosphere and good for groups. Not too loud to hold a conversation.
author: Susan G.

description:
I would categorize this place as a Korean bar more than a restaurant. I like that they show Kpop videos on the wall via projector and it is loud so don't expect anything less than loud alcohol filled patrons. The area is a bit shady and is hard to find street parking but 707 Sutter does Budaejigae (army stew) surprisingly well. It's called army stew because in Korea when it was cold, the soldiers in the milirary didn't have much to eat or options so they threw in a bunch of run of the mill ingredients and there you go. 

The broth was flavorful and not as spicy as it looked as is the case with most Korean stews. The broth reminded me of the taste of kimchi stew. The budaegijae here has everything from sliced rice cake, instant ramen noodles, spam, sausage, jalapenos, carrots, and beans. This was the first place that serves beans inside the stew which was a bit odd but they're easy to avoid and brush to the side. This stew is plentiful and can easily serve 3-4 people depending on appetites. 

The spicy chicken wings were good as well. The wings and drumsticks had a lot of meat on them and the exterior had a nice crunch but were not very spicy. I'd give the wings 3.5 stars and would have appreciated more of a kick with heat. 

This is a good spot to get drinks and have some wings among other typical Korean bar grub.
author: James H.

description:
Honestly I don't understand how this place is only rated 3.5 stars. It was my second time here and again my food was utterly amazing. 

But what was most amazing was the service. 
Jaden took such good care of me and my friends. I eat gluten free and he took his time to explain all the things on the menu and what was gluten free. 

He also recommended all the best things off the menu.. We tried some of the things and O MAAAI GOSHHH. He was so right. 

The cheese corn is absolutely delicious. 

The beef that my friend had, based on jaden's recommendation was to die for. 

They even turned on the music videos because we asked it. 

Absolutely great place. It fully deserves 5 stars. 
Com'on Yelp'ers of SF, you should rate better! 

(Also: $5 cocktails!!!)
author: Judith S.

description:
Came here with my friend, Michele...we were hoping to get into Cocobang, but the wait was estimated to be an hour long (wtf).  Saw 707 and thought, "why not"?

Crowd was mixed, but mostly Korean.  Kpop playing on the wall was mesmerizing.  In fact, a little more mesmerizing than the food.  

Family style... But portions are on the smaller side...or, perhaps, I eat a lot (lady lifter in gaining mode).  

What I had: bulgogi and dolsot bimbimbap.

Nobody can ruin bimbimbap, IMHO.  Love the stuff.

Price is moderate.  Portions are enough for 1 person...and if you are sharing...then, for 2 people with smaller appetites (not me).
author: Hiromi N.

description: For the price, this meal didn't really impress. The meat was dry and the portion sizes weren't worth it. It didn't taste like the bulgogi had really been marinaded at all. The spices and flavors felt like they came from a jar and not fresh. 707 was pretty empty when we showed up for dinner; only 2 other tables were occupied, and no one else showed up while we were there. The server pretty much ignored us, and though I ordered a drink, he never brought it. I wouldn't recommend this place.
author: Lauren P.

description: This review is for their WINGS.  HOLY MOLEY are they awesome!!!!  Hot and spicy and CRUNCHY.  Just the way I like it.  and be sure to pair it with some soju. Service was attentive and the restaurant was clean.   solid delish 5 star wings.
author: Julia D.

description:
Satisfied the Korean food cravings. They have the classics as well as the stuff available at the soju bar type places (corn cheese, fruity flavored soju drinks). 

Good was ok, no complaints. Nothing's worse than a mushy, undercooked pancake and here it was crispy, well-cooked and flavorful. Definitely a plus! The cream ddukbokki was actually better than I imagined (I'm currently trying to avoid overly spicy) and it wasn't soggy or overcooked. 

Although I'm Korean, I'm not at all interested in K-pop so I couldn't care less about the oversized wall projection of the videos playing before me. In fact, I found it pretty obnoxious but others seem to have enjoy the entertainment. 

Quick service and orders were brought over fairly quickly. I'd come back.
author: Esther A.

description: Pretty good chicken, but there are plenty if better places in the city. Great ambience, service ok. Other dishes were delicious too. Would go again.
author: Dan G.

description:
Food was pretty tasty but service was so-so. Came here because a friend was visiting from out of town. We had a total of 6 people eating dinner, but me and a friend were first to arrive and be seated. We weren't really served (ie given water) until more people in our party came. While we waited, I was pretty thirsty, and eventually I couldn't wait any longer and asked for a glass.  I learned that service starts once everyone arrives and is seated, otherwise you'll be pretty much be ignored.

Banchan that were served were pretty tasty for the most part.  The banchan were served on a plate with small slots, which included kimchi, beansprouts, green rapeseed veggies, sweet soybean, and fish cake.  Of the banchan, the worst was the kimchi-- it was spicy but bland in flavor... I think they forgot to toss in the salt or the fish sauce when they made the kimchi.  

I ordered the haemul dolsot bibimbap (seafood bibimbap in stone pot) which was pretty standard (tasty and fresh) when comparing other bibimbaps I had at other Korean joints.  You can never really go wrong with bibimbap at any Korean place.  By the way if you like your bibimbap rice to crisp up in the stone pot, the seafood bibimbap doesn't really allow for it.  Why? Because the seafood that is added to the bibimbap is "marinated" in a wet sweet chili (I think predominantly gochujang) that makes the rice wet/soggy. Sad times... But still tasted good.

Overall 707 Sutter offers some pretty good Korean fare at a reasonable price.  However don't expect world class service!
author: Matthew L.

description: I really miss Korean food. In my hometown it's damn near impossible to find one. I try to find a good one whenever I'm in sf. This place was great. Not crowded but I was eating at 4 pm. They had my faves. Bulgogi was very good, kimchi chigea was hot and good. The small plate apps were also a delight. It was clean and modern. Staff was friendly and knowledgeable. I'll be back for sure.
author: Eric D.

description: I had their tofu beef soup and their budaejigae. Both were just alright. The soup broth was very thick and was hard to eat. The budaejigae was horrible by the way, I had to even it out with some water and towards the end gave me an upset stomach. Their service wasn't that great either, but it does get busy so I'll give them that. They have plenty of choices on the menu which is nice to see, but for staples like their tofu soup they should really work on a better broth....cmon it's really not that hard.
author: Brian P.

description:
This spot is good for post-HH or some time later that night. Usually, many places serve salty, or spicy, or greasy foods when you're in a drunken-buzzed state. Here though, even if you haven't been drinking the food is pretty good. I cannot vouch for to-go orders, lol, but the eat-ins have always been good.

They have most of the Korean mainstays so you're good whatever you're used to. We normally get an appetizer, a noodle soup or jap chae, and an entree. Plus, their casserole soup (budae jigae for example) is huge. Be careful when ordering one of those if have less than 4 people!

Usually k-pop music videos are projected on a large screen, which fills up one of the wall.  While loud inside it is still bearable because the place is spacious - tables are spread out and with a high ceiling. They also rotate with hip-hop and western pop music videos so the place can be pretty fun if you don't want your night to end.
author: Peter L.

description:
I saw plenty of great reviews and wanted to try this place. My bf and I came here the other night for a double date. The Chicken katsu was great! Perhaps because we were super hungry but the ramen with dukbokki really let me down. I feel like you really can't fail at making dukbokki but this place did. 

Soju was so weak, sake was horrid. I just don't like weak alc. 

The service is a bit slow. I've had better service and better food in oakland. If you're looking for good oakland korean food, try bowld or even by telegraph theres plenty! 

The only good thing about this place is that they play videos and have lots of korean music which is great vibes. 

Long story short- I felt like this place was disappointing.
author: Amy Y.

description:
We know our Korean as my wife is from there! The kimchi pancakes were pretty good as they had a nice spicy sauce with them, but why bring them at the same time as the meal and not as a starter like it was requested ? Not sure ,but no biggie. I had the #51 bibibomp in a stone (hot stone is always better but you have to eat fast as it sticks to it) which was OK. 

The food in general so far in SF has been OK. It feels as if places are all fairly casual as folks are in sneakers and all due to the massive hills you have to climb to get somewhere. The good part is you build up an appetite. 

I do like that there is a projection TV here and you can see the Korean music artists. Wow so funny , they be looking like kids or something on Barney. I like to immerse myself into different cultures as it allows me to see how superior I am .

If you're driving,there no valet and parking is very, very , I mean crazy tough.
author: Daniel C.

description: Came here on a Saturday night and there was no line when my friend and I came in, but as we were leaving the guests started to form a line. All their food was flavorful! Enjoyed all of it. Their soy-garlic chicken was delicious as well!
author: Dee A.

description: For Korean food in the downtown area, this is the place to go. It is decently sized so the wait won't be horrible. Decor reminds me of a fast food joint. They have a projector that projects K-pop music videos onto the wall. The service here is decent and they have a large variety of items on their menu. They offer big portions and a small amount of ban chan that is pretty tasty. Great place for large groups but not really an ideal place for a date.
author: Sarah C.

description: Food is great! The spicy chicken wings are to die for and the Korean BBQ is just as good. I would have given this place a 5 star but the time me and my beautiful friend was there, they were preparing tables for a big party. Completely ignoring us until we asked for service. I'd come back but not anytime soon, I'll keep searching for that perfect spot where the food is great and the service is definitely one of the best.
author: Randy A.

description: Delicious food and great service, my lunch was seasoned to perfection
author: Alan F.

description:
I've been here a bunch of times when Cocobang was packed (it's just down the street) and I love that

1) Usually no line
2) Huge space with seating for groups 
3) Fun projector showing K-Pop songs

We came here with a group and ordered a bunch of fried chicken wings and starters to share. We didn't order enough so we re-ordered wings (spicy chicken wings). The order came out and it was spicy chicken on a plate. We called the waiter back and said he got our order wrong...we had only been eating chicken wings and seafood pancake all night, we just wanted a re-up. 

He said no refunds. We politely said we weren't going to eat this anyway and please give us our money back for the dish or bring out chicken wings. He was being so rude (he put his shirt over his face and said "What are you gonna do huh?") and we almost got in a fist fight with him. He literally wanted to take this outside. 

Worst. Experience. Ever. I had been here a bunch of times and recommended my friends to come. Now i'm embarrassed that I even suggested 707 and will never come back again. Shame on your staff!
author: Jennifer J.

description:
OMG i llluuuurrrveee 707. it is my FAVE korean spot in the city, BY FAR.

the spicy chicken wings here, are to die for. goodness they're good. sticky and crunchy on the outside, tender and juicy on the inside. a full order comes with 10, and i can probably polish all of them off.

the banchan here is also pretty great. unlimited, and free, and mmmm! hehe. 

but honestly, i have not had a bad dish here. my go-to's are the budae ji gae (for 2), the jap chae and probably the bulgogi or the fiery squid dish (ramen optional). i love to take leftover sauce home and make spicy korean fried rice with it as well. SO GOOD. literally will probably be back in the next 2 weeks or so. hehe.
author: Christina L.

description:
We came on a Saturday night (around 1am) and it was very crowded. They were evidently understaffed and we had to wait a long time for service.

The food was decent and it definitely felt good to eat piping hot tofu soup on a cold rainy night. I especially enjoyed the japchae which was soft, tasty and flavorful. The banchan selection was pretty decent as well.

4 stars for food
1 star for service.
author: Christina N.

description: Awesome food, awesome beer selection, open space, not in the crappy part of the Tenderloin.
author: B H.

description:
Decent Korean restaurant in Union Square. I've been here twice with friends.

The food is pretty standard for Korean restaurants. Highlight was definitely the seafood pancake - very tasty and filled with lots of seafood. Bibimbap was okay, could have used a bit more meat and vegetables. Bulgogi was okay, a little bit overburnt. Tofu soup was very spicy.
author: Alvin W.

description: Had my first corn cheese here! The combo with the sausages, spicy tteboki, and ramen was good for sharing between two people as well. Definitely order the korean wings as well!!
author: Vivian P.

description:
Yummm....

I brought two folks here one rainy night - one had never had Korean food before - this was a good introduction for her! I ordered for the table - seafood tofu soup, bulgogi, corn cheese and kimchi fried rice. They were all very good - best corn cheese I've ever had! Yelpers advised me to get the kimchi fried rice and they weren't wrong - so good, even though I'm not crazy about fried rice. I am now also obsessed with K Pop which streamed on the wall while we ate. Banchan was ok, I wish it was a little more elaborate and there was more of it.

Pro tip - write your name on the clipboard to the left in the entrance when you get there to put your name on the list if there's a wait - though it moves quickly.
author: Emily V.

description:
I will preface this review by saying that I have never been a big fan of Korean food. I love trying food from countries all over the world, and I love many types of Asian food. Chinese, Thai, Japanese, Vietnamese, Burmese etc. For whatever reason, Korean food has never been high on my list, but with that said, I was very impressed with 707 Sutter.

I went with a group of 7, and we ordered the following:

- Corn cheese
- Spicy Kimchi Fried Rice
- Chicken Wings
- Seafood Pancake
- Spam and Sausage Stew with Ramen and Kimchi
- Sides of White Rice
- Soju and Beer

My first warning would be to watch out for the spicy food. My friend (who grew up in Korea) was literally sweating drips of sweat because of the spice from the fried rice, and the sausage stew. There are spicy and non-spicy options on the menu, but just be aware that they are not kidding when they label their food spicy. Personally, I'm a big fan of spicy food, so I really enjoyed the meal. It's hard to say what was best, because everything tasted great, but I would lean more towards the fried rice and the seafood pancake.  

This is a great place to go with a group of friends and share several plates of food. The restaurant has a nice, relaxed atmosphere, and they also play music videos on the wall, while you eat. As far as Korean food goes, this place is worth checking out.
author: Andrew L.

description:
Korean food on New Years Eve, ayyyyyy. I came here on NYE to celebrate my friends birthday and of course, NYE. We originally planned to meet at 8:30 pm or something but we waited a good while before we were seated. 

TIP: have your whole party there or they won't seat you & make a reservation ahead of time. 

I ordered the corn cheese since I already ate before hand, but needed the food since we were drinking. We ordered the large peach and yogurt soju. 

PROS: 
 1. Variety of banchan which they gave us 2 sets since we were a table of 7, which was really nice. 
 2. Corn cheese was so good, but how do you really mess that up. 
 3. Huge ass projector on the wall showing Korean music videos. Different, I like it. 
 4. At first I thought the large size of the soju was really small, but I think we each had our fair amount by the end of the night. Both sojus were tasty. 
 5. Service was good despite it being so busy. 
 6. Portions of the food are huge!

Overall, I think this is a fun place to catch up with friends. I definitely want to return to try some actual food one day. Prices were pretty good. The corn cheese itself was $7 and after tax, tip, splitting 2 large sojus and the corn cheese, and paying for the birthday girl, I paid around $17.
author: Vivian Y.

description:
Came here a few nights ago with coworkers after HH

Jap Chae - Portion was on the smaller side, that aside noodles were cooked well and flavored properly 
Korean Spicy Wings - lacquered in a fiery crimson sauce that is not for the faint of heart, would have preferred if it was more balanced
Bim Bap in stone bowl with Spicy Pork - the nuggets of crispy rice is always a delight, all the ingredients were fresh and vibrant. Pork had a nice kick but felt there could have been more protein
Seafood Pancake - the ratio of pancake to seafood was done well, a solid job well done
Spicy Tofu Soup - heat notes were present and detected some savory elements, felt straight forward
Fried Calamari - solid crunch factor, seasoned well, curious if its from a package due to the perfect circular nature

Overall Thoughts

Now that I've gone through the core staples the only left is to sample their korean bbq options to see if it sways me differently
author: Eddie W.

description:
This Korean restaurant is pretty awesome!!

I like that this restaurant is clean and people are quite professional to work. This place is the only one that I was satisfied with the quality of Korean food, and the taste of Korean food was way much better than other places. In addition, I also love what they keep turning on a lot of Korean music videos!! You guys should visit this place and u r gonna love it!! :)
author: Yunho K.

description:
I came here last night around 7 as a group of four and we were seated immediately. We ordered the Spam Soup, Kalbi, Corn&Cheese, and Bi Bim Bap (mine). The service was quick, not super friendly but more business-like which was cool with us since we had just trekked up from Union Square. 

Food arrived within 5-10 minutes piping hot. I didn't try the other dishes but their spice level sounds pretty high and my friends enjoyed it. Even my bi bim bap had some heat to it even though it wasn't advertised as spicy on the menu. I would rate it a 2-3 out of 10 on the spicy scale. I would say there was a bit too much sauce; my friend gave me some rice to help remedy that. The quality was good regardless.

The ambience is casual, on the loud side (there was a loud party enjoying some soju next to us). We enjoyed watching the Kpop music videos on the wall. Overall 707 Sutter is a decent Korean place that is good for groups and fun chats.
author: David P.

description:
Ordered the seafood tofu soup and stir friend vegetables for delivery via Postmates. 

The soondubu came with rice and some ban chan on the side, and it was just okay. The kimchi tasted like it came from a jar, and the soup was very thin. 

The main reason for the two star review is the stir fried vegetables. It cost $12 and it was a tiny amount of sad vegetables and tofu stir fried in what tasted like store bought marinade. The eggplant was rubbery and inedible, and was a waste of money. 

There aren't many options for Korean food on this side of the city, but I won't be ordering from here again. Not worth it.
author: Stephanie Y.

description: I ate there once and got severe allergy. The food and service were both good, but if you are sensitive to "not that fresh seafood" items, avoid this place. I ordered bibimbab and seafood pancake and that was my first meal of the day. I went to hospital right after due to serve seafood allergy =(
author: Tia C.

description:
707 is an acquired taste. 

You try 707 for the first time and it appears to be your typical grungy Korean bar, although quite spacious and you immediately notice the massive, projected music videos on the wall.

On your second visit, you start to notice the amazing food selection and develop a craving for the jap chae + soju combination.

On your third visit, you realize how nice the waiters are and will have become a more generous tipper. At that point you'll have had a beer too many, and swear to never return again.

The fourth visit is when you acknowledge you love this place and will write a 5-paragraph yelp review for it.
author: Vivian W.

description: Nice ambiance, excellent taste. Had fire wings and budae jigae. Taste pretty legit. Definitely would come back next time and order different dishes
author: Alfona K.

description:
Offers pretty good food, but I expected more spice. The ingredients were all good, just missing the extra kick I like. 
Budae jigae was great, with some cheesy goodness. I wish the rice cakes weren't super soft and overcooked though (may have been our fault since we can control the heat, whoops). But I would come back for this still. 
Kimchi fried rice was average.
Service was good, I didn't come on a busy night so I didn't witness the slow service everyone else talks about.
author: Vence M.

description:
The partner and I were craving soju and good kimchi fried rice - it was a toss up between a place we'd tried before and 707 Sutter (doesn't the name just roll off your tongue?), and us being us, we wanted to try a new place! So off we go around 1230am, because I had just gotten off work, and there were only a few parties there. We were seated immediately and were given the menu. Since as I mentioned earlier, it was our first time there, we turned to Yelp to give us advise on what to order.

Based on this, we ordered the seafood tofu soup for $11 (seafood soon doo bu) - this was DELICIOUS. I was craving korean tofu soup, and I loved the flavor of 707's soup: spicy but not unbearably spicy. The pieces of seafood were perfect, and I appreciated that they used peeled, deveined shrimp - because I have had this soup with shrimp still completely in shell and it was not a fun experience. 

In addition to this, we also had the kimchi fried rice for $10 - delicious! We also ordered the yogurt soju (small for $15) and the fried chicken wings half and half (regular fried chicken and the house special sauce - 10 pieces x $14) - this we could've passed on, it was the least impressive fried chicken I'd ever had. The regular fried chicken was dry and flavorless - literally just salt and pepper. The house special sauce was too tart and not at all spicy, we literally tried one of each wing and took it to go. Last but not least we loved the yogurt soju! It tasted like yakult with the right mix of alcohol and yogurt - not too sugary! 

All in all, we had a good time. The k-pop music videos playing on a screen on the wall were very amusing and some of the songs made us pull out our phones and shazam them! The tables are spread out very nicely (unlike other Korean restaurants where you're literally elbow-to-elbow w/ other patrons) with a nice open space.The restaurant got insanely busy right after we arrived, and the servers got a little busy, but we didn't hold this against them. I would definitely come back for the soup, soju and the rice, but skip on the chicken wings!
author: Kathleene E.

description:
Good food and good price in the downtown area. 
Ordered Beef Bibimbap and It was pretty good just wish there's more meat than rice though. 
The ambience was cool. I like the large monitor screen that plays K Pop music.
author: Kath S.

description:
Out of the three Korean restaurants in downtown (or even in San Francisco), this is my go to restaurant, enough said. 

There is a good list of food and besides some of the best foods that you have to eat here, the rest is all (so much) above average. Here are my suggestions:
Chokbol--Pig Feet (They have the best Chokbol, and even if you go by yourself and you can't finish it, order it still and pack for later)
Seafood Tteokbokki or better yet, Seafood Rabokki (Dip that Pig Feet with the sauce here. You're welcome)
Corn Cheese (The best find)
Chicken Gizzard
Seafood Tofu Soup
Bibimbap
Any type of spicy stew pot

Not recommend Spicy Fried Chicken but the rest is all safe choice.

Besides, this is probably the first time I have to praise for their service. One of the guys here is magic, and by all mean, magic. He comes with the food, takes like a second to observe *underlined*, and perfectly arrange the dishes to the perfect arrangement. He doesn't care if I need to have my phone and my wallet on the table or my friend needs to have her arms on the table when she talks to me. If there is no place, he would put those objects away (not my friend's arms of course--or not yet, I'd say) without even asking. #likeaboss. I don't know if this is his main job or not but that thought when you look at someone doing their job and you think in your head, they are born to do it, like a fish is supposed to swim and Einstein is supposed to be smart (whatever he said). This is just that. It's very pleasing to the eyes and I have to applaud for his attitude. Much respect from me.

Other than that, great atmosphere to hangout with friends, good Korean music (love their taste), what else not to love? Oh that 18% gratuity tip...
author: Tran N.

description:
I had the kimchi soft tofu stew and Bulgogi. Now, I am quite snobbish when it comes to Korean food, having been spoiled with homemade kimchis and food both in U.S.A & South Korea. Take my insight with a grain of salt. 
First, the banchan. I was hoping for more variety. Dinner comes with 6 type of banchan (2 types of cabbage kimchi, spinach, fish cake, kelp, and black beans)
Comes the meal, the soft tofu stew was nothing special. Honestly, a bit too mild on the flavor.
The bulgogi was better than the stew. The meat can use more marinade.
Aside from the meal, the service was good and attentive. Kpop was continuously playing and can be a bit loud. Perhaps not great for first date. But for getting drunk on soju with friends? Yes!
author: Jenny T.

description:
This place is spacious so it seems a bit empty.  They need more tables/chairs or rearrange the space.  Perhaps more casual seating with sofas and long tables?  Something to make it less cold and more cozy.

Other than that, the service was quick and efficient. The food is pretty good too.  While I am loyal to Cocobang, I have to admit the food is better here.
author: Chris L.

description:
Why do I keep thinking I've already reviewed this place? They're like our neighborhood canteen. We come here at least once a month.   

If you're deciding between 707 and Cocobang, ask yourself how hungry you are first. Cocobang has limited seating and for the same reason we have turned around many times and went straight to 707. 

Banchan (small dishes) are always yummy and aren't always the same. They are also more than welcome to refill them too.

707 serves great food. Items you must try:
Soon do bu
Kimchi fried rice
Spicy jabchae
author: Michelle C.

description:
This place is huge! I'm surprised that I never knew of this location before. Very convenient for Korean food in downtown and open late. It's got a bar feeling and kpop music videos projecting on the wall. I stopped by here yesterday night for dinner with some friends. 

We ordered kimchi fried rice, bibimbap, japchae, and a small bottle of yogurt soju which came in a plentea bottle. These were pretty standard Korean dishes. Nothing amazing, but definitely hit the spot. The yogurt soju was good! It tastes like Yakult. Three stars because nothing too special and the banchan is really small. Prices are around $10-$15 for dishes and soju is $15 for small and $30 for large. I'd definitely come back if I'm craving Korean food and in the area.
author: Christina G.

description: The food was really good, and the yogurt soju cocktail was even better. But it's on the pricier side so be prepared for that! The ambience is very casual, with Korean music videos playing in the background~
author: Erin J.

description:
Yelped this place because we were feeling like Korean food for dinner. We got there around 7:30PM and there was a group of 2 ahead of us, but they are SERIOUSLY understaffed so there was quite a wait before we got seated.

FOOD:
- seafood pancake - good! Big portion and thick, not super thin and crispy like some other places.
- kal guk soo (hot noodle soup with vegetables and clams) - YUM YUM! There must have been mountain yam in it because the noodles were so sticky and delicious! Super good broth and slippery sticky noodles = makes me super happy!
- spicy chicken wings - an order of 10. These were nice and garlicky! Not too spicy, but served piping hot and definitely burned the roof of my mouth

SERVICE:
They are SO SO understaffed and unorganized!! There were only 2 girls working that I could see. The line to get seated was long and confused because there was a whiteboard and a piece of paper to write your names down. We also waited an extra 10-15 minutes to be seated because there were several empty tables but no one had time to clear them.

Once we were seated, we placed our order and got our food quickly enough. Our request for more water and extra napkins came quickly enough. Servers are friendly but slightly frazzled. Neither of them were slow, but the place just needs more staff!

VENUE:
Pretty spacious! Dim as well. Bathrooms are single stalls for each gender and relatively clean. At the end of our meal, they started projecting Korean music videos on the wall. That was a bit strange...

I'd come back for the food, but hopefully on a day with more staff!
author: Yenny D.

description: the spicy and tangy chicken wing is sooo good. But, so spicy! Warning to those who can't handle hot and spicy food.
author: An C.

description:
I went here the other night, craving for cheese and corn. It was a chill ambiance. Theres a projector that fills up one whole wall and plays K-POP throughout the night. 

The waiter was nice and was patient with us. I ordered Spicy pork and corn cheese. It wasnt bad at all, my friends order the chicken with cheese, which was spicy but good, I was able to eat my while plate. I would come again if my friends were craving but nothing that I got to try again. 

The waiter was awesome, while we were watching the music videos playing there was one artist who we didnt know. The waiter found out what was her name, thanks man!! 

Overall good experience, just got to look for street parking outside.
author: Kaycee-zhanel C.

description:
The name and address is 707 Sutter. 

And what kind of business is 707 Sutter?

It is a Korean restaurant, an Asian cuisine I don't often dine but crave for occasionally.

You can easily tell that the owners have no ingenuity in naming the restaurant. 

But don't let the bland name of the restaurant prevent from coming here. These young cats are cool and treat you like a part of the family. 

I was here two weeks ago for lunch and craving for a bowl of BiBimBap. This restaurant offers two kinds of the popular rice bowl, regular bowl for $10 and a stone clay bowl for $12.00. I took the beef with bean sprouts, wild greens, an egg, julienned carrots and rice in a "707" degrees clay bowl. I may not be David Carradine in handling the hot stone clay bowl with my bare hands, but the steaming rice bowl made me sweat while I was enjoying my meal. My rice bowl: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/707-sutter-san-francisco?select=g4cUKC11o7SNGKbMeAq2HA#CuZxz1jeDgCzzdn0FjqMrQ

I love the vibe and the dark ambience of this new Korean restaurant so much that I bought my daughter with me for dinner; the day before my Labor day trip. We ordered the Chicken katsu and an order of Kim Chee Fried Rice. For $12.00, I get four pieces of panko-battered and cut up Chicken pieces with the sauce. For $10.00, Kim chee mixed with fried rice.  I have had better Chicken katsu elsewhere. But the kim chee fried rice is one rice dish I find very unique for everybody including vegetarians. Fried rice:  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/707-sutter-san-francisco?select=g4cUKC11o7SNGKbMeAq2HA#tngZXW9ma-FA1iIyJCUtHw    

All meals, including my two visits, come with a side dish of Banchan. 

As we were enjoying our meals, we were watching and listening to music videos from the hottest K-Pop entertainers in a wall projection television. 

Majority of the dining patrons are students from the Academy of Arts. 

Another solid Korean Restaurant near Union Square; and the prices are reasonable. 

707 Sutter is the name and the address. If you land at 703, you will end up at Subway!
author: Matt G.

description:
Really cool kpop atmosphere-- they have large party seating by the video projection. Came to eat with my dad. Enjoyed the space, variety of food options, clean bathrooms. Service could be a little quicker and a bit more attentive; though it was busy and the servers were moving swiftly. 

Food was interesting n decent enough. 

*Tried the clam noodle soup (clam flavor, did not actually find any clams. The noodle was thick and soft, and so was the gravy soup-- would try again if dining partner hates spicy); 
*the chicken skewers (order comes with 3 skewers-- tasty-ish appreciate the variety); *the pork cutlet (prefer the katsu cuts a little thicker than what was served); 
*the kimchi seemed to have variety; albeit sparse portions .depending on what one orders-- they seem to serve different kimchi dishes depending on which entrees one orders. Also I asked for more side dishes, which never came :/
*the apple martini, and the mojito were decent for the price-- a bit on the sweeter side 

Anticipating and excited for a return visit with some friends to try 707's take on other Korean fare!
author: Alexander T.

description: 707 is a dangerous place, I'll always find myself wanting to order half the menu. My go to are the potato Croquettes and a steamed egg soufflé. May substitute the rice cakes in cream sauce if feeling up to it. It's a cozy establishment that can still serve a few large groups, with prices on par with SF but not insane, highly recommended. I've gone with 6-7 friends and set up at a few tables pushed together, and the wait staff is just as pleasant as if I had a party of two. Food is always brought out quick and HOT. -- if you don't want to get burnt, patience is a virtue.
author: Seth M.

description:
Pretty good korean food, decent service (but pretty slow), and reasonable prices for SF. I tried one of their stir fry dishes (comes with a bowl of white rice) and the kimchi fried rice. It's not that much food for ~10-15 dollars, but I guess I just accept that because we are in SF.

I really like the yogurt soju! I shared a small sized yogurt soju with some friends and it was really funny that they served it in one of those glass bottles from Plentea.........anyway, the yogurt soju tasted really good (the small size cost $15 I think).

They have pretty slow service which has been noted. When we got the check, I put my card down to pay but it took them so long to take my card that I ended up just walking up to the counter to pay so that I wouldn't have to wait anymore.

They have a huge empty white wall where they project random korean music videos onto. This is definitely not everybody's thing but it's kind of entertaining to me haha.
author: Theresa L.

description:
This place gives me mixed feelings. I came here expecting an amazing time due to the high reviews, but 85 reviews is not enough for an accurate reflection.

Walked in around 7pm and we were seated immediately and provided water and menus. Everything was a little bit slow from this point on. Very.... slow....

We decided what we wanted and set our menus down. All the waiters and waitresses were busy, but barely looked our way. We talked amongst ourselves, and a while later, a waitress comes over to take our order. The order consisted of Gal Bi, and Kimchi Jjigae.

After placing our orders, we were somewhat promptly provided our side dishes. 

Ban Chan - These side dishes were not substantial (aka, not enough in both quantity of each item, and quantity of items). My friend ate some of the cold noodles and told me they were stale. I was unsure of what to make of her comments, so I tried it myself. Yup, stale... it wasn't even soggy! Just stale, like a stale cracker, but in the form of a noodle. Anyway, refills were free, and we were provided more of the stuff, but even less variety. Meh, I'm not impressed.

Gal Bi - This dish was tasty and was a large portion. By large I mean larger than most korean places serve this dish. The meat was tender, juicy, succulent, (am I being redundant now?). There were two large meat-in-bone pieces that I can appreciate. I don't see that too often, but I see it once in a while.

Kimchi Jjigae - This was perfectly spicy, with kimchi and tofu. It was very delicious though a bit on the saltier side. I guess that's why there's rice.

We were ignored and it was really hard to waive somebody down. For both refills on water / ban chan, and getting/paying the check. It took a while to leave the place. When we were leaving, there was a huge line almost out the door!

+Pretty good flavoured food / entrees
+Decent size (for the price)
+Accepts Credit Cards
+Open late
--Terrible ban chan quality and variety
--Service was definitely lacking here.
--There is projector projecting a huge display on the wall. The display is of K-Pop music videos. This is pretty distracting, especially if you're trying to have a conversation. 

Overall, I've seen better. A lot better. I probably won't return, and I'm a bit iffy on recommending this place, but I'm going to say try it once. Just keep in mind that while the food is pretty good, the service is not.
author: Kaje Y.

description: Great place to have dinner on a Saturday night. The menu is big so there is a lot to choose from. I got the spicy buck noodles with vegetables. The buck noodles came with an egg and some pickled vegetables. You get to add as much spicy sauce as you'd like. The sauce was not too spicy and had the right amount of sweetness to it. My friend got the corn cheese appetizer and the rice cake dish with cream sauce and bacon. Apparently they're known for the corn cheese appetizer which tasted pretty good. The servers were really attentive and quick. The ambiance was very dim. They also had Kpop videos being projected onto the wall. Side dishes were okay. They don't offer as much as other Korean restaurants do. Overall, great location, great menu and great place to eat before hitting the clubs on a Saturday night.
author: Jennifer Z.

description:
Not bad but not great (compared to those in LA Ktown). Underwhelming for the 4 stars and 400+ reviews on Yelp.

Spam and sausage stew was flavorful and spicy. Portion is good enough for 2/3 people. There were also ramen with a slice of cheese on top, dukbokki, and just many other things in this stew. 

Calamari was cripsy but portion was too small.

Yogurt soju was alright ($25 for large size). The flavor was rather bland. Can definitely use more soju mixed with a sweeter yogurt drink.

Dark and spacious. We had to wait a bit (15mins) on a Friday night. You can watch the kpop music videos projected on the wall - some of them are so weird..
author: Vanessa N.

description:
Amazing food and nice looking staffs :P
   I like the beef and steam eggs, and soup I'll come again
author: Evan Z.

description:
707 was one of the restaurants open on Christmas Day and my partner and I went here since the wait at Sears fine food was taking too long and we were starving. Upon arrival, the place was not crowded at all, 3 tables were occupied and there were two servers. We promptly got seated and our order was taken immediately after putting our menus down. We received a very fast service, but I do wonder how it would be affected if the place was a little bit busier.

 I ordered the beef bi bim bop and my partner got the spicy pork bi bim bop on stone bowl which meant he got crispy rice. I really liked my order, I thought it was tasty but my partner thought that his was just okay, nothing special and that he wouldn't come back for it. 

We also ordered beef tofu soup and chicken skewers. It was ok, but we both definitely had better. 

Over all, the food were all okay but it wasn't anything special. This place gets a four for the decent food, decent price and fast service.
author: Arianne D.

description:
I can't remember the last time I loved every single dish ordered at a restaurant. Everything was on point. Here's what my group of 6 ordered (we did family style):

APPETIZERS: 
Seafood pancake: (5/5) Just the right level of crispiness. Basically like a seafood pizza for those who've never had it before. Sliced into 6 pieces I think. Perfect for sharing. 

Garlic soy chicken wings: (5/5) I think this was our group's favorite. Comes with 11 pieces so I forfeited my second piece. :'( Chicken was marinated very well and the flavor really gets into the meat, unlike other places where the flavor seems to be only on the skin that peels off the meat too easily. 

Rice cake in cream sauce: (4/5) It was not at all what I expected, in fact it tasted italian and I loved it. Although it has a spicy symbol next to it, it wasn't spicy. 

MAINS: 
Kimchi fried rice: (5/5) I got to this dish last and my friends had already devoured most of it. It was damn good and I love the fried egg on top .. though I didn't get to taste it...

Spicy pork: (5/5) I don't eat spicy things (weak I know) but I thoroughly enjoyed this dish. Ate several pieces and dealt with the spicyness. This was probably the spiciest thing we ordered (because the others just weren't spicy at all.) I guess if you really want spicy here, you gotta ask for it. 

Japchae with beef/veggies: (4/5) The consistency of the noodles was nice and chewy, and the noodles were flavorful. Only complaint is that there wasn't enough meat / veggies. 

PRICING: 
A little overpriced. It cost $17 a person after tip/tax which is more than I like to pay for an average no-occasion dinner. But I would still say it's worth it! 

ATMOSPHERE:
Nice, clean, dimly lit restaurant with kpop videos projected onto the wall. Even though I never watch kpop videos, somehow my eyes always ended up on that wall.
author: Amanda C.

description:
Great experience at 707 Sutter! Went on 11/4/2015 with 2 people at about 11:45am for lunch. Appears to not have a wait during weekday lunches. Ordered the lunch size of Beef Bibimbab with beef on stone and bu dae jji gae. The bibimbab was delicious; the rice used in this dish is smaller grained than the rice that I normally eat, which added more texture to this dish. The bibimbab tasted great! The bu dae jji gae was so delicious. It was a little salty as expected since there was both spam and hot dog, but I loved it! The "broth" was so thick, spicy, sweet and had a strong kimchi and beef flavor! I would buy this "broth" and eat it was everything all day if I could.

Beware: if you have a short lunch break, I suggest getting bibimbab in a bowl instead of stone because it was just too hot to eat. If you order the du dae jji gae, ask for a small bowl to cool the stew since it was too hot to eat straight out of the stone bowl.

Overall, I loved the two dishes we ordered and the yummy side dishes. We both had leftovers to bring home since we couldn't eat all the hot rice and hot stew.
author: Jennifer H.

description: Not bad for "authentic" Korean food. The bulgogi was definitely good and they give a decent amount of side dishes but it wasn't my favorite. Reminded me of a "fusion" place rather than authentic.
author: Jenny J.

description:
7 oh 7 Sutter - Korean food!

With the spicy, hot tofu soup, noodles, juicy, meaty entrees, Soju and large screen TV, I would claim this place to be the Korean hot spot in central, downtown SF!

They offer plenty of delectable Korean dishes to choose from and a good amount of different Soju flavors to order up!

It's a plus that they stay open late too!  Great place to hit up to grab late night munchies and to drink the night away!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Huh, well, I've obviously forgotten to review 707 because I've been rather drunk almost every time I've come here. Alcohol has a way of making one's memory a little fuzzy and all.

ANYWAY, having been here a number of times already, and having tried a variety of things, including their budae jigae, jap chae, and kimchi fried rice, I'll say that, while it's not GREAT Korean food, it's pretty solid, especially for anything on this side of the city.

The waitstaff is pretty friendly, and I've yet to see the place packed, which is especially nice when you're drunk and starving. As others have mentioned, one of the walls is used as a giant screen for a steady stream of K-pop videos, so love or hate it as you will. I personally find it to be a reliable source of amusement throughout my meals here.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - A large, spacious restaurant with plenty of accessible seating and room for putting about.

Bathroom - While they might not be the cleanest, especially depending on what time you're there, they're accessible.
author: Johnny W.

description: This place is okay.. price is a little steep. I wouldn't come back by choice but I wouldn't be mad if got me food from here.
author: Anny H.

description:
I had high hopes because of the Yelp ratings but I should have really known better, especially when it comes to Korean food in SF. 

The banchan was measly and they only gave us 4. WTF? 

We ordered:

kalbi - burnt.
the chicken wings - a-ok. we got half of them spicy and half not. i think they just use a mild gochujang 
steamed egg - didn't try but my friends said it was whatever.
kimchi jigae  - WAY TOO DAMN SALTY. We poured water into it to dissolve some of the salt but it didn't really help. This pretty much went untouched.
chicken gizzard skewers. I liked these but they were not evenly cooked.
creamy dokkbokki - the only good thing we had. loved the semi sweet/tangy creamy sauce it came in. 

All in all, if you're in the area I guess it's an okay place to stop, grab a drink or two and nosh on food. It's open late. But otherwise I wouldn't make it a destination.
author: Susy C.

description:
My go to for Korean comfort food in SF! I've ordered from Postmates and dined in numerous times and have been pleased with the quality and quantity!

Ambiance: basically 0 wait time. Pretty large space and I generally see people coming in with large parties. They play kpop music videos on the large blank wall throughout the night. This is  a great spot for a dinner with big groups!

Food: Definitely one of my fa
Side dishes: Not much variety with to go (usually just kimchi, and pickled veggies)  but dining in offers a pretty wide variety - kim chi, japchae, potato, bean sprouts, fish cake, and usually some kind of a green veggie)
Short Rib Stew: favorite on the menu hands down. Whenever I was feeling under the weather I'd order this for dinner. Even to go, they have a huge amount of soup and there's plenty of meat, noodle and usually some veggies. Light broth that feels healthy but also very flavorful!
Seafood Pancake: I find that it's too bready and not seafoody enough. Sauce is great but the pancake itself is quite bland
Kimchi fried rice: I generally won't order this on its own because it's super heavy but this paired with the bulgogi is A+ comfort food!!
BiBimBap: Can't really go wrong with this one. Especially in the stone pot it's a huge portion and very delicious.
Drinks: usually i get a soju or one of the rice wines to share with friends.  Got the hot sake once on a dreary day and it was smooth and hit the spot! Pretty low in alcohol content but delicious and light.
author: Taryn Q.

description:
When I saw the giant K-Pop video projected on the wall, I was thinking of turning around and walking out (photo: http://bit.ly/Zp1t4I). My thought bubble exclaimed, "I'm too old for this room. Go to Shalimar where you belong with the other daredevil geriatrics." But the young waitress ensnared me with an innocent "Table for one?" I hesitantly nodded as I scanned the restaurant and saw all the youngsters with their Korean barbecue and bottles of soju (photo: http://bit.ly/15IZuL8). Clearly this was not Brothers, but it wasn't HRD Smokin' Grill either. The hipster factor was cranked up but not the edginess you would expect from such a club-like ambiance.

It's more like the Tendernob version of the Castro's Kpop serving about the same level quality of Korean eats (review: http://bit.ly/10cAB2x) but with a bit more authentic menu like you would find at Dong Baek a few blocks away. I took advantage of the difference by ordering more than I should have, but first I received the regulation banchan. Only four little servings in a subdivided plate, rather paltry by Sahn Maru or even Brothers standards, but probably just as well (photo: http://bit.ly/15G1S5G). I then moved to my starter, the $8 Tofu Salad, which consisted of a rather hefty serving of soft tofu sliced into a dozen pieces and accompanied by a pile of mixed greens.

It was all drizzled with their house dressing which had a nice miso flavor to it, so it was relatively easy to devour too quickly as I did (photo: http://bit.ly/17W3Tdd). Good stuff but nothing that exceptional and probably a larger portion than what I bargained for when I ordered my main dish. I must have gone over the deep end when I asked for the $17 Jok Bal as the large platter serving was meant for a small band of skinny bar hoppers. But I didn't complain because I was hungry. It's described as "pork feet" but it's actually a pork shank that's been steamed, braised in a broth, completely deboned, and sliced thinly. As you can see, the bones make up the centerpiece of the dish (photo: http://bit.ly/YNMEEf).

Huge, huh? Yes, and give credit to the waitress who didn't raise an eyebrow when I ordered it without apology. I was only able to devour about a quarter of it before raising a white flag. I think the fact that it's a dish served like a salumi dampened my appetite a bit since lukewarm pork does not excite me no matter how tasty it was. And it was in a slightly gelatinous way that had me stuffing my mouth with alarming frequency. But I stopped. I slid the porky remains into a large take-out box and slithered out of the restaurant hoping none of the hipsters saw any of my gluttonous behavior. Good thing they were all bopping to the video. I didn't know Lady Gaga was Korean.

FOOD - 3 stars...good dishes, not great but good enough and plenty of it
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...ah, to be young again
SERVICE - 4 stars...quite attentive and not judgy
TOTAL - 3 stars...Korean goes K-Pop and the world goes 'round
author: Ed U.

description:
I first came here after asking a friend for Korean restaurant recommendations, and I'm really glad he suggested this place.

I love the food here! Stone bowl bibimbop is my fave - because if you're going to get bibimbop, you should get it with the stone bowl lol. The K-pop videos are projected onto the wall while the music plays, which is good background entertainment while you eat. 

The location is an easy walk from Union Square area. It's not that small of a place compared to other restaurants in the city, but it does get really busy here sometimes. The last couple times I went, I had to wait for a bit even though there was only 2 of us.
author: Bianca C.

description:
Really great place to have some cheese corn and potato croquettes! Some friends and I came here on a whim to have some drinks and to share a family style meal. We ordered croquettes and cheese corn and although portions where small they were delicious! 

One fun feature about this place is that they have this huge wide screen for KPOP videos/chore to KPOP songs. When I was there they were playing 1MILLION dance studio videos which were super inspiring and kept the upbeat vibe of the entire place. 

Waiting was long but worth it (considering the fact that we had a large group that was about 10 people)
author: Faith C.

description:
This is my go-to place for Korean cuisines. Banchan is my all time favorite. I ordered 707 sutter salad with tofu every time I was there so you can tell it's very good. It's heavy and salty but the salad tofu is in good texture and healthy style. Bulgogi soup is not very recommended because it's too bland - without having the savory saturated in bulgogi thus tastes inconsistent. Japchae (stir-fried glass noodles with vegetables and meat) with bulgori is highly recommended, mild and tastes the-right-level-savory. The one with pork is unpleasantly spicy and few pieces of pork - caveat for those craving for some more meat.

Budae Jigae and seafood pancake are on my next list. Well, till next time.
author: Yixi F.

description:
I'm a fan.  I really wanted Korean food after an even last night that had open bar so I was pretty tipsy and hungry.  I really wanted bulgogi! What I did know is that I'm not really a big fan of Cocobang, so we came here.  Best decision of the night.

Being a Thursday around 10, it wasn't too busy and our party of 7 got seated right away.  First off, the bonchon is pretty good, presented in a nice long fancy tray.  A little light at first, but you can ask for more.  We got Bulgogi, Dukboki, Cheese Corn, and KimChee Pancake.  I like all of it.  The bulgogi was savory, a little sweet, and slighty crispy, just the way I like it.  The pancake itself was okay, but the ponzu sauce with it was really good!  On the spicy, which I love!  The dukboki was good as well, solid, again the sauce being the standout.  Now the cheese corn, normally I'm whatever about cheese corn.  But this one, this one right here...this one is good!  It was almost like Mac & Cheese because of its creamy, cheesy, garlicy goodness!!! YUM!!!

Place is spacious so you don't have to stand around in the a little doorway waiting on 5 tables.  Videos and music make it fun.  And staff is friendly and responsive.

We also had a large carafe of Yogurt Soju, that seemed to keep going!   With the food and drinks for what ended up being 5 people, it was $20 each with tip.  NOT BAD AT ALL!

ps.  A waitress walked by with the kimchee fried rice, and it looked really good that my jaw dropped a bit.  She noticed and laughed, but she knew that i knew that it was gonna be a good meal.  Must try next time.
author: Veasna H.

description:
Parking may be a challenge in this area so be prepare for circulating the blocks several time or to pay garage parking fees.

The restaurant is large enough to seat large groups up to 12 without crowding other tables. There's also a projection scene of korean music videos.

The food was just ok. I'd rather drive out to Toyose or Playground if I was craving korean bar food. We ordered:

Soon soo bu with beef - 3/5 it was spicy but the beef was very hard and chewy and the tofu's texture wasn't soft it was a little rough

Mandu soup- 3/5 generous portions of mandu but it was overly peppery filling

Half sauce/half fried chicken wings - 2/5 the chicken lacked spice. The spicy sauce was very sugary.

Bing soo- 3/5 the shaved snow comes with strawberry ice cream, red bean, kiwi and cocktail fruit mix. Nothing special. Wished they had vanilla ice cream.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
First me and my friends went to Coco bang however there was not enough seat. So they told another Korean reataurant if we go up  a bit and then turn left. So we got to come 707 Sutter.
 We wanted 15 people seat however they told it is impossible because it is friday night so there is no enough seat. For the first time they told they can make seat seperately to 10 and 5. But one of the man told that for friday night more customer will come so it will be not affordable. At that time I thought... we came first, so shouldn't they consider customer who came first ? They showed stern attitude so I felt not that good. 
Anyway we decided take out the food. While we ordering seperately, the girl was really nice. Also when we were waiting outside from the restaurant , the boy who served the food was really kind. So we felt better.
And the foods were quite nice! 
Although for the first time I felt not that happy about the man who told a bit stern, later the workers were so kind and cool So it was good.
Smile smile
author: Kim Y.

description: My go to for the San Francisco General Staff Graveyards!  My coworkers and I are grateful for the hours of your operation.  We get every and all types of dishes that pleases our appetites.
author: A P.

description:
Was looking for some late night eats around the Chinatown area and wounded up around the hostel I was staying at. The food was okay - definitely had better in NYC and LA. The soy garlic was good and crispy, but the spicy was way too saucey for me. The fried calamari came out cold and unappetizing..
so my meal ended there. 

Seems like all the waitresses here do their laundry the same day because they all reeked of detergent (not a bad thing) so another +1 star for that.
author: Dan T.

description:
I came here with a friend on a Friday night, 11pm.  There were a lot of people but we were able to find open seating without problem.  The venue is a bit loud with the TV running in the background, so keep that in mind if you're aiming for an intimate date. 

We ordered the Korean pancakes and beef short ribs. They were okay and definitely enough for 2 of us.  SF is not as good as other places for Korean food (like LA), but this was acceptable and had the convenience of being open until 2am.
author: Nick A.

description:
Service was horrible. Nobody greeted or helped. They seemed careless. Took 15 minutes for order drinks. Not to mention, we had to flag them down every single time. 
Food? Nah, I warn you. Please avoid this place.
author: Iris C.

description: A-Ok, for Korean BBQ in SF, The boys and I wanted some Korean BBQ and normally we would stop by Cocobang but we wanted to try something new. As we entered 707, the hostess welcome us and the atmosphere was pretty modern with K-Pop Videos playing on the wall. Pretty Hip Place- A. The wait time wasn't too bad. The little tapas came out and the portions were pretty small and the BBQ Bol Go Gi, wasn't hot enough, although, it came out a hot plate. The Chewy noodles were good and the Fried Chicken Mix weren't as we expected. Overall, the quality of the food could of been better.
author: Teresa C.

description:
My friend, Kendra, and I stumbled into 707 Sutter for lunch on the first San Francisco rainy day in February. This Korean restaurant is extremely spacious and was very quiet, which gave us an opportunity to catch up.

Although the restaurant is huge, there was only one waitress serving the whole restaurant. Having only one person in the front during this time was sufficient since the restaurant was pretty slow, but I do hope she has more help when the restaurant gets busy! A full house in this restaurant would be extremely difficult for her to service every single table during peak hours.

Kendra and I shared a corn cheese. It was literally just corn with mozzarella, and super delicious. I guess how could one go wrong with mozzarella and corn? :) I would recommend getting this appetizer when you come.

I was debating between japchae and dolsot bibimbap. I really love eating jap chae, but since it was cold and rainy out, I decided to get something on the hotter side. The tofu dol sot bibimbap is a hot stone with tofu, egg, and mixed vegetables. There was nothing special about the dish. It wasn't bad, but I've had much tastier dolsot bibimbaps before. Not the best, not the worst, but average.
author: Jade F.

description:
It was definitely a spot worth trying, but I'm not sure if I would be returning the next time I'm in the city. I'm someone who likes to try out new restaurants, and if the restaurant had anything in particular that appealed to me, I will return.

My friend and I were strolling around 1/4th of the city, walking up and down, hiking here and there. After a while we really wanted to settle to a spot and just sit and rest, eat some good food. We came to the suggestion of having Korean food, since we were craving the tofu soup. We walked 30 minutes to this restaurant from where we were at that moment, and walked into a store that had not a single customer. Alarmed, we began to step back out since we thought it was one of those restaurant that has break hours. To my surprise, someone stepped up and greeted us.

To cut it short here were the food we ordered:

1) Beef Tofu Stew: I thought the appearance was really appetizing, the steaming heat really appealed to me. I thought the waitress was going to crack the egg for me, like other restaurants, but that wasn't offered. I guess that just might not have been a routine done everywhere? The taste of the tofu soup was honestly quite average. There were large chunks of onions, which I was not quite used to. And the beef was honestly almost no where to be seen. I came by a few small bits, but it just didn't fit the title of a Beef Tofu Stew... without much beef? 

2) Kimchi Glass Noodles: My friend ordered this plate and to our surprise, it was pretty spicy. It did have a chilli pepper next to it's sign on the menu, but we just didn't expect the spice to be that overwhelming. I definitely think this plate was well seasoned, the flavoring was good. I personally enjoyed the spice. But for other people who may just see this as a mild, I would consider this as a medium spice level.

As for the side dishes that were provided with our meal, very basic. Simple. I've definitely had more side dishes at different restaurants, but I understand that each have their own preference, so I respect that. The taste of each item has potential, just the day I went, it didn't feel too special. 

Overall pretty alright!
author: Jenny Z.

description:
Came here with my girlfriends the other night and I really wanted to like this place. 
But....the service was soooo slow, the music was too loud. I really don't want to sound like a grandma but the food was too salty too. 


+1 star for good Korean flavor
+1 star for funky videos on the wall
+1 star for giving us more kim chi when we asked. 2 out of the 5 of us have a kim chi addiction. 

Get the seafood pancake, cheese corn ( I know. it sounds gross but it was good. I had to swallow my yuck face and admit that it was delicious after my friend ordered it.) 
The glass noodles were also yummy as was the fried rice egg thing.

 TURN DOWN THE MUSIC.. please. :)
author: Suzzie B.

description: I was a little hesistant after reading the reviews but this place was great. The food was delicious, the staff was attentive and friendly and best of all, it was actually affordable for Korean food. I'll be back!
author: Bimbo B.

description: Pretty good at a great price. The shrimp on the skewers are tiny, so they lost a star for that. Shrimp skewers better have good shrimp. Otherwise, it's consistent.
author: Jm C.

description:
Came here one weekend for some comfort food. It was a really cold evening and was craving some Bu dae jji gae (assorted spam, sausage, stew mixed with meat, ramen and kim chi). It's a melting pot of carbos, veggies, meat and spice. 

The music videos that are playing are on the louder side. If you're looking to converse over dinner it maybe a little noisy. The staff is pretty helpful and attentive. If I'm in the area I will stop in again. Not a place that I would go out of my way.
author: Kristina S.

description: This restaurant is really awesome. I like the korean food and music. If you come this place you can enjoy both together. You should visit this place and you gonna love it.
author: Eunchong L.

description:
Late night craving for some Korean comfort food and don't want to leave downtown? Don't hesitate and head over to 707 Sutter. This isn't an ideal date spot (way to loud), but probably one of the best places you can go to if you're looking to host a small to large group of people with food and drinks.

The quick and dirty:
- Korean comfort food, nothing fancy, but hits the spot
- They serve soju and giant beers (you should do them both, at the same time)
- Giant screen displaying the latest kpop videos

Food:
My favorite dish at 707 is the Budae Jjigae (), which is a large spicy bowl of soup w/ ramen noodles, sausage, spam, hamburger meat, and a variety of vegetables. It's pretty big, so you want to go with a group (serves about 4 for a bowl of soup).

Another must have is the Cheese Corn. If you haven't tried it yet you're missing out. Brown sugar, cheese, all melted over corn served on a sizzling platter. It's a crowd-pleaser.

Ambiance:
The staff, food, and music give off the vibe of a busy Seoul street cafe, but the restaurant's facade feels more like a office space converted into a dining area. Don't worry, you'll quickly forget about the tile floors and honeycomb ceiling once you're 3 rounds in. The place has open seating, which is pretty much first come first serve (fill out a white board wait list). They have groups of small black tables that can be joined together to form seating for larger parties. I typically go on Fridays, which are packed if you show up late. Expect waiting at least 30 minutes if you have a large group. It's not uncommon for the floor to erupt into boisterous laughs and clanking of glasses as parties toast the night away. In the background is kpop music blazing through small speakers and a giant projection of music videos on the side wall.

Service:
The wait staff is super friendly and as attentive as they can be considering the number of tables they are waiting on, however, you might find yourself wandering up to the front desk to order a few rounds of drinks from time to time. 

Pro tip(s): as soon as you get seated, figure out what the group wants to eat, and have one person order for the entire table (including drinks). Rely on the same person to place the subsequent drink orders. I find food/drinks come out much faster if the server only has to deal with one person. Set your group up with 2 or 3 rounds of drinks in advance so you give the staff plenty of time to catch up.  This is a family style dining restaurant, I highly recommend ordering several different dishes for the table, instead of everyone having their own dish, the portions are large and are more suited to be shared.
author: Jasper S.
