description: The dokbokee was one of the best, including those from the motherland. The staff are very friendly and quick in service. As with most Korean places, the beer selection isn't great, but they do have options other than the traditional Hite, Cass and OB. Initially, the fried chicken didn't seem so great but having tried competitors in the area, it now is something that causes cravings and mouths to water.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
Not too bad a Korean place. A little on the pricey side but considering that San Francisco really doesn't have many Korean places to start with and this is pretty authentic (as in, run by a bunch of Koreans), I'll give it four stars.

They have a giant k pop music wall, you will be blasted with k pop music which is either 5 girls that look identical dancing or 5 guys that look identical dancing. Occasionally there will be a love song which is a guy being very emo singing and the camera showing him wearing a sweater sitting in various places....but I digress.

We ordered tofu bimbimbap, kimchi tofu soup, stir fry squid, and bulgogi. The tofu soup and squid are both pretty spicy --there is no American spicy level here, just one level of spicy, so if you are used to wimpy spicy food levels, don't order spicy food here (clearly marked on menu). The bimbimbap was nice as in, very healthy which is what I wanted. But the stone pot was very hot and I wasn't warned and ended up getting a burn mark on my arm -_- they also didn't give me the typical red sauce that usually goes with bimbimbap. The bulgogi was soft and juicy and very nicely done. 

Everything on the menu is about $12-15 so it is on the higher end (I'm thinking compared to Manna in inner sunset). They provide high chairs and has enough spacing for ppl to sneak strollers in. Overall the place is clean, staff is responsive and friendly, but the place can be loud with pop music and dimly lit.
author: Elizabeth T.

description: Came here to eat with a friend for dinner and we live around the neighborhood. I usually go to Geary St. in San Francisco for Korean food but I think I found another great place now. Here they have a lower price than any other Korean restaurants in the City that I've been too. Two entrees for $23 after tax! We had a dumpling soup (this is not the same tofu dumpling soup in a stone pot) and shrimp fried rice wrapped like an omelette. We liked our dishes!
author: lydia m.

description:
We ordered the seafood pancake, spicy chicken wings, seafood hotpot, ramen dukbokki, and galbi.

I highly recommend getting the spicy chicken wings--they were bomb diggity.

Reasons for 3 stars--
We got the seafood hotpot to share. The flavors were not very authentic or well-seasoned. Instead it tasted as if everything was drenched in salt. The soup also wasn't spicy enough or very versatile.
Another reason is that It's pretty pricy for the kind of food they serve. I have definitely had better, more homey Korean food for a cheaper price.
None of the other orders were anything out of the ordinary--as such, they shouldn't be so pricy.
author: Claire G.

description:
Had a fun time here the past couple times I've been. Food here is solid. Tried the short rib soup and soft tofu soup really hearty and delicious. Soups are great to sober you up after a night of drinking!
Service here is fantastic with plenty of handsome waiters :)
I shall make visits a plenty.
author: Tashi C.

description:
My husband's dream come true. 

1. $5 Appletinis, peachitini, and the other fruity tinies.
2. The Liter sized Hite and OB for $14
3. Wall sized broadcast of kpop videos.

The food portions are generous (like most korean places).  A $40 meal for two is plenty of food and drinks.
author: Virginia L.

description:
707 Sutter was just a few blocks away from the hostel we were staying at and I had major Korean food cravings -- it was a no-brainer that we ended up there for dinner one night.

I got a tonkatsu which was good but nothing out of this world and my friend got spicy octopus stir fry, which was AWESOME. I almost regretted not getting that instead, it was really really good.

Kpop videos are projected over one wall, the decoration is basically non-existent but service was quick and nice and the food was good! All you could ever ask for at Korean restaurant, in my opinion.
author: Eline M.

description:
Wow this place was a huge let down.

Their portions are very small for how much they charge. You know how when you order galbi it usually comes in a stacked pile on a sizzling plate? Here it's just a thin layer of meat that barely fills up the plate, and the meat looked and tasted like it's been sitting in the kitchen for a while. It was the saddest thing I have seen for something that's $24. I seriously thought that they had mixed up our order when it was served. 
I won't get started on the other dishes... 

We ended up ordering wings from Milan two blocks away after dinner.
author: James A.

description:
I usually get takeout from this restaurant and the food is mega dank. Because I'm such a big fan of the food, I began to dine in at the restaurant. But after my third visit here, I will never be a patron here ever again. I came with a group of 6 coworkers when the restaurant was empty minus one or two tables. There was plenty of staff behind the counter, not really greeting us (the only ones waiting at the time). Since it was pretty slow, we sat ourselves at a 6 person table, thinking it was a reasonable optimization that would save everyone some time. Then, one waiter, visibly irate approached us and passive aggressively inquired, "So, do you guys usually go to restaurants and seat yourselves?" Confused, my party played along. However, the clown kept up his sarcasm and the situation clearly went downhill. Finally, one of us asked whether we should leave, and he insisted. I'll never be back, and I will actively deter anyone from eating at their restaurant.

tl;dr steer clear of the waiter who has a vein popping out of his forehead.
author: Arthur C.

description:
So far, the best Korean food I've had in the bae area.

I'm very critical when it comes to Korean food, especially because I'm Korean and I come from southern California where they have the best Korean food.

Seafood pancake - 5/5
Yuk-kae-jang? - 3.5/5
Soon-doo-boo - 3.5/5 (doesn't come with rice; ask for it)
Stirfry squid - 5/5 (get it extra spicy)
Corn cheese - 4/5 (pretty basic but pretty good)
Spicy pork - 4/5 (could be spicier)

Not the best, but it did satisfy my cravings.

Will come back.
author: Jeff H.

description:
Great korean food (for SF). Seafood pancake, japchae, soft tofu, ribs, and etc. Ra bok ki looked amazing but we didn't order it and I will definitely be back to get that. The fried chicken was okay but nothing like bonchon which I really really wish they had. Blue moon was $15 a pitcher.

The line isn't too bad but the place isn't big so if you can make RSVP ahead of that that would be great.
author: Lily P.

description: Strongly recommended their Budae Jigae! The best one I ever had in San Francisco, speaking as a Korean food fanatic!
author: Sharon L.

description: Very poor service. Sat waiting for forever and no one came to take our order, finally got up and left
author: Courtney K.

description:
One of a few places that has ddukbokki with chol myun, chewy noodle. It's much better with this noodle than the instant ramen versions everyone else has. 

Now you know.
author: Derrick V.

description: Fun place - food was good - like the big screen. Service was a little lackluster and no free barley tea, but flavors were on!
author: Andrew K.

description: A friend highly recommended the restaurant. The environment is nice and the waiters are so kind. We ordered cheese corn and bi bim bop with seafood. In addition, they offered us some pickles(not as good as cheese corn and bi bim bop) for free. Really delicious and authentic Korean food.
author: Nancy S.

description:
Very mediocre food but I mean...if you're drunk (or trying to get drunk) and really looking for Korean food around the Union Square area, this could be a place to go to. But if you're looking for quality Korean food, I suggest looking elsewhere. 

They offer a standard menu of typical Korean bar food (e.g. Rice cakes, fried chicken, pancakes etc) but it's just so meh. The chicken is ok and the pancakes are doughy. I guess it's a fun atmosphere, with Korean music videos played on a huge projector but I would head over to Oakland for better Korean bars as they offer much better food for the same price.
author: Michelle Y.

description:
After a day of jamming out at Hardly Strictly, this place hit the spot.  Came in at ~8:30 PM on a  Saturday night with a party of 4 and the place was packed.  The staff turned tables over very quickly and we were seated within 10 minutes of stepping in.  Impressive considering there was a line of people in front of us.   The service during dinner was fantastic as well.  

The atmosphere was fun and lively, with some of KPOP's best music videos playing on the wall.  

Everything we ordered was amazing! Japchae, kimchi fried rice, bulgogi, spicy chicken wings, dumplings and of course some Soju and Hite.  I would definitely recommend this place if delicious noms is your thing!
author: Alice W.

description:
I was skeptical because my standards are so high for Korean food, (the best is really in L.A.).  But I sampled it on my lunch break on a weekday to-go, being totally aware of the higher prices.

Below is lunch, (just for me & yes I finished everything except for 4 fried chicken legs):

Bulgogi:  This was the one I was totally expecting to bomb but it was actually quite excellent.  It was tender & not dry and had good flavor, you can really taste the garlic & onions.  It comes with 1 serving of white rice which is good because it was like $15 bucks or something.  But you have to eat it right away, it doesn't keep well.

Kim-chi Pancakes:  This has to be the easiest thing to make, so it always amazes me when restaurants mess it up.  It was very yummy to me.  It's a matter of personal taste but I like my Korean pancakes a little doughy-mushy, just like Mom makes them.  

Fried Chicken with Spicy sauce:  This was alright, but nothing I'd order again.  It had a kick but was kinda dry.  Also a matter of personal taste, I like my KFC-Korean Fried Chicken, with a gooey, sticky, sweet, spicy glossy glaze.  Kuk-Jae Korean market in Daly City has the best I've ever had, ready made to eat in a package.

I'm looking forward to sampling more things there, definitely worth at least checking out.
author: Johnnie N.

description:
707 is a great place and I love their food, accessibility, and the fact that they are open late for those nights you just want some hot noodle soup after drinking, BUT everyone  should be aware of their billing (I wasn't before!)

There is 18% gratuity ALREADY tacked onto your bill before you even give them your card. Regardless of how many people you're there with, it's reliably there, and they swipe your card with the option to tip more. Now, I wouldn't have minded this as much if there had been a fair warning that the 18% gratuity was already included, but when you give them your card, they also have a convenient habit of not returning you the itemized receipt, so it looks like there was never tip included to begin with.

I'm all for tipping generously for great service, but I'm also not pleased when I'm scammed out of extra tip unknowingly, so ask for your itemized receipt and make sure you're aware of what's going on!

Tipping weirdness aside, the food is great--I always come here for the budae jigae (army stew with sausage, spam, and ramen noodles). The soondooboo (tofu soup) isn't bad but it could use a bit more flavor (flavor, not spiciness). The seafood pancake is delicious, as is the bulgogi. Bulgogi stew was great the one time I tried it, and I will definitely be back! All their flavored sojus are also delicious. This place is a tad expensive for being one of those late-night drunchie places but it's versatility makes it a good spot for either that or a casual meal.

They take reservations which you should definitely utilize because it gets packed during peak dinner time and late night hours (i.e. anytime after 11pm).
author: Chrystal Z.

description:
After a long day out of town, my friend and I decided to go for Korean food. This restaurant is one of the first Korean restaurants that I had ever gone to besides Korean BBQs. When we arrived, the restaurant had dim lighting and soft music playing in the back ground. The waitress greeted us accordingly and we got to choose our seats. 

FOOD
First off, 707 Sutter's menu is GREAT. I am a picture type of person (which is why I look on yelp before ordering at many restaurants that I have never been to before). My friend and I ordered tteokbokki with ramen noodles and kimchi fried rice. After we ordered, the waitress brought over a long plate of mini individual samplers of kimchi, veges, noodles, and fried tofu (I believed).  When our meal arrived, we dove in. I honestly loved the dishes that we ordered. It was yummy!!

PRICE
$25 tip, included. 


OVERALL
I really enjoyed my first dining experience at 707 Sutter. We will definitely go back soon.
author: Cleo C.

description:
Just came here with a group of guys from work. It's great for groups with family style dining. I really enjoyed the spicy tofu soup. The kimchi fried rice was decent, and the mackerel was crispy and fatty.

Of course it wouldn't be a meal without Hite and soju :-D. Would definitely go again though probably only with a large group.
author: Nader A.

description:
3.5 but round to 4 because 707 brought Miss A into my life: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EkSOOiMDGiY

Living in Miami, finding good Asian fare can be challenging. So, when I'm in a city like SF I want to take advantage of the spoils of Asian food bounty. I hadn't had Korean food in a while, so it was on my mind. I convinced a skeptical friend to come with (it's not really fair; she has her pick of awesome Asian eats on the regular; I was operating on a deficit) and we were on our way. We arrived to an empty restaurant and the side-eye came out in full. As I attempted to slide under the table, our incredibly nice server came by to take our orders. Whew! This woman was so genuinely nice that you just wanted to smile back at her and radiate in the kindness. This, too, is lacking from general experiences in Miami, so I drank it up.

Caught up in her warm smile, we started the meal off with a pitcher of strawberry soju. Yeah, not the best of ideas. I've been drinking since the age of [redacted]. I've been drinking overly sugary beverages since much earlier than that. Strawberry soju should have not been an issue at all for me. It.was.rough. After downing the pitcher (what? It was paid for and at $25 I got what I paid for), I almost immediately got a headache. Oy. Empty restaurant. Bad. Nice waitress. Good. Strawberry booze. Bad. Very bad.

Hoping that the booze wasn't a sign to come, we started in our our huge order of grub. BiBimBap with plenty of rice, spicy pork and banchan was a mixed bag. The bibimbap and pork were very good. The rice was cooked well and there was a lot of it. The banchan was... eh. No one orders food for banchan; I get that. But when the banchan offerings don't match up to the entree, it's a bit of a letdown. A bit. My dining partner was bit more over the moon for the mackerel than I was. It was good but not great. What *was* great, however, was the kim chee pancake. Texture, flavor and quantity, it satisfied on all levels.

As you've read, the food was a mixed bag and the drink almost knocked me out for the night so... 4 stars? Yes. Why? K-Pop. It had been out of my life for much much too long and it's such a wonderfully guilty pleasure. Horrible videos. Love interests that make no sense. Outfits out of Lady Gaga's nightmares. Hoodrats (I love the 'rats). And catchy catchy tunes that despite all the aforementioned horror will keep your eyes glued to the screen, wiggling in your seat and declaring to no one and everyone that you don't need a man, you don't need a man (what?!). 

Who's not a fan of that?
author: Johnny T.

description: Came here for a birthday dinner the other night, and with all the food and drinks we got, it still only came out to $20 a person! Surprising for this kind of place, where it usually costs an arm and a leg and you're still hungry afterwards. Food I tried were: cheese corn (YES), spicy rice cakes, kim chi pancake, kim chi fried rice, and potato croquettes. Everything was really good and, of course, went perfectly with the beer and soju. Our table also ordered chicken wings, which I didn't try, but looked really yummy as well. You also get a small selection of banchan (typical stuff, including kimchi, japchae, cucumber, and bean sprouts). They have a giant projection of Korean music videos too, so it was fun to watch that during any lulls in conversation.
author: Kathy L.

description:
TLDR: Chicken Katsu is really good! Ramen w/ dukbokki okay. Flavored Soju was really weak, and tasted bland... service not great.

The first thing you notice when coming in is that there is a large screen with Korean music videos playing. So it's pretty sweet if you're into that! I generally enjoy going to Korean places like this for strong mixed sojus and good food. First off the sojus were really weak and tasted like water. Not sure if we just got unlucky. I also ordered the ramen dukbokki which is pretty good. The chicken katsu was very good though. I'd eat that again if I went there.

In terms of service, I just feel like there are normally 2-3 people circling this place, but majority of the time that they are out on the floor they are serve food and then immediately go back to the kitchen. Its a little less common that there were servers who were just out on the floor to just assist customers. We always felt we'd have to yell/ stare at them to get their attention. At time it felt that we stared at them so long that we could see their souls. We learned the history of their lives, their likes, their dislikes, their quirks, what makes them and their souls just so beautiful, and sometimes...even what sort of pets they might have. And then close to the point of epiphany and strong spiritual connection with them...they'd finally turn around or one of us would just get up to get their attention.

Not sure if this is a result of just short staffing, or just short staffing the two times I came here, but it makes eating here not the most efficient experience.

If you're in the tenderloin and just suddenly want Korean food, this place will still hit the spot.
author: Derrick C.

description:
Really disappointing visit and I LOVE KOREAN FOOD. It's pretty hard to disappoint me...

The short ribs were burnt. 28 dollars and burnt to a crisp. Could barely eat it which was such a waste of money

The pan chan wasn't very good and the kim Chee was not tasty at all. 

Sigh so disappointing.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
Just moved into the area - I grew up on a lot of this food so was real happy to find a decent Korean place next door. From what I've tried, the food here was on par with if not better than many places in the Berkeley Korean food scene. 

We came in at around 8 or 9pm at night and there was no wait for 2. 

My friend and I ordered the soondubu jjigae (soft tofu soup) and bulgogi (beef) plate. Great portions, was barely able to finish. Both dishes were delicious and came out relatively fast. Service was nice and responsive. The atmosphere is lively and modern (with k-pop music videos projected onto the wall), perfect for bringing a group of 4-5 friends in to grab dinner. 

Only thing I missed was the patbingsu (shaved ice with red bean and other toppings). The waitress said they were out of the red beans. 

Look forward to coming here again - going to try the kimchi fried rice next time!
author: Heather A.

description: Great place for dinner. Huge projector screen playing K-Pop videos all night. Fried chicken was delicious. Fish cake soup was good and served on top of a stove to keep it warm. Will be back with more friends to try more selections from the menu. My kids loved it coz of the big screen and great music.
author: Jenny L.

description:
"Good food, good times!" so says my friend. So did I have a "good time" at 707 sutter? Heck yea. 
-Clean
-Good food
-Good service
-Kpop projector!

I came here around dinner time, it was fairly busy with only two waiters. Despite the lack of workers service was still good. Our water pitcher was always full and our orders were taken shortly after being seated. Once our orders were taken we were given some yummy banchan which was pretty good and very nicely served in a modern setting. I ordered kimchi jjigae while the others in my party ordered japchae, bulgogi, galbi, mondoo, and bibimbap. With a nice variety of food we enjoyed all the food. 

Besides the food and service, we were highly occupied with videos being projected on the wall. Parking looked pretty harsh though. Over pretty good.
author: Mahina M.

description: This place is very entertaining. They have a huge screen that shows korean boy/girl bands performing. Their food ia perfect with soju. I love their kimchi fried rice and version of shrimp tempura. Great place to eat and have a few drinks. Better arrive early on fridays though as the place can get pretty packed.
author: Rachel P.

description: The fired chicken is so good! We love this restaurant. I agree that the seafood is hard to find in the bowl. However I'll still come back for fried chicken.
author: Vanessa Z.

description:
Of all my SF reviews, I don't think I've recommended a single korean restaurant (Because there haven't been any TO recommend)...until now. 

My friend said that she was in the mood for korean soup, so we came here. Little did I know, it was like her third time here this week. She is ADDICTED!!! 

We came in on a Thursday night and were seated immediately. The place was relatively full, which is a good sign.  We started with the complementary tray of 5 banchans (I was not impressed).  Since my friend was now "a regular", I let her take over on the ordering.   We shared the seafood pancake (ok this was AMAZING). It was under the "Small plates" section, but it's huge and filling.  We then split a bowl of soup with roe and tofu (lots of flavor, kind of spicy).  The food did take awhile to come out, but in the meantime I admit that we watched the k-pop videos on the wall :)

All in all, this was a filling meal for $16 each including tax and tip. I can't wait to come back and try other things on the menu.
author: Janet Z.

description: Very disappointing. I have a lot of friends, myself included, that loved this place over a year ago. Having been here so many times the quality just dropped. Corn cheese, which I did not know could be gross, was gross. It certainly looked and tasted like creamed corn -- watery and crying in its own sadness. Yogurt soju, a drink that could not possibly be nasty, was, you guessed it, nasty. Super watered down and they added 1/4 of liquid yuck into it. Noodles and such were dry and overcooked. This was just sad. How could you mess this up so bad 707?!
author: Sandy T.

description:
Strongly not recommend,we've waited here for 40+ minutes but still can't have the meal. ONLY 1 waiter in the restaurant when the hall have 8 tables 30 people are waiting for service or placing the order. My friend found there is ONLY 1 cook in the kitchen when we were waiting!

I don't know why there is no more waiter or cook in this restaurant, maybe they just want to make us starve enough to feel the "delicious" food.

Personally I don't think you will enjoy meal here.
author: Chris Q.

description:
It's so hard to find a place with good Kim Chi Fried Rice!

But my search is over!!! So full of flavor! The egg is so well cooked! And they make it so fast and fresh! YESSSS!!! YESSSSSSSSSSS!!!!!!!!!!!

I'm probably not gonna try any other foods unless I'm in a party (their giant soup pots are tasty) , when I'm by myself, I'm definitely gulping down some of that deliciousness of rice!
author: Alton D.

description:
Finally, good Korean that is actually near everything!

This place is so freakin' good! A girlfriend and I missed a bus back to Sac and had to wait until 1AM and really really wanted soup to combat the cold. This was the only place open late, thank goodness for Yelp app.

When we came it was pretty much empty, but a really nice space so I can only imagine the vibe when it's full. The menu looked good, prices were fair and they had all the Korean classics I'm used to. I got the spicy seafood soft tofu soup and my friend got a type of clear broth dumpling soup dish. 

While we were waiting, yummy banchan were brought out for us to munch on while watching K-pop videos projected on the wall. My soup came boiling hot and included an egg for me to crack myself, how fun! It was so delicious, and perfect to SF weather. My friend said her soup had so many dumplings! And the rice filled us both to the brim. We felt bad for not finishing the side dishes, but we were so full! 

The service was probably the best I've had in a Korean restaurant, utterly shocking! The entire time, super nice and helpful. I definitely recommend this place! Great location, good prices, delicious food, and friendly service. Every other Korean place I've tried in SF has lacked at least something, but now I have a go to joint!
author: Julia N.

description:
My first time here and it's definitely a great restaurant. 

We ordered : chicken wings, seafood soup, bbq beef, corn cheese, and lastly my boyfriend managed to squeeze the spicy rice noodle fish cake thing in (ehhhhh..). 

My brother who is not a fan of Korean food at all surprisingly had no complaints. He devoured the banchan and we even had to order him another rice! The corn cheese alone deserves its own star because I have YET to find a decent place that does corn cheese this good. I'm used to it being a sweeter cheesier texture but omg it is SO yummy still. I'm not talking about half assed corn cheese either, THIS IS LEGIT. My boyfriend was dying to try the entree with the thick spicy sauce with cut up rice noodles.. I believe it had fish cake. He loved it! If parking wasn't so much of a hassle I would probably be here more often. Arrive early and expect to be circling around for some time.
author: Michelle G.

description:
My friend and I really wanted to try Korean restaurants while we stayed in San Francisco, so we looked up 707 Sutter and decided to try it out. We ended up going late (around 9PM, which is late for me) and decided to walk there since it was only a 13 minute walk. Once we got there, we waited in line for 5 minutes and were seated immediately once we talked to the hostess. It was a bit dark in the restaurant and a little too loud. There was a group of friends sitting behind us who talked loudly and obnoxiously, but of course that has nothing to do with 707 Sutter. My friend and I ordered the beef bibimpop and both enjoyed it. 

If I want Korean food again in San Francisco, I would probably want to explore more restaurants before coming back.
author: Sheena V.

description:
Alright so as everyone in SF knows it is impossible to find a solid Korean joint within the city especially when you compare it to LA which is only an hour flight away. 707 is a recently new development in the bay area and I have already been here about 5 times. I can easily say that within the east side of the city this is probably the best place that is a Korean Pub style joint because of a few reasons. 

1) The wait is not bad compared to nearby places such as Cocobang
2) Better variety of Korean food with more selections
3) Better variety of types of Korean drinks 
4) Really spacious joint compared to some of the other tiny places around the area
5) Service is excellent and friendly.

Now I know some folks may disagree with the last bullet point but I have found the service to be impeccable. Through all the times I have shown up, we have ordered a variety of different food items and all have been OK with a solid 3 star rating. We have ordered everything from the cheese corn, a variety of jjigaes, japchae, galbi, etc. Everything was good but not mindblowing. Yes I agree the banchan is weak here but its free and not the main show so I feel people should take it easy on the banchan bashing. The reality is that the food is decent, the drinks are great, and it is perfect for large groups to come and relax for a casual night. Based on these alone, I would bump up the rating of 3 to make this joint a solid 4 stars.
author: Dan M.

description:
Nice little Korean restaurant with a wall playing KPop music. Main dishes were really good, side dishes though were not up to par. The soju pitchers was pretty much straight juice with little to no soju, tastes great though, but I would've liked some more soju in there.

Took a star off because the service was I would say not there. Maybe it's because we were a table in the corner, but we had 13 people, how do the waitresses not attend to us. Asked for more water in the pitcher, took the pitcher and never came back. 

Food good, drinks and service could be improved.
author: Raymond L.

description:
Great place for a group of people, share the soups they are huge. Foods good. Had the Spam noodles, spicy, comforting, and huge (meant to share). I havn't had it ever before and it was something I would get again but there are a lot of things on the menu I also want to come back and try first like the tofu soup, bbq spicy pork and the wings. 

The drinks are inexpensive  and thats a huge plus and makes it even better for group of people especially people on a budget and lets face it, who isnt in this town. I will say I was a little disappointed in the size of the beer pour. I ordered a pint and it was about three fingers from the top of the pint glass, not a full pint. The soju cocktails are yummy.
author: Kristan B.

description: Kind of on the border with this place. 3.5 stars. Staff was friendly. Food arrived at a nice pace. Ban chan had a good selection. Dinner however did not meet my expectation. For the price, the dishes were pretty small. Corn cheese was not very good. It was very buttery and the cheese was grainy. Bulgogi isn't as flavorful as other places. Jap chae was good, I liked the taste. Had Dok Boki for the first time and it was pretty good. If it wasn't spicy, I would have loved it more but that's the dish. Have had better Korean elsewhere though...
author: Benita M.

description:
Good late night place to eat and sober up after drinking... or get even more wasted with kiwi soju. 

You can't go wrong with kimchi spam fried rice or budae jjigae (korean army stew).
author: Xinxin W.

description:
Went there once for lunch. The place was empty so I was a bit concerned. Still ventured inside and ordered their combo box. 

All the food was actually pretty good. Wouldn't say the best Korean in town but in this part of town one of the best I tried. The lady who served was also super nice and attentive.
author: Nuno S.

description: We started off with some appetizers which were pretty standard in any Korean restaurant. For appetizers, we ordered the corn cheese and potato croquettes. The corn cheese was slightly too sweet for my preference, and potato croquettes were dense and under-seasoned. We also shared a kimchi fried rice with vegetables. The egg was cooked perfectly and the rice was flavorful with the kimchi. For my main course, I ordered the soft tofu soup with vegetables. The soup was rich and flavorful and the tofu was smooth and soft. Good balance of soup to vegetables as well and I enjoyed it. I ordered a bowl of white rice to go with my soup. I don't eat much spicy food, so be sure to ask if they can do a mild spicy level if you're like me. Overall not bad, but the music and ambience was a bit too loud for conversations.
author: Nicholas Y.

description: The korean food here is decent. I've definitely have had better but if you want korean bar food then come hurrr. Its pretty dim inside though so it kinda reminds you  of a club. Or a sad place. Me and my friends got the Budaejjigae, Seafood Pancake, and soondae bokkeum. The Budaejjiage was pretty good but soooo expensive...like $28. Jesus take the wheel. The pancake was fine and the soondae was alright but it was kind of sweet which was weird. Our bill was like $70 dollars so i kind of cried on the inside cause in socal this would be so much cheaper...
author: Jane K.

description:
This restaurant was a 2 minute walk from out hotel. We arrived at 6:30pm party of 6 with no reservations and they were able to seat us immediately as long as we were out by 8. They served us our food really quickly and we were out by 8. 

I think the k-pop music projected on the wall is a hit or miss for some people. It seemed to be the only light in that restaurant. My friends and I had to use flashlights on our phone to read the menu. We also couldn't really see what we were eating, but it was delicious nonetheless. 

I ate the stir fry "glass noodle"n( I call it long rice) because I figured I'd try something new and I was happy with my decision. It was a very large portion so I had leftovers. I definitely would come here again.
author: Amelia L.

description:
Came here around 1am after enjoying a tipsy night at Bill Graham watching The Weeknd/ Jhene Aiko/ Schoolboy Q.

Food was honestly "meh" especially for the price but the servers were really nice to us even though we came in 30 minutes until closing. 

We ordered:
- Japchae - pretty hard to mess up and probably our favorite of the night
- Soy garlic chicken wings - tasted plain and we weren't in love
- Seafood hot pot - Good selection of shrimp, squid, udon and spicy soup. Good to warm us up on the cold night!

The bill came out to be $58 for the three dishes for three people so it was a pretty pricey drunchie session. I'm not sure I would come back unless I was in the area and it was late again. 

I do appreciate the spacious setting, nice servers and cool music videos projected on the wall though!
author: Bonnie S.

description: Great location if you are looking for Korean food late in the evening in SF.  Food quality is very well managed, and great with soju/beer.  Servers were very attentive.  Some of my favorite items are the kimchi fried rice, soy garlic wings, and the creamy tteokbokki.
author: Andrew C.

description:
I really enjoyed this restaurant until I had a rude experience with a server here. After dining here with 5 friends we paid in cash but we didn't have exact change so we added an extra $20  and expected to get change back. We waited about 10 minutes to get our change and when they didn't return it we had to ask for it back. The waiter was visibly upset and quipped "You know this is San Francisco you should at least tip 15%".

Whoa, excuse me? First of all tipping is not a requirement and it is a kind gesture for good service. We had every intention of tipping and regardless of bad service I always leave a tip...
I have always received my change back after paying a bill and then left my tip after. 

Anyway...there's Cocobang and now Zzan right down the street so I will be going elsewhere from now on. Really disappointing but a server should never be so rude.
author: Sueann W.

description:
Traditional Korean food - Yes
Very busy - Yes. Waited for half an hour
Yummy food? - I had better
Worth the wait? - Not really
author: Nikki L.

description:
I love Cocobang and have been very loyal to it, but now I might have to stray.  707 Sutter is a huge space with a huge projection wall of Korean music videos and no wait.  And of course, there's delicious soju. 

They have budae jigae (ramen soup with spam, hot dogs, rice cakes, kimchi, and everything you can think of), one of my favorite Korean dishes as well as the best seafood pancake I've ever had here.  

Cocobang might be upset at having some competition across the street, but I'm a very happy gal :)
author: Jane N.

description:
Came here after partying all night at slide, awesome atmosphere!

kpop music videos on the big projector screen.

Banchan was certainly lacking in variety and flavor, but it feels just health to eat veggies.

Very sweet and syrupy japchae was ok, but definitely made up for me not haivng dinner before going out.  hypoglycemia resolved.

Good kimchee fried rice - the mariniated beef was sweet and the rice had a strong kimchee flavor

Seafood pancake has crispy juicy big shrimp which I appreciate.  not a lot of places would be so generous in number of shrimp in the pancake as well.

overall the food is just ALRIGHT (a little heavy in the corn syrup for the noodles though), but the very fact that it's a cool late night place to hang out makes it a 4 star.  my friend says that she loves the dumpling soup over here so i will have to come back next time after partying
author: Tina A.

description: This one is located at Tenderloin which is famous as a food area. Most of the staffs are Korean so it is surely a Korean restaurant. I would recommend to try their noodle because it is reminding me of True Korean noodle.
author: Tran M.

description: This place was great! I had never had korean food before but this place gave me a terrific experience. I don't remember everything we ordered but among the things we had were: dim sum soup and fish. The  rest you can see it on the picture. This a great place for dining out late, i left at 1am on Thursday night and there was people still there. The waitress is really nice too!
author: Janet S.

description: K-Pop and Korean Food is a good combination.  Went here on a weekday at 7ish and was able to get a table right away.  Place is pretty big for an Asian restaurant in the area.  Staying in Union Square so this was a close spot if you are craving Korean.  We ordered the squid stir fry, BBQ Galbi, and soy sauce garlic wings.  I would rank the dishes in that order.  Stir fry squid had the right amount of spice and squid.  The only downfall of this place I would say that the side dishes are lacking.  Make sure you order a large Hite beer for 2 it's a good value for $6 in downtown SF.
author: Darwin S.

description:
Pretty great Korean place in the tender nob. The usual Korean options are all here (if you want bulgogi, pork bone soup). I have a friend who's a vegetarian, and theres some options at 707 for him as well. 

The cheese(y) corn appetizer is delicious, the large soup with sausage + spam is also delicious. Alcohol wise, you can get 1.6L of beer for $13 (not bad), and the yogurt soju is pretty easy to drink. This place constantly plays k-pop music videos, so if you ever get bored of your friends there's something to zone out with :P. 

This place does get quite busy towards the later part of the evening (9 and onwards) so be prepared for a bit of a wait.
author: David C.

description:
Most legit Korean place East of Golden Gate Park! The decor isn't anything to brag about (looks like it really just was some other bar restaurant repurposed to being a Korean restaurant). They spice it up by projecting Korean music videos on the wall.

The food though is amazing. Selection is pretty comprehensive of all Korean food staples. I recommend the Soondubu jjigae
author: Victor W.

description: Just so so. The Soon Tofu is too spicy and they didn't ask me for the choice of mild or spicy. Bibimbap is just so so and the cod fish is too dry. I have tasted many Korean restaurants so far, this is at most an average level. And they are short stuffed: too busy with so few waiters/waitresses, you have to wait for long until you get served.
author: Angela J.

description:
Have never wrote a negative review on Yelp. But this place is just so bad. The pork tofu soup only has like literally 4 small pcs of meat. I had to pay additional $3 to change Beef to Pork? And the first time the tofu soup was served, there was no meat after I put the egg in there. They even thought about charging me for the egg when they re make the soup for me. What?! 
The taste wasnt even anywhere GOOD. Please do yourself a favor. Go to Tofu House on Geary Street and see what a Korean Tofu Soup is.
author: Josephine L.

description: Staying downtown San Francisco and wanted to find good Korean fare nearby. Solid reviews and convenient location led me here. Décor was nothing memorable, and for better or worse there were no KPop videos playing during lunch. By comparison, the food was excellent, specifically the spicy pork bi bim bop in a hot stone bowl. Prices were very reasonable and servers were pleasant and attentive.
author: Mark H.

description:
We came for late night food. We were there like about 1.30am and i ordered bulkoki. I bit on a small piece of bone and cracked my teeth. Its bad. 
I got only 6 side dish. No refill. No lecture.
The food was good.
author: Mark T.

description:
(See pics) Updated on 4/11/2013 Second visit. It's still just okay. Came back for late night dinner and ordered the jok bal (steamed pork hog) and seriously, this is not an appetizer and is not for 2 people. It's so much food that it's easily for 5 or more people and at some point, we were tired of it.

Also had the soon doo bu again but this time it was not spicy at all! Was quite disappointed as I missed the hot spicy soup. However, this time they brought the egg separately and we cracked into the soup. So my suspicion of last time that the egg was not there was likely the case.

The chicken gizzard skewer this time was pre-cooked and microwaved up as they were very dry and shrunk to small meatballs. They were a bit hard to chew on. The chicken skewer and soon doe skewer (Korean sausages with spicy sauce) were a little bit better.

The soju drink was alright and not too sweet.

Service was still excellent.

*************************

(See pics) Review #1358. More of 3.5 stars for now and would be higher if it's not for the raw gizzards. Soon du bu is definitely definitely making me hot and sweaty.

This is a changing scene city, with new eateries opening up all the time, even long time places were gone, long time as in anything that has opened for more than a few years. And this spot was vacant for quite some time and finally another Korean spot is open (there are only 2 within walking distance) about 10 days ago.

In a fizzy drizzling evening, a hot soup base dish would totally warm up the chilly night.

The seafood du bu ($11) was piping hot and you can see big bubbles bubbling up. This is one of my Korean favourite dishes. The broth was excellently spicy heavy and can make one drip sweat. The taste was very flavorful and the bowl was filled with lots of tofu, mostly squids and a couple shrimps. Was hoping to find a couple other items though. Also and unfortunately, only some egg white was found and not the full egg even they did say it's cooked with the soup. The rice that came with was good and perfectly absorbed all the spiciness and was very filling.

Also got the chicken gizzards / hearts ($5). Sadly out of the 2 skewers (8 total) there were 4 that were raw! Did point it out to the server as a note. They might have had forgotten that order as it arrived after the tofu soup.

As usual, there were complimentary small pickled dishes but only 4 while other places usually have 6 - 8. But they all tasted pretty decent.

They also serve beer, sake and flavoured soju drinks but had not tried any at this visit.

There is a projector playing K-pop MTV on the wide wall with GREAT sappy love songs playing that were not too loud, just enough as a background. The place is spacious with dim light.

Service was very friendly though a bit slow but not too bad.

There are many other items on the menu such as appetizers, noodle soup, full entrees with mackerel and spare ribs, as well as hot pots and bibimbap, so will definitely come back to check those out, especially since they open until 2am every night except Sunday nights which is until midnight.
author: T L.

description:
The Short Version

+Food: Good
+Drinks: Bad
+Videos: Oddly enjoyable & completely hilarious

The Long Involved Version 

I live in Hawaii where 55% of the population is Asian. So when someone suggests we eat Korean food in SF, I automatically think to myself "Should we take the chance of possible mediocrity to people please and satisfy the whims of others?" And in this case, I said "Okay" while my insides filled with doubt.   

707 Sutter was empty when we arrived with only one other couple eating dinner. Not gonna lie, it was awkward, and this is why no one wants to eat in an empty restaurant. We were seated by a very nice server and perused through our menus. We decided on a kim chee pancake, stone pot of bulgogi, and a grilled fish (can't quite remember if it was mackerel). To start they served a variety of ban chan which was not horrible, but not impressive either. These days the worst thing you can be is "not memorable." Our main entrees however were DELICIOUS! The balance of flavors and textures were all right on point, and I gave my friend Johnny T a big high-five for not picking a loser restaurant.

The downside of our meal had to have been the strawberry soju pitcher which was $25. It's a deal when you think about how many drinks you get and for you fellas who are looking to close the deal, this is your perfect vehicle. It tastes like you're drinking kool-aid and it's very easy to get completely wasted. Which of course makes your date more sexually attractive and exponentially more interesting. Our soju had weird chunks of ice in it and the flavor just wasn't there. But I still drank it!

The cherry on top of our kim chee sundae was the medley of K-Pop videos which were projected onto an entire wall. Watching K-Pop is like driving by a horrible car accident. You know you shouldn't stop to look, you know you should feel bad for being wanting to see the chaos, but you cannot help yourself. You are completely fascinated by the awfulness of the entire situation. K-Pop is AWFUL. But we could not stop watching it and we are still talking about how fun those videos were. 

Back Street Boy + Spice Girls + Justin Beiber Hair + Hello Kitty + Everything In Korean = K-Pop AWESOMENESS
author: Emi H.

description:
707 Sutter is such an amazing combination of a Korean restaurant and a bar.  Usually, from the previous restaurant/bar places like this that I've been to, their food is only so-so, and their drinks are what they specialize in because that's what brings in the profits.  

Not so here.  The food is so amazing.  I have been here twice already and I keep getting cravings to go there again!  The first time, I got soft tofu soup-kimchi flavor, which is unusual for soft tofu soups.  Usually, they have the different meats, then vegetable, and seafood, but usually not kimchi.  That's why I usually just get kimchi jigae.  The flavor was just perfect; I ordered it extra spicy to suit my preference.

The second time I got the bu dae ji gae with my boyfriend and our housemate, and it was amazing.  I will always get that if I go with more than 1 other person from now on.  The flavor of the broth was so rich and perfect.  Careful, the ramen noodles can get overdone quick, so bring someone who's experienced with watching it.

My boyfriend reports that the kimchi fried rice is the best he has ever had, and specifically, the pork one is better than the shrimp one (he tried both).  

One of the best parts about this place is that it's not too crowded ever (at least when I went) but it's never eerily quiet or empty either.  With kpop streaming in the background and always at least 1 to 2 other tables, it's easy to settle right in and get to ordering some amazing Korean food.
author: Charmaine D.

description: Love their soon doo boo chige soup. Comes with rice and variety of pickled(marinated) vegetables in small plate. Service is friendly and quick. My favorite place!
author: Chihiro A.

description: Bi Bim Bop! Cheese Corn!
author: Dingding Sherry W.

description: Good Korean food - their Bi Bim Bap and BBQ pork are favorites. Slightly overpriced and the service can be slow but they're open late and quick with takeout!
author: Nisha G.

description: I went to this Korean restaurant on a Tuesday around 2:30pm-3pm and the place was kind of empty. The food was okay. The BBQ bulgogi was not any different from other Korean restaurants that I've been too. The deep fried oysters that I got as an appetizer was good and it came with a kind of mayonnaise dip. A bowl of white rice came with my order and a small dish of sides. The service was good and the waitress allowed my friends and I to split the bill 4 ways instead of 3 or less just for that one time.
author: Junisa V.

description:
Yay, finally a good Korean place near me! This place is a bit of a trek to walk up those hills but worth it!
I love their weekday lunch specials which includes soon do bu, and spicy seafood bibimbop in clay bowl. I also love their side dishes, which I always end up finishing and asking for seconds before my order arrives.
author: Nancy Z.

description:
Conveniently located and tasty Korean food.

707 is pretty new, yet it already seems to have gathered a following. Given the lack of Korean restaurants near Downtown, it definitely satisfies a need with its somewhat more accessible location. 

I have tried several dishes here including the spicy pork, the cold 'chol myun' noodles, and the spam & ramen filled stew 'budae jigae'. All of them have been pretty good and service has always been very friendly. The budae jigae in particular was a very large portion. It is labeled as being for 2 people, but 4 can easily partake in the feast. Their 'banchan' side dishes are also pretty good compared to what you get at other restaurants. 

Atmosphere wise, it is pretty standard. It is basically one big spacious room and the Kpop videos playing on a projector get the job done. It is also open till 2am, which is always a huge plus. 

The food here won't blow you away or anything, but it is solid. Their location and late-night hours are a winning combination.
author: Augusto T.

description:
Welcome to the neighborhood!  One day while walking home from the gym, I noticed a new snazzy sign "707 Sutter" with a hanging sign that indicated it is a Korean restaurant.  Bing!  Instant smile on my face as I have been waiting for a good, local Korean place within blocks of home.  Yay!  I couldn't wait to tell my bf when I got home.  I went online and read other reviews and was instantly curious!  

So, we went to check it out for ourselves last night!  It's got a cool, young vibe and it is nicely modernized with awesome music videos projected on one wall while you dine.  Service welcomed us and were so friendly!  

We ordered the beef tofu soup and the bbq chicken.  The tofu soup was perfect and comforting for a drizzly SF night, and the bbq chicken was flavorful and tender.  We love banchan (side dishes brought to you before your main meal), and enjoyed ours here.  We were instantly impressed with 707 Sutter and already thinking about our next meal here!  :)  Can't wait!
author: Maile N.

description: Overall pretty much satisfied With the food and service. They were starting to get busy but the servers could handle all the tables. The food was not so good but it was ok but I feel coco bang offers a more flavour full food. Will surely return.
author: Maria T.

description:
Comprehensive menu.  Nothing's really in Korean and English is spoken, so it's easy.  They take cards and cash.  The waitstaff are attentive.

$10+ a main dish isn't 'steep' but it isn't a 'cheap eat' either.

Their kimchi jjigae is legit. :)
author: Jennifer Y.

description: Loved the big screen playing Kpop music! Totally a good place to hang out with friends and get drinks while feasting on Korean chicken wings and jap chae! The jap chae was flavorful and no bland at all! The calamari was alright nothing special. The Korean fried chicken soy garlic was good it has a good crunch and sauce ratio to it. I Also enjoyed the ban chan set out while waiting for the food to come out! Overall this place is worth going back to!
author: Roseanne V.

description:
Pros: 
- Wide variety of typical, late-night Korean food
- Try the hot pots for 2+ people as they're a good variety of food
- They have a big projected screen of korean pop music always going in the background which is kind of a pro?

Cons:
- Food is decent for SF but pretty mediocre compared to LA Korean food. 
- The banchan (the little tapas they give you for free in the beginning) are kind of hit or miss in quality and there isn't much variety.
- Can sometimes be a line.
author: Doug G.

description: Delicious! Seafood pancake, dumpling soup, and stir fry pork and kimchi. Fast service. Good price. Didn't mind the continuous K-Pop soundtrack.
author: Keith C.

description:
Came here with friends, so we got to try a lot of stuff!

We had spicy topokki or ra bok ki (I forgot the name) with ramen noodles. It was pretty spicy for someone like me who is kind of sensitive, but I just washed it down with yogurt soju.

Then we tried jap chae which was garlic-y, not spicy, but delicious!!! My favorite.

We had regular fried chicken, which was also really good. Definitely different from KFC, but in a very good way! You can get spicy sauce on it if you want but we opted for plain.

Tried the omurice - I like the idea but something about the flavors was off. It may have been a personal thing. I also dislike peas in rice, but that's just me!

We had a kimchi Korean pancake which was not very spicy at all, but I still enjoyed it. Very tasty.

While the soju was good, I wouldn't recommend it for the price. $25 for a "large" container didn't get us very much. But they do have a wide variety of flavors if you want to try some.

All in all, I thought it was great. I look forward to coming back!
author: Julie W.

description:
Things I Liked: Decent Food, Big Open Space, Delicous Soju Cocktails, and We Happened to Just Miss the Line (but it can get crowded)

Things I Disliked: Service, Food Was Overly Spicy, Service.

Came in and got seated almost immediately. Then waited about 15 min to order and about another 30-40 for our food to get delivered. One dish got delivered about 30 minutes into all our other dishes getting served (as we were all literally finishing our meals) with no apology or willingness to comp anything. We had tried to ask her why it was taking so long, but after unsuccessfully trying to wave her down for about 10 minutes, we just gave up.  When I tried to flag down any server, they just waved us off and then rarely actually came by. Our food was also all too spicy, but that could be our poor white taste buds. Would've been more acceptable if anybody could bother to give us water or napkins.

I'm used to service being rushed at busy places, but this was borderline ignoring our table even when they saw me literally waving my hand at them nonstop.

Could've been an off night, but probably wouldn't be back since I like Cocobang better anyway and their service is apologetic if it's slow.
author: Christina R.

description:
I got to admit, the atmosphere of the restaurant was the best. All the k-pop music videos were really cool. But it was kinda too loud for us. I don't know if that was because we sat near the corner, where the speaker was, but it was hard to listen to the person across me or right next to me. We had to say real loud.
Other than that, the food was like the best Korean food I ever ate in America, and maybe even better than some restaurants in Korea. If you are good at eating spicy foods, I suggest spicy squid. Every food we ate was extremely good even for Koreans! I definitely suggest this place for not only Korean food lovers, but everyone. One notice, it might be good at first but later on it might get spicy. Very.
author: Anna Y.

description:
Service is insanely wonderful, there's Korean music videos playing on the wall, and food is great!! If you like kpop, make this your hangout~ Surprised there wasn't more people!

We shared the tteokbokki and it was so good!! Ramen was chewy, rice cakes were chewy, and the sauce wasn't too spicy or too sweet. I took some home and reheated it later, and it was STILL GOOD. You know a dish is yum when even the leftovers are yum ^^

I had the kalguksu which was nice and comforting and warm ^^ I was running around SF without a jacket at night so I wanted something like that and this was perfect T___T Only thing is I wish it had actual knife-cut noodles instead of long thin noodles.

Another criticism is only having six banchan selections, but I'm just being picky :P I'm kinda spoiled by way of banchan; those six that they gave us were still good. I just like having a bit of everything, and wish there was radish :3

I love this place, my new favorite. I wish it was closer to San Jose~
author: JoAnn C.

description:
Food here is amazing.

Rice cake with cream sauce is a must ordered dish. The kimchi fried rice is pretty awesome, too!

The only thing I don't like is the price raise. They raised the price of BBQ chicken from $9 to around $16 last year.
author: Davis L.

description:
Considering how I am on a total Korean food withdrawal from Toronto, I'm glad to see that this place opened up when I moved here to San Francisco about 6 months ago.

The food is legit. Spicy and legit. I always get myself the soon dubu chigae (with kimchi) -- it's something that can never go wrong. One time, I ended up getting myself the budae chigae with two other friends, and boy - we were stuffed. 

Another plus for all the guys out there -- they play kpop videos in the background. It's hilarious when I'm out with my guy friends, and you just see their eyes fixated on the screen.
author: Joanne W.

description:
707 Sutter is my new favorite spot for Korean in the city, with comforting dishes that always fulfill my cravings. They start you off with a nice display of banchan that varies a little depending on what they have. I love their kimchi, and sometimes the japchae comes as an appetizer as well. Both times I've gotten the hot stone bibimbap, which comes with a generous portion of rice, veggies, and the meat of your choice. The ratio of each is perfect, and the rice gets super crispy at the bottom due to the heat of the stone bowl. 

I've also tried their spicy rice cakes, which come with fish cakes and a slightly sweet and spicy sauce. It's a heavier dish, but exactly the kind of carb-heavy food you want on a cold day. They have a lot of variety on their menu, from noodles to rice dishes to snacks, and I'll definitely be back to try everything out!
author: Ashley T.

description: korean soju bang in the city...dark, loud and k-pop...young employees...order of soju $11 and pitcher of beer $15...drinks before deciding on food...group of four and on 2nd round of drinks in the city...budaejjigae (army stew) $26  to simmer on the table top...quite large and enough for 3 or 4 people...has a slight sweetness and buttery note to the broth...army stew is a mix of everything processed...hotdogs, spam, packaged ramen, msg seasoning packets from the ramen, and add vegetables and more...a stew from the korean war...armerican military bringing spam and processed meats...add korean noodles and seasoning...bring to a boil and enjoy...kimchi fried rice is $10 and good...mix in the egg and eat...soy garlic fried chicken wings $14 and lightly sauced in sweet sticky coating...pretty decent and $99 total for group of 4 after tax, tip and drinking...
author: Hen A.

description: Got here around prime dinner time and without a reservation, we managed to get a table for seven people. Ordered the kim chi fried rice w/ beef, which is pretty decent. The beef pieces could have been a little more substantial. I've heard great things about their soups.
author: James N.

description:
It was so so... My expectations were high since reviews were so great. I've had better Korean food else where. I ordered vermicelli noodles which was too sweet, beef bulgogi was decent but the dumpling soup was too salty. 

Atmosphere was too dark. I had to use my flash light to see what I was eating. Decor was very plain and simple. 

I realized, you shouldn't rely too much on the reviews. Some restaurant reviews are just too over rated and some are overly negative.
author: Helene K.

description:
Solid food in tenderloin. I was a bit disappointed by the four little dishes of side dishes in the beginning. I liked the beef bimbimbop and spicy seafood hot pot ( with new Zealand green mussel, tofu, mushroom, crabs, octopus, zucchini and other vegetables). I wish that the vegetables were put on the side as they were perfect in the beginning of meal and too soft by the end of the meal, after cooked on fire for an hour.

The ambience is interesting, a bit dark with Korean pop and romantic cheesy music videos projected on one side of the wall. Amusing but the restaurant could probably play it up to make it more fun. It seems a bit dark and cold as background music.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
Cavernous eatery with de rigueur k-pop videos on a wall. Portions are huge, but the food was just okay. Except the cheesy corn....which was the best I've had. Overall, I prefer the food at Cocobang.

They forgot to bring us a couple of our dishes (and we forgot to check the bill at the end).

More like 2.5 stars, but I'm rounding up because they had to deal with my drunk friend.
author: Carolyn F.

description: Very genuine korean food ! Super large dishes with very cheap prices. Waiters are good-looking also!
author: Zhiwei S.

description:
Twinkly lights
Projector playing Korean pop R&B on the wall
Seasoned meats over rice or noodles, yum
Soju cocktails
Late, late night yums and fun

A+
author: Super L.

description: Great spot if you're craving for some spicy Korean food but too loud with K-Pop music video projected on the wall. Cocktails not enough alcohol.
author: Des L.

description: Great place for dinner! Our first time to San Fransisco and we came here twice 2 nights in a row! High ceilings, dark lighting, constant K-pop music video projected on the wall, attentive waiters and waitresses, delicious authentic Korean food, good selection of Korean alcoholic drinks, value for money. Overall, highly recommend for a good meal and a fun night out. You can eat till you drop!
author: Fransiska A.

description: Seafood pancake is crispy and filled with seafood. Spam kimchee fried rice was amazing, extremely flavorful and solid portions. I am a fan. I also recommend the yogurt and mango soju, those were really good! My friend ordered a bibimbap with spicy pork and that looked scrumptious. I want to try everything!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Came here on thursaday for dinner. It was three of us and we were looking for an alternative since Have a Rice Day changed their times and are not open to dinner anymore.

First thing we noticed was the ambiance. Very little travels into the building with tinted windows and few light sources inside. A huge projector is displaying Korean music videos and dramas on the wall. Kpop is being played incessantly but not too loud to obstruct conversation. 

Staff is super friendly. They were very courteous and apologized when the food was slightly delayed and gave us a estimate when our dishes would arrive.

We made three orders: Japchae, Kimchiee fried rice, and Fried Chiken wings sauted in pepper sauce.  

This is where i have to knock on their performance. Portions were slim, from the entrees to the banchan they serve on small sauce trays. The Japchae and Kimchee fried rice was nothing spectacular . The only saving grace was the Fried Chicken Wings. We felt they didn't skimp on this plate as they gave us roughly 8-10 wings. The texture combined with the pepper taste gave it an amazing sweet tang that clearly made eating here worth it. I would come back here for multiple orders of chicken wings and nothing else. 

Overall trendy atmosphere with mediocre dishes and slim portions. However the Fried Wing is what may make me walk that steep hill to get here from union square.
author: Jude N.

description:
Pros:
+Soju - variety of flavors, taste like juice for those who don't like ethanol flavor. 
+Seafood pancake - Perfectly cooked with squid, shrimp, potato?; Great to share
+Short ribs - tender and little char on the outside. Bit pricey but great entree to share. I wish they would cook the onions a little more though. 
+Jap chae - korean glass noodles with beef; Sweet and salty, the noodles yummy to slurp as they are not dry like stir fried noodles. Perfect portion for one.
+Egg souffle - perfectly salted, fluffy and light.  Great with rice.
+ Service - very attentive waitress; she was also very cheery greeting us and quick to respond when we asked for anything (water, utensils, etc)

Cons:
-Kimchi (and other side dishes) - was stale and not nearly as pickled/spicy as other places
- Soft tofu with beef soup - Tasted like kimchi soup and no beef/chicken broth. Barely any beef or other sustenance in the soup. Wouldn't order this again.
- Street parking - near downtown so needless to say, it is hard to find a space

Overall, the experience was enjoyable although I would not go out of my way to come here.
author: Rowena N.

description: The budaejjigae (spam and sausage soup), omelet with cheese and mackerel were excellent! Definitely coming back.
author: Helen J.

description: Really nice place. Would definitely come back to try more food on the menu. Excellent staff, good beer and tasty dishes.
author: Neto R.

description: Went for lunch  - service was quick.  Ordered the box lunch spicy pork. They was no Kim Chee with the lunch - just shredded soy flavor potatoe . Portion was just enough for lunch. Love that they leave a pitcher of water on your table.  Ordered to go Kim Chee fried rice.  Not the same like home but it did have a kick in the fried rice - especially when you eat it the next day!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Came here last weekend for a nice dinner with friends.  The place is large, sprawling almost, with plenty of space in between tables.  I liked that we weren't all packed together like sardines. 

They have a huge wall projecting K-Pop and other music videos, has a great club vibe.  I feel like this is as close to a Korean bar as you're going to get in this city.  I guess the only thing that's missing is the indoor smoking like they have in Oakland..  

The food came out, the side dishes (banchan) were a little lacking, vvery small portions, we only got 3 1/2s of the yellow daikon radish pickle, there were 7 of us...
Although they were happy to refill.

The food was ok, typical Korean fare, nothing spectacular.  Might try the pig feet next time.

I would go here again, maybe not to eat, but to drink.  Nice place.
author: Tu T.

description:
I like this place.

Came in for a late lunch on Saturday.  For $12 + tax & tip, I got a legit dol sot bi bim bap with banchan and miso soup.  Left stuffed and couldn't finish it all.

Very happy that there's an actual decent quality restaurant in this space instead of New Peking.

Not sure if they'll dethrone Coco Bang for best Korean fried chicken in the hood, but I'll determine that next time I'm here.
author: Jeff D.

description:
Let me explain the two stars. I read many ranting reviews that sound petulant or due to service, etc. But this is purely about the food. Furthermore, I hate to criticize a restaurant particularly because it's someone's livelihood. I do feel the need to say that I was very disappointed by the quality of food tonight.

I ate chabchae, dumplings, and shrimp skewers. Not the most Korean meal, but my wife is Middle Eastern so it never is. But all the banchan was also off.

I think the biggest detriment of the food was texture and traditional flavor. It unfortunately had odd sour tastes and somewhat salty flavors that were unexpected. Kimchi is also a true barometer of a restaurant and although there are many types of kimchis out there... This was just plain awful.

If the owner would like to reach out, please feel free and message me. Given the volume of reviews, I am sure this will not impact the overall score. I am happy about that, because again, I would not want to damage someone's livelihood but simply wanted to provide feedback.
author: Jae K.

description:
DON'T get the soon tofu here, especially if you're not inebriated. If you ARE, then this place should do just fine for you.

I came here for dinner on Friday night and my bf and I each ordered a soon tofu and shared a seafood pancake appetizer. The seafood pancake is good, very tasty..but also extremely oily.  

The soon tofu doesn't have much flavor - it's definitely spicy but lacking of any other flavor besides that. Neither of us finished our meal. If you know how decent Korean fare should taste like, stay far away from here.
author: Venus L.

description: Very tasty!  Got the bi bim bop.  Atmosphere was fun, started dancing to the k-pop videos by the end!  Overall great experience. Highly recommended!
author: Garrett F.

description: This place is great.  I've been here twice now, and both times I've been really impressed.  The first time I tried their vegetarian japchae noodles which was ungodly good - especially if you're a fan of shiitake mushrooms.  I also ordered the kimchi pancake, which when hot, was amazing.  Loved the banchan as well. When I came back for the second time, I tried the vegetarian dumpling soup.  The soup, while good, wasn't something I'd come back and order again.  That said, I'm going to keep exploring the menu for 707 Sutter because so far, I like what I see!
author: Zach S.

description:
I love this place.  I used to go here 2 times a week with my friend.  This is our go to spot in this area.  

I like the Kalbi and the Kalbi short rib soup.

They have a great mix of Pon chon (not sure if i spelled it right) and a great poppy atmosphere.  

I like to sit down eat and drink soju while I'm here.

All the waiters are really attentive.  My friend did know the manager running the place so we were taking care of very well.  Even when he wasn't there, the staff was very proper and hustle hard.

Its so awesome, I wrote about it which you can read here

http://www.thealldayblog.com/the-choose-your-own-adventure-1-day-all-day-trip-guide-to-san-francisco/  

This spot definitely makes my list! This is a spot you have to try if you're in San Francisco and looking for some good authentic Korean food!

Thank you 707 Sutter for keeping me full! :p

-Mike Le All Day!
author: Michael L.

description:
The seafood pancake is good, but it is quite big for 2 ppl. My friend and I came here at 4pm and it was not too busy. The service is not really helpful though.
We had bibimbap and kimchi soup, not really special but the seafood pancake was surprisingly good :).
author: Phuong P.

description:
This place is so cool! 
A few cons: it's really hard to find parking. And it brings in some weird people who just go in to use the bathroom. 

Anyway, we were looking for a well-priced Korean place to dine at. Using the Yelp app, we found 707. We circled around for a long time. Finally, we found a parking garage. 

I had a raging hunger headache throbbing in my brain. The place was busy. Only two people were working all the tables in the place... So I felt sorta sympathetic to their plight. We actually didn't have to wait long for our table of five. 

We were placed right in front of the k-Pop videos being played on the wall.

It did take a while for them to get us completely settled with drinks and side dishes and appetizer... But again, they were pretty busy. 

We started off with cheese corn. I think...? It's just corn in like a cream cheese mixture on a hot plate. It was an interesting appetizer that I thoroughly enjoyed. 

Beer on tap was only $4/pint, not bad. I had a Sapporo. 

I had a bibimbap and it was so beautiful! Everyone else ordered soup. They all really loved it. 

The quality and the amount of food you get for the price is great. Actually, the prices are surprisingly great for such a cool location just off of some major touristy areas. Just a few blocks down, you might sadly end up at Cheesecake Factory in Macy's. Bummer.
author: Natalie C.

description:
We went back to try again the next day.  Gluttons for punishment?  Maybe.  But hey!  It wasn't busy!  :D

Food was really tasty, great flavors, and relatively quick.  I loved the rice cake dish I ordered and my father in law's fried cheese was interesting.  Still only one waitress though...

Note to management:  help yourself out and hire a couple more waiters.  It will do your business good.
author: Winnie J.

description: Came with a friend to grab some Korean food on a chilly day in SF. It was close by to where we were at so we decided to try it out plus the reviews were good. Walked in, was welcomed by a gentlemen and escorted to our seats. After looking over the menu, (coming from a Korean)the prices are really high. Korean BBQ for $24, ridiculous. I've been to many Korean restaurants in Bay Area and LA and never have I seen a dish for $24. Anyways, we ordered spicy pork and bibimbop. Came with 3 side dishes which I wasn't happy with because the portions were small. Kimchee,   ( fish cakes) and   (potatoes). Later asking for a refill on our side dishes they said they were out of potatoes.. It was only 6pm, how are they out of side dishes already? Doesn't make sense. Food was good I'll give them that. Probably won't be coming back again but they should really add more side dishes to give it a Korean vibe. We Koreans eat a lot of side dishes, 3 just doesn't do justice. I left to the bathroom and after coming back the waitress took our utensils and bibimbop away but left our spicy pork (did she expect us to eat with our hands?) I wanted to take our leftovers Togo but they didn't even ask or give me an option and cleared our table felt as if they were rushing us out, another disappointment.  Maybe I should have spoke korean to them and probably would have got better service!
author: Lau H.

description:
came here two days ago for the first time, and I would def come back. service is great, food is great. we ordered a soondobu with beef and grilled salmon. soup was nice and spicy, just how I like it. the salmon was good too, not dry and went really well with the onions in the sauce.

atmosphere reminds me of a more upscale version of Playground (soju and kareoke lounge in japantown), with the kpop playing in the background.
author: Ava F.

description:
This is a surprisingly big place, especially for being right in the middle of downtown. I went there with a friend late one night, and we ordered quite a bit of food. The service was pretty fast, the k-pop playing on a large projector was pretty fun. 

We ordered the kim-chee pancake, the rice cakes with ramen, and the pork bulgogi. The pancake was probably our favorite, though nothing was particularly spectacular. Still great and very satisfying for a late night bite though!
author: Ti Z.

description: Ate the food, pretty good, gave a tip, waitress came back to my table after I signed the receipt and the waitress said "Why only little tip? I should get more" I found that to be very rude and unprofessional. NEVER COMING BACK HERE AND THEIR GREEDY STAFF !!!!!!!!
author: John J.

description:
I've been here about... 4 times within the month and needless to say, I do love it here. They're open till 2am, got great service (props to the waiters who don't need to write our orders down!), delicious Korean food, and a home-y environment. Although, I believe the music videos on the projector could be a little loud, I think it's a great conversation starter! 

The food has always been delicious every time. The appetizers are priced very well (college student speaking), the servings are shareable, and the amount of time waiting for your food to arrive, you'll be too busy staring at all the beautiful K-Pop stars (Yes. I said beautiful. *drool).  I would suggest the gyoza, corn cheese, bim bap, spicy BBQ chicken, and jap chae. 

My favorite part about 707? The flavored soju pitchers! So delicious, I've tried every flavor. Mango and Peach are tied for first.  

The afternoons are not so busy, but the nights get pretty packed. Luckily, I've never had to wait for a table yet! The environment overall is very friendly, I always see the tables around me playing drinking games (as well as my own lol), while the others are curiously staring. 

Definitely should try this place out!
author: Alyssa C.

description:
Great food choices, servers are nice and very attentive.

Projector Screen is awesome. Tables are nice too with a some uneven ones but its doable.

Lightings are nice, very classy looking. 

Oh and if you turn the menu upside down youll see it differently LOL! :-P

Nothing negative to say about this place. That wobbly table can be replace so its not a big deal.
author: Clipperson P.

description: Went to 707 Sutter after shopping in the Union Square area. After going to a couple of restaurants that had long wait times, we stumbled upon 707 Sutter and decided to give it a try. I had the bulgogi and got a standard sized plate of the meat, not too little but not anything too much. The bulgogi was a bit watery at the bottom but the flavor and meat quality were on point. Additionally, my vegetarian friend noted that the place was fairly accommodating for vegetarians (she got the bibimbap). Food arrived in a reasonable amount of time and service was friendly and helpful--would come again/recommend to anyone who likes Korean food.
author: Lucas L.

description:
So all this time the good Korean restaurants were hidden around the TL!! Like Cocobang, 707 Sutter is has casual atmosphere serving the usual soju and beers along with your late night cravings for fried chicken, dukbokki, and casseroles. Then there's the usual soondoobu and bimbimbap but that's not the focus here (that's right--I never order tofu unless I'm held at knifepoint. They are evil blocks of soy).

Got the bulgolgi beef soup, garlic sauce fried chicken, and sausage noodle bokkeum. Everything was super flavorful with just the right amount of spiciness. Paired with my favorite club soda, Hite, everything was just mucho delicioso!! Service was somewhat slow, but fine. Will come back again!!

Last thing--I notice that downtown Korean places don't automatically give you rice. It's included. You have to ask.
author: Cheri S.

description:
Thank you 707 Sutter for accepting our party of 35+ not-the-best-behaving but inebriated happy guests on a Monday night at midnight.  We  definitely threw ourselves a mini post-grad night party in their restaurant with a 5 minute notice of our arrival. 

Food: Delicious drunk (and certainly sober!) korean food close to all the hot spots in downtown? check. Legit buh de jigae also known as "army" soup by koreans? Check. Crispy seafood pancake? Check. Reliable kimchi fried rice? Check. Ra Bo Ki (dukk bok ki w ramen)? Check. Even more amazing dishes that I cannot currently recall? Check!

Service: 5 stars for service! Kept their calm and split our checks. This will definitely be one of my go-to spots for flavored soju and late-night munchies.
author: Patricia K.

description:
My friend and I were there yesterday (Jun27,2016) around 4pm - 5pm. Both of us got sick (stomachache, felt cold, been sweating, and got a little high body temperature).
