To clarify: by the time 7:50pm Jun 28, 2016 (after more than 24 hours self-recovery - drinking water, night sweats), my body temperature was 101.12ºF. By the time 10:38PM Jun 28 2016, my body temperature was 102.92ºF (I took picture of my thermometer. And iPhone is smart enough to prove the actual time/place I took the picture).  I also asked my friends/coworker to feel my body temperature, just to get enough witnesses. And my Fitbit also recorded my a little high resting heart rate last night. And I couldn't eat anything today.

To be fair: I think there might be something wrong with the raw egg (for tofu pot). My friend who had dinner with me also said that the egg tasted weird  yesterday but she thought that was cheese. It might not be the restaurant's fault - it might be the the ingredients suppliers' fault.

It's reasonable that the restaurant must see doctors notes. But by the time we see doctors, we might be self-recovered already. It is also reasonable that I am not paying emergency fee for hospital just to get a meal refund. We are trying to clarify the fact as we liked this restaurant and have been there a lot before. But it is reasonable that we are very disappointed now.
author: Jess C.

description:
Mad props to how fast our servers were! A packed house on a Saturday night with only two people moving at breakneck speed -- it was impressive!

Food was also good. We had bibimbap and pork bulgogi.
author: Althea S.

description: I have no word to describe the food here,best korean food I've tasted so far. It's so good that I can eat all day. We order seafood pancake, tofu soup with beef and bibim naeng myun (I think it's spicy cold noodles with veggie, but they use buckwheat noodle here). Seafood pancake is great,enough crunchy & soft, fresh seafood. Food is well seasoned, actually it's kinda salty but everything else is amazing. If I dont live that far away, I'd go there alot.
author: ChiBoi L.

description:
I happened to stop in here as there was a long wait at the nearby Cocobang. It's located in the Tenderloin, but it's near the border so don't let that scare you away. 

This place is much more spacious than Cocobang. It has a large open space with a projector playing Kpop music videos while you enjoy your food. But since the space is a bit large, sometimes it can be difficult to signal the waiters. 

I ordered the daily special, kalbi tang. It wasn't the best kalbi tang I've had as the meat could have been more tender and the broth could have been more flavorful but it was pretty decent. They should put this on the regular menu as it is a standard item and I would definitely come back.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Poor selection of vegetarian items. I had the bi bim bop pot with tofu and it was pretty awful, woefully lacking flavor. I shared a Korean omelette with friends and that was decidedly much better. I believe the meat dishes are much better since my friends seemed pleased with their options.
author: Natasha I.

description: This place is big and probably a nice place to go to for after hour eats with friends. My BF and I came in randomly around 6:30 on a Tuesday. Fast service. K pop playing on the wall. Cool spot. As for the food. It's ok. The Kal bi wasn't bad. I've had better. Their was a spice in it I didn't like. CoCo bang down the street has better Kal bi. We also got bulgolgi and we just didn't like this dish. I've had it so many times but, again, there was a weird spice. The cheese corn though was BOMB!
author: Cheryl V.

description:
Summary: Decent Korean food with loud K-pop on blast non stop.

I've been here several times and there has never been more than two waitstaff and one person in the kitchen. Service can be slow when it gets busy  It's a nice change from the other Korean place around the corner since there's no wait here. Prices are fair for Korean food but there are no frills.

This visit I ordered patbingsu which is a dessert of shaved ice with red beans, green tea ice cream, canned lychees, maraschino cherries, and sliced fresh kiwis. It does the trick when I'm craving an asian dessert. You get a big bowl for the price and it definitely enough for two people.
author: Jeanne C.

description:
When I heard there was another korean restaurant in town that did not necessitate driving out to the Richmond or Sunset district, I was overjoyed to actually walk on over to the Tendernob on a chill, rainy night.  
 
The venue was quite spacious, you can tell the previous restaurant tenants left a series of artwork and decorations behind particularly a water color painting of an African women with bare bosoms. You do not see that everyday in a Korean restaurant! 
  
The menu was filled with various options ranging from several rice dishes, rice cake dishes, rice cake ramen dishes, beef stew, seafood stew, you name it, it looks like they have it. 
  
Depending on the size of your party, the ban chans are served on a mini platter rather than individual small plates like most Korean restaurants. Do not be discouraged by the size of the platter, you can always ask for more and they will happily oblige. 
 
Prices were decent for the city, $5-7 for appetizers, $11-15 for main entrees.
author: Becky Q.

description: My favorite korean place in SF!! I always always get three dishes (with 2 people): the soy sauce fried chicken, the kimchi fried rice (WHICH IS THE BOMB!), and the kalbi which I love comes out still on the bone (for 2 of the pieces). The kpop music videos playing on the wall is also a nice touch for that chill, hangout-with-friend vibe. They can accommodate large groups as well -- just make sure you call ahead so they set it aside for you :)
author: Jessica X.

description:
I had to wait a few days after eating here to clear my mind and write a coherent review...

Maybe the stars aligned in some fantastic way, because the food was PERFECT here. I ordered the soft tofu soup (soon doo boo) and my girlfriend ordered the dumpling soup. After I started eating, I became so engrossed I forgot to even offer to share some with her until it was almost gone. I could barely bring myself to share any! Probably the best soon doo boo I've had yet, just heavenly. I ate until I was so full I felt sick, and did not regret it at all. I'm sad I don't live nearby, and can't go right back!
author: Alexander C.

description:
Delicious late night bbq bul go ki!

We were at hopwater distributions having beers nearby but they close early and we were hungry for a late snack. Saw what appeared to be a movie randomly playing on the wall inside and thought what the hell...

The "movie" turned out to be Korean pop videos which was oddly entertaining at midnight after a few beers. It was a unique experience and ended up being the subject of more than a little conversation.

The waiter was good natured, fast, and our food was delicious. I had the bbq beef bul go ki and even though my memory says it was 5 stars I am pulling one because I was  most likely influenced by the aforementioned beers ;)

I have no idea what this place is like in the day time but it's a fantastic casual late night stop if your looking for some delicious late night Korean food.
author: Shayne H.

description: The best Korean spot in the city. Great food good drinks friendly staff. Get your ass over here!
author: John M.

description: First restaurant we ate at in San Fran! We had the Creamy Tteok Bok Ki rice cake, vegetables and bacon with cream sauce as our appetizer..omg it was DELICIOUS! Also, the dish is huge too...I guess you do get what you pay for because it's the price of an entree! We totally recommend that! For our entree, we decided to try the Bu Dae Jji Gae and see how it matches Pocha (my fav Korean eat in NYC)...and unfortunately, it doesn't match..Pocha's had the cheese and that was the gem that ties the whole dish together! Anyways, the food is still good and I will definitely return when I'm in San Fran! One thing that I really like about the atmosphere was that it is really airy which is great because I don't want to smell like grease after dinner.
author: Allison G.

description:
Clean place, lots of tables & chairs -- Good for big parties

My friend and I ordered the lunch special bu de ji ge (spicy spam kimchi noodle soup) (For lunch it's a smaller portion for half the price) which was pretty good, I expected there to be rice cake (dok) in it
*I even asked the waiter, but it wasn't in the dish.

We also ordered the seafood pancake which was good, but I have to say their dipping sauce in particular was pretty good. (better than the dish? haha jk, definitely enhanced the dish though.)

Ordered the corn cheese which is usually my favorite dish, but this place made it extra ....milky? and they added sugar to the cheese forsure. It was sweeter than usual, needless to say, we didn't finish and it was a pretty small dish.

Overall, I'd like to say this place is pretty decent. It's clean, spacious and chill. The food is okay to me, not anything terrible or anything great. It's nice to have a Korean place in the downtown area though. ;p
author: Mel T.

description:
We have eaten at various Korean bbq restaurants in South Bay. This was the first place we decided to try in SF because of the Yelp reviews. We asked the waiter for recommendations and ordered based on them. We quickly regretted our decision because we didn't like most of what we ordered. 

The Kimchi fried rice with bbq pork had maybe 2 pieces of pork in it. The seafood pancake was so oily to the point where we couldn't eat it. The food was also quite pricey for what it was. We might give it another chance and try other options on the menu.
author: H K.

description:
Only visit here was some of the best Korean food I've had outside Seoul. The seafood pancake was delicious, as was the kimchee jigae and Mandu soup. Not as impressed with the chapjae, and the dolsot bibimbap was good but would recommend trying something other than the seafood variety.

Good service, reasonable portions and prices. 

The atmosphere was great with K-pop videos playing on the side wall!
author: greg c.

description:
Have come here a lot.. Always Koran rib..this time got two chewy Hugh ribs.. Not cross cut .. And a poke if pretty cold meat.. Waiter argued that was Korean rib.. Does not even match their picture.  He said he would comp.. Then came back and said since I was eating (11:30 pm and just drive from la.. Thus hungry ) he wound take off 15 percent.. Shoved plate at him .. Comp...  

AVOID!!!!
author: Sue P.

description: Truly great Korean food! It looks very genuine, much different than in the places advertised as "Korean BBQ". Everything I've had there looked interesting and tasted intriguing. They also have a great choice of Korean alcohols, both beer and liquors. A nice feature is a giant screen displaying kpop, which makes the food even better. The only downsides are the decor and men's restroom that gets clogged quite often.
author: Piotr G.

description:
I've made a lot of great memories at this place over the years. The restaurant feels pretty spacious relative to a lot of its competitors. The service is always very nice and doesn't freak out when we come in with a large group. It's a great place to just hang out.

Their seafood pancake is delicious. I enjoy the dipping sauce that comes with it. I also like that it is thick but not too doughy. It's nice and crispy on the outside for a little bit of crunch. The yangnyum chicken is probably the best dish here. There's a good amount of heat but also some sweetness in the sauce. Can't put my finger on the ingredient making it nice and sweet but I love it.
author: Brian E.

description:
Came here about a month ago with my boyfriend. Since it was in downtown SF, parking was obviously really ridiculous so we had to valet for $10 when we only stayed for an hour and a half. 

Anyways, it was a nice little shop. Being a Korean raised in SoCal, I was reminded a little of back home when I came here. They played Kpop on the tv screens like any other Korean place and the environment was good. 

My bf isn't much of a drinker so we split the peach soju. It was way too sweet in my opinion, and on the weak side. We also ordered the ramen with rice cake entree and it was just okay... Nothing spectacular. I'm leaving 3 stars because the prices were kinda high for just basic tasting food and weak flavored soju. The workers didn't seem too attentive until you called them over either. 

Overall, it wasn't a bad experience. It's definitely a chill spot that I would go to once in a blue moon if I had no where else to go haha.
author: Ashley P.

description: This is a fun neighborhood spot that is open late and serves delicious and spicy dishes. I visited for the first time at 10pm on a Friday and it was packed. The beers were $4 and the kimchi fried rice was perfectly done. Order anything with beef bulogi. The food is great and the prices are reasonable.
author: Kim O.

description: Very poor service. Waters were never filled no one checked on our table. Servers wouldnt even take a glance at us. Wasted a lot of time waiting on our bill. Ordered a diet never got it and still charged us. They really need to work on their service!!!!! FYI business was moderate so no excuse for why the service was not good.
author: Chantelle I.

description: Stone bibambop was delicious and legit. Definitely will come back and try the kimchi fried rice next time.
author: Mandy Y.

description:
Yummy casual Korean food in a fun hip environment. I've come here several times with friends, both on weekends and weeknights. Unless you make a reservation or arrive early, expect to wait a little. This place gets crowded on weekends and is a great place to eat at after going out downtown.

Food: Try the army stew, kimchi pancake, chicken wings, tofu soups, and bulgogi. Banchan was tasty and refilled upon request. 

Ambience: Dark and sort of loud, depending on the time/people there. They project Korean pop music videos onto a wall, so it's definitely a lively environment. Probably best for a meal with a group of friends.

Service: Pretty good - food came out quickly and water was refilled several times. Had to flag down the waiter to get our check at the end.
author: J L.

description: We were looking for a Korean place that offers ramen and found this place.  So we decided to give it a try and I was a little disappointed and that could be that I ordered the wrong but the menu is not clear. . We ordered the spam ramen thinking it was in the same spicy tofu soup broth but this was in a tomato base broth.  It was not that great and my mouth is super dry low they use msg or it was too salty for my taste buds.
author: T L.

description: They're open late and the food is good. And it's Korean. So when it's 9pm and nothing's open, this place becomes a 5 star restaurant. The cheesy corn could use some work though as well as the kimchi fried rice.
author: Joshua F.

description: Food is great. Best Korean bbq I can find in downtown. But It's simply overwhelming when 3 people serve almost 50. They need help!
author: Jeremy S.

description: As an Korean food lover, It was great experience! The restaurant was pretty clean and tidy. In general, the food was amazing, and especially the servers were very friendly. I would definitely visit again :)
author: Hyesung L.

description: Just got back from dinner- our first experience with Korean food. The waitstaff were all very sweet and helpful. My husband and I shared beef bibimbop (get it  in the stone- the crispy rice is fabulous)and the sweet chicken wings- great prices and portions. I was a little wary of the "hipster vibe" described in some of the other reviews, and I am waaay past enough aspiring to be a hipster, but there was none of that. Very tasty. We're just visiting, but may have to seek out Korean food back in NJ.
author: Meryl A.

description:
First time there this afternoon. I tried spicy jap chae, small bu dae Ji ge something spelled like that, and lastly the kimchi fried rice with shrimp. Would have to say that this fried rice is different from the usual. It's better than the usual fried rice. The Jap Chae is simply the best out of these three. The bu dae ji ge is alright. 

The place is comfortable and service is good ;).
author: Sanjaya Gin P.

description: A-Ok is nicely put for 707 Sutter. The Korean food isn't memorable but I will admit that the Galbi Tang Special is a good one to get here. The Ban Chan (side dish) portions were weak in all areas but if you can flag down a waiter/waitress, you can ask for seconds. Not a bad place to go to if you're near Union Square/downtown SF. The restaurant is pretty spacious and it's not a bad place to bring a bigger party.
author: Grace L.

description: I don't why there are quite a bit of bad reviews but we had great service. I was starving and quickly ordered. They were generous with giving more ban chan when we were done. We order the seafood pajun, kimchi fried rice, and corn cheese. All of them were pretty good. Definitely not the best but id come here cause it's close to home and satisfies my Korean food cravings.
author: Jennie C.

description: Flavorful, spicy, and satisfying tofu soup that comes with a raw egg, rice, and side dishes (refillable). Environment is spacious (hard to find in this neighborhood!) and has a nice vibe with K-Pop projected onto the walls. Definitely my go-to place if I'm ever feeling Korean in the downtown/Union Square area.
author: Jeffrey Z.

description: My new go-to place for Korean food in the 'loin. I had the fried chicken here and it was comparable to famous chains like BonChon - extremely spicy and super crispy. Definitely recommend!
author: Ananya M.

description: Place gets busy at nights/ weekends. They have a big screen projector which plays kpop and sport games. Great place for soju and beer. They have a lot of good Korean food on their menu. Chicken was great! Was visiting from LA and I would say it's definitely on the same level as the popular LA Korean places to drink/eat. They also are open until 2am which is a plus!! It's in a good location so def come here after shopping to eat and drink!
author: Peter S.

description:
Always the spot when I want a late night bite after work. This is in lower nob by the way, not TL. Servers are always attentive, small Korean dishes or banchan are always tasty, fairly large menu, atmosphere is trendy with kpop playing from a projector to the wall. 

Out of all of their menu items, I come back every time for the budae jjigae (large hot pot full of hot dogs, ramen, veggies oh my) and the seafood bimimbap (stonepot rice dish). The budae jjigae was $30, pricey but is fairly large to feed up to 4 people. Servers always bring it out within 5 minutes of ordering, and cooks meanwhile kpop songs blast the place. The bimimbap is probably one of the best I've had. It comes already bright red from a Korean spiced sauce with a generous amount of seafood- just amazing with a cracked egg and crunchy rice bits at the bottom! 

Everything comes out quite timely which is what you want after a long day. The only criticisms I have of this place is that it is a bit dark in there, more lighting would be a plus. I also feel like there is room for more tables, especially on nights when there is a long wait! The music is painstakingly loud most of the time I come there, and can get a bit awkward when there are only 2 or 3 tables in at a time. Other than that, 707 is a must :)
author: Aimee A.

description: I ate Boodae Soup(Spicy sausage noodle soup) with my wife. feels like it is little bit spicy but it has all flavor required when we want to have it. as a native korean who remembered original taste of Boodae soup in Uijungbu where is an origin of the food, I can say their food is really great for us regardless we are in USA. I can suggest to have it if you enjoy spicy and fantastic taste. and you will experience special taste which is mixed USA and Korean flavor.
author: Kyungsuk S.

description: not bad for a korean place in the city. compared to places in south bay, food is a bit more expensive here. budae jigae is gooood (better than the one at cocobang in my opinion), and i recommend it for groups. cheese corn here is like cheese corn at any other place, but i guess it's a 'must get' at these types of korean restaurants. spicy pork serving is kinda small, but maybe i just eat a lot or my friends ate majority of it before i got to some. steamed egg and seafood pancake were aaaaiite (wouldnt get them again). soju cocktails were on the weaker side, so we used them as 'chasers' for the 239042903490234 shots of soju we had. we also did multiple seoul trains in different configurations and made a mess, but the workers were nice and didnt stop us haha (thank you!).
author: Annie S.

description: Came here for dinner Monday night and the place wasn't busy at all so we got seated right away for a party of 5. The place is so roomy. They have a giant projector of Korean music videos. Kinda loud but it's ok. Ordered the soon doo bu with beef. It was good but not the best I've had. It was $10 so that's a good deal. Friend got the seafood soon doo bu but she said there was barely any seafood in it. Just a few pieces here and there. The chicken Kim chi fried rice was really good. The bathroom was huge and relatively clean so that's good. Overall, it was good. I would come back.
author: Tammy W.

description: We are staying close of the Union Square district and we want to try a Korean restaurant. That place was really good. It wasnt expensive and the food was really great and tasty. I took a meal with beef and my bf took a meal with octopus and both really enjoyed our meal. If you are going there, try the soju too. The drink is really good but kick fast. Really a nice ambiance and the service was really fast. We went a monday nigh in november so the place wasnt too full. I really recommend that restaurant to everyone if you want to eat a good meal to a raisonnable price.
author: Christine G.

description: This place was great! The Korean Tofu was excellent. I know dumplings are pretty easy, but for some reason the dumplings here were pretty excellent as well. Not sure there are much better Korean restaurants in San Francisco, so I'll definitely be coming back here.
author: Alex K.

description:
Unfortunately my stellar first experience at 707 Sutter was marred when I took three out of town friends here for dinner a few Sundays ago. Despite the restaurant being at only 50% capacity, the service was horrendously slow.

The food was still on point, though. I'll still be giving this place more visits, but I hope for more reasonable service next time.
author: William C.

description:
I've been here twice now, and I'm giving 707 the benefit of the doubt. The first time was great, but the second time was slightly mehhhh. 

We have had the bulgogi, pork, soft tofu soup, and the soju at various times at 707. I asked to add noodles to my soup and was told they couldn't because the bowl was too small. Um.

The flavor was great, the soups were spicy, and we didn't have to wait when we made a reservation. Highly recommend making a reservation.

The good: tasty food. 
The bad: don't think you're special and order something weird. You're not special--they will remind you of it. :)
author: Amanda B.

description:
Randomly searched for this place while near Union square.  I was a bit skeptical of it, but it was surprisingly good.

Tried the seafood pancake, gamjatang (pork broth spicy stew), chicken skewers.

Seafood pancake was really good.  I was surprised, because this can be easily messed up by Korean restaurants.  Instead, this was very tasty with the right balance between the flour and seafood.  Definitely the highlight of the meal.

The gamjatang was extremely spicy, but very tasty.  Just the way it should be.  Was sweating up a storm.

The chicken skewers were just ok.  My friend insisted on getting them but I was disappointed.

Service could stand to get a little better.  It was very friendly but very slow.
author: Min Y.

description: Came here with my friend and tried their seafood tofu soup. It was tasty but beware that it could be quite spicy for your palate. The food was very fast as we didn't come at a busy time. However banchan (side dishes) were very small. I also ordered another dish to go with request to make it mild. When I got back to the hotel, boyfriend found out that they forgot the rice. Went back again for the rice and my boyfriend had his meal...sweating from how spicy it was. Wish they would pay more attention to details... Not sure if I would be back.
author: Jen C.

description: This is a great spot for soju and fried chicken.  Came here late at night and it was still busy after midnight, hip place with the projector, music and all.  The food is actually really authentic, the hot pot and egg omelette dishes where just like having them in Soul.  I never had fried chicken in Korea, but it was pretty good too and the spicy sauce ones in the mix are good.  Though, the chicken itself was a little fatty, being fried crispy really made it a non-issue.  Would be a five star place with just one step up in chicken quality though!
author: Cameo W.

description:
Food poisoning! 

I went there last Friday night and started feeling sick stomach after I got home. Since then, I've been practically living in the bathroom for 4 days straight. I have never had such a bad case of food poisoning before. I'm still not fully recovered yet. Avoid at all cost. The food was mediocre. Not worth the risk. Find somewhere else for safer food.
author: WS P.

description: The atmosphere of this restaurant is great. If you're looking for somewhere trendy you've found it. Also, 707 is a short walk from Powell Station. The calamari and strawberry soju were two of my favorites last night. I'll definitely be back!
author: Melissa C.

description: Okay first of all I'm giving this place two stars because the food was decent. The service here was so bad! I came here with four of my friends, the whole time we were eating no one checked up on us. I even had to walk up to get my OWN water. The servers were rude and the food came out so slow. We sat here and waited for 40 mins before receiving the appetizers. I would not come back again and would not recommend.
author: Jessie S.

description: I tried several smaller-than-expected appetizer skewers (chicken and beef) and the soft tofu soup. Everything was just okay. Banchan was pretty skimpy. The servers weren't attentive. We probably should have ordered the chicken wings since those looked promising. I'd probably come back to give this place another shot but I won't be in any hurry.
author: V V.

description: Been here a couple of times and it's now my favorite place to go to whenever I'm craving some dukbokki! They come in a pretty large serving and I recommend the creamy dukbokki, it's AMAZING!! Out of the times I've been there, it's usually not very packed and the service is pretty quick. Also love the kpop videos they sometimes play with an overhead projector onto the wall.
author: Sandy N.

description:
When CoCo Bang is too packed, don't fret: just head over to 707 Sutter.  Heck, nowadays, I just come here instead.  

The restaurant is about 4x as big as CoCo Bang, and imo, the spicy fried chicken wings here are much better tasting.  Moreover, the Seafood Pancake is really legit, and that's coming from a SoCal Native.  

I'm surprised this place has only 73 reviews (well 74 including mine), but it's definitely a place you'd want to check out if you're craving some flavored soju and some delicious Korean Bar Food.
author: Joshua P.

description: I had the chicken stone bowl bibimbap, and to say the least it was ok. I went for dinner with my gf and she had the pork rice dish. It was good but it was basically smothered with that spicy Korean paste. I see the reviews and it sound great, but maybe I came on a off day. Service was slow and dropping stuff, but the customers too were loud and drunk so I can understand its tricky. In any case, the music video is cool to have but it wasn't the best experience in a Korean restaurant in SF I had. Parking is also pretty much hell to find haha.
author: Robert H.

description:
Went here for the first time last night. Service was good, K-Pop rockin', but had hoped for better on the some dishes. By the way, this isn't Terderloin - it's Lower Nob Hill. 

My BF and I will give this another try as I'd love to have a go-to Korean spot close to home.
author: Susan C.

description: The best authentic Korean food in town! Their Seafood pancake is made just right and flavorful~ Great place for some beer, soju, and good food!
author: Daisy W.

description: this place is soooi fucked up. this is the first time that i have visited and the waiters just trew the memu and didnt dring anything. we were sitting there for 15mins only for waiting, nobody came and ask what we gonna eat. soooo fucked up. never ever going there again in my life. fucking hate this place.
author: Sue N.

description: Do you like K-Pop? This is the place for you. With a projector's worth of your favorite Korean stars and central location downtown, this is your convenient spot to get your K-Pop and soju fix. The food is typically Korean, with some pretty decent prices for beer and alcohol. Come for a good time, stay for the music videos.
author: Chris P.

description: Good music videos and good korean bbq. My boyfriend and I came here  on a Saturday night... parking in this area sucks but the restaurant was great. Friendly waitress and great korean music videos on the wall. Very clean restroom.
author: Jennifer M.

description: Good food! Especially good place to drink soju and people here are nice and welcoming. I like their fried chicken and seafood pancake. So far the best korean food in SF and it has a decent price. If you are going to visit SF i would recommend this place for good time drinking party and good food with your friends.
author: Jordan S.

description: Bibimbap was good but could have used more vegetables. Seafood noodle had an excellent taste. I also liked the music video played on the wall. Would love to go back and try some other dishes.
author: Fiona J.

description: Kind of a hole-in-the-wall, although apparently the place comes alive at night. We went for lunch on a Wednesday, so the wall was bare (which seems strange until we realized they played videos at night) and customers minimal. Waitress was not particularly friendly at first. Why the 4 stars? Because the food was authentic, delicious, and perfectly cooked. The side dishes were so-so, but the mandu soup and the bulgoghi were so yummy.
author: C J.

description:
We came to satisfy a Korean craving in the late evening and were not disappointed.  From the clearly Korean crowd, we knew this place should be the real deal and it was!  The bulgogi and jap chae were delicious.  The banchan offerings were traditional and tasty.  The food is for sure five star worthy.

The service was mediocre.  The food arrived quickly and was steaming hot.  But, out waiter never asked if we wanted drinks and we had to ask for water.  The atmosphere was also a bit spartan but who cares if the food is good?!  The K-pop playing in the background wasn't too loud and added to the experience.

If you're looking for traditional Korean food, this is the place for you.
author: Laura E.

description: Friendly staff, quick service and legit Korean cuisine. The environment is pretty loud and dim, but if you're in the neighborhood and craving korean it's worth a visit.
author: Angela L.

description: Nice place to eat and hang out with friends. Ordered fish cake soup, soon dubu (soft tofu soup), dumpling soup and spicy pork. For drinks we had, raspberry wine, lemon soju, mojito and rice wine. The mojito and lemon soju were not good at all. It tasted like lemonade. Told the servers and they made us a new one which was much better. Food was super tasty. Will be back for sure. Minus one star because of the watered down drinks.
author: Pana P.

description: Excellent food! My friends and I were wandering around the Bay Area and stumbled upon this hidden gem on Yelp. The food portions were HUGE, the food was great (especially the Bim Pop, and the Dumpling Soup!) and our waiter was very helpful. My favorite part though was the K-Pop music videos constantly being projected on the walls. If I'm ever back in town I'll definitely be bringing people here!
author: David R.

description: Visiting SF on vacay and hubbie was craving Korean food. To our surprise, there's not a lot of Korean food in SF. Found this place and it wasn't too far of a walk from our hotel in the financial district. Nice space. Loved the K-pop music videos projected on the wall. Food was good. We had a light dinner--seafood pancake and kimchee bokkum with tofu. Husband was satisfied and happy.
author: D K.

description:
Came here for a birthday and food was good and reasonable. They had cool videos playing and unlike other places service was fast. I would recommend the fired chicken with dipping sauce. Cooked to perfection and spicy ness was not too overwhelming. 

There's also the corn with cheese which is bomb. Place can get busy so make sure you make sure you make reservations. Also remember to get drinks haha the usual beer and soju is a must.

Ok time to get back to the birthday. Come visit it's greaaaaat!
author: Darryl S.

description: Love coming here when I'm craving savory flavors and meat. I go for the garlic chicken wings, steamed rice, and the side of spicy radish squares (not sure if that's what it is actually called). Fun atmosphere with a wall full of TVs playing K Pop videos. I feel like I'm groovin' in a Korean club. My first time having Suju was at this place - it was like an alcoholic slushy.
author: Kristen C.

description: Their seafood pancake is the best I've ever had. The yogurt soju is also very good.
author: Diane W.

description:
Modern vibe. Quick service. Great food! Loved the kimchi pancake and cheese corn. Oh that cheese corn.....so good!!
Small drink menu. Not much on the soju front. The bottled soju was great though! The vegetarian bibimbap did not have to much flavor. I've often had a veggie version that has a bit more flavor than this one. It was still good, but I've had a veggie one that was better.
author: Zoe D.

description:
The service is okay. The food was meh. The four-star yelp ratings had me thinking its going to be something good but it's whatever. 

Their banchan is eck, the galbi was blah, burnt and chewy, the kimchi jigae was disgustingly salty (we watered it down w/ a glass of water and it was still almost inedible), the steamed egg literally was just steamed egg (completely bland), the chicken wings were OKAY. The only thing I actually liked was the creamy dukbokki. 

If you asked me, I don't think I'd come again. 

PS. Seriously avoid the kimchi jigae unless you want your blood pressure elevated! Yikes!
author: Jeanette Y.

description:
The food portions here are rather large. Even most of the appetizers seem to be meal-sized. Everything I have tried has been amazing. That includes: kimchi pancake, soft tofu soup, spicy rice cake, spicy calamari, tonkatsu, and some other stuff I can't remember. (I've been here a lot...) None of the food has even been bad, but they do get really busy. Sometimes there's even a waiting list and people lining up inside. They could easily fit a few more tables in but its current set-up is very roomy. Also, they need more waiters!! It can take forever just to order your food if the place is almost full. 

There's a large projector that plays k-pop videos on the wall. It's rather loud, so it's not the best place if you intend on having conversations with the people you're eating with.
author: Adriana N.

description: We walked past late Christmas Eve and were drawn in by the amazing smelling food!! It did not disappoint!! Loved our meals - stir fry vegetables were a stand out, awesome friendly service & very cool KPop music- will definitely be back!
author: Denille L.

description:
Came here before a show in the area, made reservations for 9:30, we walked in and noticed that all the tables were taken..hmm..the manager or whoever came over and said that they have people leaving soon and that we'll have a table ready soon.  My question was just what if that weren't the case? lol seemed pointless to have a reservation if they don't reserve a table.  

Anyways onto the food: do NOT order the kal guk soo. the description is not what the actual food is. it says it's seafood and spicy noodle soup.  But what it really is just a few pieces of clam and bland soup...WTFFF soooo disappointed.  

I ended up just eating my friend's jap chae and my b/f's leftover bipmbap lol which were both quite delicious.  

Overall, not a bad place but there are a few things they could work on.
author: Amy Y.

description:
Not very good, but they get an extra star from me because the service was friendly. (I'm tempted to say 1.5 stars?)

The service was not anywhere near perfect, though, because they had completely forgotten about one of our dishes, until we reminded them well after we finished the other dishes that were served to us.

The banchan was not good, and I would even say they were bad.

The dishes were mediocre at best. I was pretty disappointed in the flavor and quality of the multiple dishes that we tried.

The decor and vibe were fun, but very noisy on a Saturday night. 

Overall, it wasn't a good experience, and I will not go back!
author: J K.

description: Food was alright. We ordered the octopus stir-fry and garlic chicken wings. Side dishes were very simple and they only gave a small amount of each. I was horrified to find a dead cockroach in the women's bathroom. If I'm really craving Korean food I'll come back, but I won't go out of my way to return.
author: Diana F.

description: Love this place.  It's always a blast every time we go with a group of friends. Service is great. Beer and soju is quick.  Order the kim chi fried rice, Pajoun, Dok boki, and any thing else really.  It's all delicious and spicaaaay.  This place would be amazing if they we're a little bigger and had a dance floor, cause then I could do some AZN clubbin finally.
author: Kyle I.

description:
Cheesy Corn was not made right.
Fried rice wasn't very good either.
Meat skewers were very bland.

The Service was very nice though
author: Nathan C.

description: Pretty decent place. As other people said it was not busy at all, so I was bit concerned but it turned out to be good choice. I ordered spicy pork and it was very good. I can come back to this place any time.
author: Amit A.

description: Great food and excellent service. Went here with a buddy the other day. Was craving some Korean food after some drinking and this spot came up. Cool vibe and videos of K-Pop girl groups that my buddy couldn't take his eyes off. On the way out I didn't know I forgot my laptop bag but the guy ran out and handed it to me. There are still some good people left in the world.
author: Ariel P.

description:
It was an unexpected visit after an unsuccessful trip visiting the Ramen fest.
Our group of 12 yelped for the better Asian food around J-town area and came across this place a little more than a mile away. So after taking our hike across town and arrived at this restaurant we were a bit starving.

The ambiance was good and we quickly settled at our table and took our order soon after since the place is about half full.

Now, the wait begins. I am not really blaming it on slow-service because there are only a chef in the kitchen and one waitress managing the entire floor. It took over 30 minutes to have our appetizers delivered.

The foods are good, from the Kimchi that was flavorful and mildly spicy, the seafood pancake that had the perfect crispy char while still showcasing the tender squid and moist interior, the fried rice cooked up fluffy and a bit chewy with a balanced rice to ingredient ratio, I am rather impressed with how the chef was able to prepare food for the entire restaurant by herself non-stop, multi-tasking at its finest delivering quality food.

Perhaps more people showed up to eat because the Ramen fest was too crowded, or perhaps a few people called out sick, I can't help but feel that this place has had some fantastic moments satisfying some serious Korean food cravings; but just not our day.

The waitress treated us to a "pitcher-bottle" of free beer to help us with the wait. I honestly had a pretty good lunch, but I know this place is capable of much better.
So until next time I revisit.

Cheers.
author: Edward L.

description:
First off, I don't know how they got a 4-star rating, but by means of friends and family.

Service: Friendly, but not attentive. When you get their attention, they're nice, but they're not really paying attention otherwise. And the place wasn't even crowded.

Freebies: What asian restaurant serves tea without a pot, but per individual cup? A restaurant that doesn't understand Asians, that's who. Banchan, they were paltry bird-size servings. Didn't satisfy my late-night Korean food craving.

Food: I can get better japchae at the Korean grocer's counter. Too much soy sauce and not enough sesame oil. Japchae is basic 101. If you get that wrong, you won't last.

I kind of wanted to give these guys 3 stars for being open late at night, but I woke up the next morning with the worst upset stomach. Too much sodium and MSG, and not enough hot tea to rinse off the grease. Not going back unless I'm stuck in the 'loin with amnesia.
author: Bibi B.

description: Love this place. My boyfriend and I love this as our late night date place. If you want the wings order them first because they won't come out until the very end of your meal but they are worth the wait. We have been there a half dozen times and have had the same waiter every time. He is organized and methodical and rearranges our table every time he delivers a new item. This may sound annoying but the way he arranges the table makes perfect sense.
author: Sarah K.

description:
Ate here on New Year's Day because I was craving Korean BBQ. We ordered...

Ban chan - I'm not even sure why they bother serving this at all. The selection and amount is such a disappointment. Additionally it did not contain much flavor.

Kimchi pancake - i didn't have this but my bf did and thought it was good. Appeared crispy which is good bc a lot of places tend towards the soggy side.

Soon doo bu - broth did not have a rich flavor. It was bland compared to other tofu soups I've had. Also there were only a few small pieces of beef in the soup. Included some odd veggies like green squash which appeared to be used as filler. 

Galbi - very tender but not as flavorful as the Galbi I've had at other restaurants. 

Jap Jae - this was very disappointing. Barely any beef included and extremely over salted. Also the noodles were undercooked. 

I'd have to say that as far as Korean BBQ goes San Francisco has nothing on northern Virginia if this place is any indication.
author: Mai C.

description: Decent Korean food. Nice k Pop music and movie on the wall. Service is soso. Quite a busy place.
author: Jeni Y.

description: The spicy pork neck bone soup is delicious!! Plenty of vegetables and pork, more than enough for two people!! Although, we had to wait a little after the food is on our table for it to fully boil to eat it, but the wait was worth it! All are reasonably priced.
author: Ran C.

description:
This is the second Korean restaurant I've tried in downtown area and it turned out to be better than what I'd expected. (The first one I tried disappointed me so much I thought twice about having koren food in downtown.) It might look expensive when you see the menu but the food portion is above average. I had tofu soup and it was heavenly! I'm going to go again to try out what other yelpers recommend!

Just a heads up. The neighborhood is kinda dangerous to walk around alone.
author: Fong C.

description:
My dining companion felt like Korean, so we decided to check out the new joint in the hood.  One of the first things that I noticed about this place is how unimpressive their banchan is, especially for the price that they charge for their food.  For two people, we got a plate with five of them with about a tablespoon of each.  But at least the half tablespoon of each that we got to try was tasty.

We also ordered rice cakes in red spicy sauce, BBQ spareribs, and tofu soup.  I've never been a huge fan of tofu soup, but the rice cake and BBQ spareribs were delicious!  The spare ribs were flavorful on their own, but after having the rice cakes with the tangy red sauce, I couldn't help but dip my spare ribs into it.  I know, totally unhealthy, yet amazingly delicious stuff.

We ate that while watching K-Pop music videos projected against a wall.  Ya know, just to round out the whole Korean experience.

Can't say I'd be here often since this is really, really heavy food, but should I get a fried chicken craving in the future, I really want to try it here, and I'm adding an order of those rice cakes just so I can have its tangy red sauce to dip them in.
author: Debbie L.

description: Good food, good prices, efficient service. If you're looking for some quick Korean food, this hits the spot. I've been to Stone Bowl Plus and the prices are much higher and service definitely not as good. I'd come back here and recommend to friends!
author: A S.

description: The food was pretty good, but they seem to be severely understaffed. We had to flag someone down a couple times to order and ask for the check after about 25 min of neglect, but the waitress was really sweet. I guess it'll be nice to have an alternative when Cocobang's busy.
author: tianyu l.

description: Had a bunch of different stuff here totally yummy. Cute spot. Loved catching up with a old friend here.
author: nancy w.

description: Keep it up guys! Awesome service, called to get our food ready before we got there since we were in time constraints and they certainly perfectly timed our arrival with food hot and ready on our table. Talk about exceptional! I will defo be a regular. Cheers.
author: Dustin G.

description: Been here a few times and thought it was a good place to host my bday din. Asked for refill on the banchan side dishes and was told I will be charged extra. WTF - is this a Korean restaurant?? Horrible service. Servers were slow and gave us attitude. Charged us mandatory 18% tip for horrible service.
author: M J.

description: you must try the budaejigae here!  YUMMMMMMMM...  with Kpop playing in the background...  it was fun!
author: Soo M.

description: The quality of the food here is amazing and the staff and owner are extremely friendly and generous. When I don't have time to come here I always order food from here via postmates because the food reminds me of my mom's cooking.
author: Brian L.

description:
I came here last night (Thursday) and it was pretty packed.  It's quite spacious.  Good for large parties.

Food:
Banchan - fish cake, broccoli, noodles, daikon, small portions but they refilled it for us when we asked
Beef Dumplings - YUM!  the dipping sauce was a bit spicy but still really good
Soon Dae (Korean Sausage with noodles and vegetables) - it was my first time trying Korean sausage, to my surprise it was made out of noodles.  The spicy sauce it was in was HOT but delicious as well
Kimchi tofu soup with pork - again, really spicy but good

Service - it was a bit hard trying to wave down the waitresses, since it was quite busy.  It took a while before they took our order (we had to wave them down).  But the food came out pretty quickly.

4-stars
author: Veronica N.

description: I've walked by this place all the time but finally had a chance to try this past weekend. It was pretty crowded for a Sunday night but we were seated immediately and the service was good. This place is pretty much the same as Playground in Japantown but less rowdy. The menu was extensive and the banchan was kinda mediocre but it was okay. I had the spicy kalgooksu and it was really good, which is saying a lot because I'm really picky with my Korean food. Will come back!
author: Patty K.

description: Let me start by saying, I love me some Korean food. Unfortunately for my experience, this place really wasn't all that. Drove an hour to see what all the hype was about. Ordered 3 dish, spicy rice cake with ramen, kimchi pancake, and ramen noddles soup. Spicy rice cake was good, kimchi pancake was soggy and plain, and the biggest disappointment was the ramen, too sour and not spicy at all (we ordered extra spicy). And mind I say, this place is not cheap. Service and environment was okay. Overall, it wasn't worth it driving an hour for food we didn't finish. If you want some bomb as Korean noddle, Tonight Soju is the place!
author: Ka L.

description:
Glad to have found this place. Ambiance is similar to Cocobang. Service was quick and excellent :)

We enjoyed the Omurice and Soondobu jjigae. The steam egg was not as smooth as I had hoped but the flavors were there.
author: Lyn X.

description: Finally the New Peking Restaurant closed and this new hip Korean joint opened up. They show Korean movies on a big open wall and have great music. Plus added bonus for me is that they have pig's feet on their menu. Yay!! They're open for lunch and dinner are supper nice. And super yummy food. AND large portions. It's wonderful to be able to get Korean food closer away from the TL. What's great is this place is much bigger than CoCo Bang's and since it's still new...no lines yet.
author: Ms. T.

description: Good Korean restaurant! Totally satisfied by the food and the service. But menus and tables not the cleanest I've seen in my life. They are super helpful trying to adjust any of your requests (vegetarian, no garlic, gluten free, light, mild...)
author: Stefano D.

description: This is the best Korean restaurant I found in downtown so far! The flavors and spiciness of are just about right. The tofu soup is great and price is also very reasonable. Only thing is their small dishes are very limited - they don't have kimchi! How can you not having kimchi for small dishes in a Korean restaurant? Except that I am satisfied with my meal and will definitely come back again and try other dishes.
author: Sophia H.

description: Service is REALLY REALLY REALLY bad! They made customers feel embarrassed! Although the food is ok, they sometime let me just sit there and wait about an hour, just because the waiter "forgeted" my food. Don't even say they always forget to give you some food when you order to go.
author: Xiaoyun W.

description:
Food:  We ordered Jokbal and Dubu Kimchi.  The pig's feet was absolutely delicious and the consistency of the meat was perfect.  Dubu Kimchi was good too but a little bit on the sweet side.  

Service:  The servers were friendly and efficient.  Though one male server accidently spilled on my hat and bag when he collected an empty plate at the end of dinner.  He apologized but the store didn't offer anything more than just a few napkins.  

They have a wide selection of food and decent list of alcoholic beverages.  The dinning area is pretty clean.
author: P C.

description:
Seven up.

Tough decision among many good looking choices. One bite into the house marinated BBQ confirmed the right decision was made. Flavorful, tender, lean and delicious.

Price of $14 plus tax was very reasonably considering the only reason it didn't become two meals is because it was good enough to eat as one. 

Comes with a few complimentary traditional Korean sides.

Projected K-pop is different. But I guess that's the point.

With dishes this generous and this good Seven Zero Seven should stay on the up and up.
author: Jason B.

description:
My coworker and I love Korean food, so when we heard that there was a new Korean place in our work 'hood we were uber excited to go try it out. This place did not disappoint. 

We came here for lunch on a Monday afternoon and was pleasantly surprised to hear that they are open until 2am!! We really didn't want to tell anyone about this place since the food here is so good, we really wanted to keep it to ourselves, but they are a new place and I want them to do well, so I'm letting the yelp-verse know how great they are. 

They have a great little lunch menu, I had one of the stews (they pare it down for lunch so that it's for one person) and wow it was honestly one of the best Korean stews I've ever had. My coworker had their lunch box and there was so much food he couldn't even finish it all.  Super generous with their helpings! They even refilled our "side dishes" when we went through it all. 

The staff here is was so attentive, we felt so special eating there. Can't wait to come back! We took to go menus with us so we can get some to take home on those crazy late work nights.
author: Diana A.

description: karaage is not really crispy, a little bland. I prefer most ramen shops' karaage over this. The beef dumpling soup was not bad; the soup flavor is good but the dumplings are only a little better than frozen ones from the store (better skin and filling quality a little but just didn't seem that flavorful). Best thing is that it's late, but Cocobang is not far away...
author: Linus W.

description: I was in Union Square with my family and a friend. Our mission: bibimbap. We were tired of Stone, so I suggested 707 Sutter. K-Pop videos are always a win with our group! We headed over and got seated almost immediately, which was unexpected for a Friday evening. We ordered the corn cheese, BBQ bul go ki, fried chicken wings with soy garlic, strawberry soju, and bibimbap with chicken (of course). The food was pretty good. The chicken wings and bibimbap were definitely the highlight of the meal. Service was a bit slow as there were only about 2 servers for the entire room, but all in all, it was an enjoyable night and a great way to kick off the weekend.
author: Crystal S.

description: If you are in downtown and pining for good Korean lunch that isn't Sorabol, you can totally come here! In terms of comparing this place to other Korean restaurants in the city, I would rank this above average, but doesn't leave me with that total WOW factor. The place is spacious, the food doesn't take too long, it tastes good, and it doesn't hurt your wallet. If you are in like Union Square, this place is convenient for Korean food.
author: Cynthia D.

description:
Good food, big portions. We came around. 645 and it was empty. By the time we left, it was pretty crowded. I was worried that the service wouldn't be good, but thankfully it was very smooth. 

We had the ramen and rice cakes, creamy corn, beef dumpling soup and short ribs. Everything was delicious and we couldn't finish everything.
author: Natalie S.

description:
Loved the seafood pancake.  Would come back just for this item.  Only two shrimp, tho, it's mostly  bits of squid.  It'd be even more awesome if it was just shrimp

We also had the spicy chicken  wings. They were good,not great. We've had better at other. Korean restaurants. They were a tad too sweet

The shrimp on skewers were just blah

We walked here today from the Cartwright Hotel where we saw a play, with two women, "Collected Stories" which was excellent.
author: Foodlover B.

description:
707 Sutter is much better than the other Korean restaurants in the area, and is my go-to place when I'm craving Korean food. 

There's plenty of space in the shop and there's room for you to move around without bumping into somebody. There is also this "relatively" out-of-place nude (abstract) painting up against one of the counters, which I thought really contributed to the whole WTF design of the place. And in the authentic Korean restaurant fashion, there is a continuous stream of exotic K-Pop up against the wall, projector-style.

The fried and pan dishes were delicious. The Soon Tofu Jigae was not the best, so I'd recommend you eat something else here.
author: Don L.

description: I got food delivered to my place and it was terrible. Ive had food here at the restaurant and delivered before so I can definitely say it wasn't due to the traveling factor. The fish eggs in my pollack roe soup were really mushy like they were old, the rice was hard and the side dishes seemed to have gone bad. I only got two side dishes which seemed sad when I specifically asked for extra. I am Korean so I know what Korean food and this dish was supposed to taste like. Not only were the eggs very strange in texture and taste but, they skimped on the amount - not like I would've wanted anymore of the strange eggs though...) this was by far the worst Korean food experience I've ever had
author: Kira P.

description: Absolutely below average. Dont think that this restaurant is standard Korean restaurant. Seafood pancake is the worst one Ive ever had... it was mostly burnt black and did have only two shrimps. Even they got wrong order. Im also Korean but there is no advantage in this place. No consience. Dont be attracted by fancy Kpop star movie.
author: Sungchul K.

description: I have been going to 707 since the opening and I have never feel disappointed. Being a Korean, I find the food very satisfactory and most of all it is a great spot with the right atmosphere for friends gathering.  Whenever someone ask me for referrals, I tell them about 707
author: K L.

description:
Wow.  REALLY good Korean food!  The Tofu soup with beef was EXCELLENT with lots of tofu & just the right spice, not too vinegary.  My friend and I shared Tofu soup and the lunch special box with short ribs.  That was the perfect balance of spicy, salty tart and a tiny bit sweet from the ribs, and the noodles and potatoes made for a good neutral contrast.  I am VERY picky about Korean food and this was DELICIOUS.  No complaints at all.  The server (maybe the owner?) was very attentive and friendly. The check was only about $22 fora big tasty lunch for two.  The food is legit-don't change it!

For ideas on improvement, I think they may do well to add some plants and more canvas art on the walls to help buffer noise.  We were there in a slow time, but if it was busy I think it may have become pretty loud with the tile floor and high ceiling.   I do wish they had a more memorable name, something more descriptive of Korean food just so that everyone will find it easily...I want to see this place last for a long time! No matter what I'll be BACK and will bring in friends!
author: raven n.

description: First time eating at a korean place and not ordering the bi bim bap. Way to evolve, self! I still think about the kimchi pancake and drool.... we also got a dumpling soup that was delicious. I've been looking for excuses to come back ever since.
author: Kristina B.

description:
I am pretty sure that the 707 restaurant is actually LOL-  and the Laughing Out Loud part happens in the kitchen...
Totally not impressed by this place. I ordered pork noodle soup by the # indicated on menu, and received some tofu fandango stew instead. People make mistakes, no harm no foul. However, the waitress (1 of 3 people who visited our table, as there seemingly was no designated waiter, just a free for all) told me that this (what was in front of me) was the pork noodle thing i ordered, as if i was stupid or something and could not differentiate between gelatinous chunks of tofu and actual meat. Another telling sign was that my Stew noodle slop fandango came out much earlier than my friend who I was dining with. Instead of just admitting innocent fault (who really cares, I didn't, i just wanted her to bring me the correct food i ordered), the lady argued that it WAS pork...  picture this :literally in front of me sits soup with whiteish looking chunks and are practically vibrating with the korean pop music projected on the wall, and she tells me as if I am blind or something, that'd it is pork... Yeah...
I ended up having to talk to manager who was honest enough to offer me another dish, though this took up more time as I was on break from work. Unfortunately the second dish -though appreciated was not much better... some chewy noodle cold thing. It was so cold it makes me wonder why on earth it would have taken so long to bring out (refrigerator cold). 
I would not go here again even though the manager did eventually correct the error, because it is way over priced, and not even good, I should have just eaten Ramen or something.  I do not understand why this place is so packed... must be hype or something.
author: Ang G.

description:
Was looking for good Korean food in the city, and came here to check it out. Waited in line for a good 20 minutes, and the service was pretty attentive. Pretty loud and not a great space for intimacy, so I'd recommend it more for meeting up with friends than going on a date. The appetizers, although free, weren't great. 

We ordered:
- Seafood pancake (6.5/10) -- pretty good, crispy, standard pancake, but BURNT quite a bit at the edges so docking points for that. My date enjoyed it regardless.
- Kimchi Soondoobu (soft tofu) (5/10) -- we asked for mild, because my date can't really handle spices all too well, but it came out more medium, tiptoeing over to hot. Pretty standard soondoobu, but nothing remarkable.

I do recall that we ordered something else as well, but it just shows that most of the food is just like that: unremarkable. I'd suggest looking elsewhere for seriously good Korean food.
author: Courtney N.

description: Yum!  A great spot for comfort Korean food, as well as non-stop entertainment from the K-pop videos projected onto the wall.  Food is fresh and service is friendly and quick.  The duk bok ki is quite tasty, although I thought the rice cakes were a tad overcooked.  Soon du bu is good, and the galbi and bulgogi are also excellent.  The yuk kae jang was pretty good, as was the kimchi jjigae.  Will definitely be back again to try other dishes, like the bi bim bap and other grilled items.
author: Michelle C.

description: Came here with my friend from Japan:) we enjoyed few dishes (Seafood pancake, Rice cake, etc.) with Korean rice cocktail:) Will come back here for sure.
author: Maitai N.

description: The place is simple but I saw quite a few Koreans dinning there. Some dishes are quite authentic and it certainly satisfied my cravings for seafood pancake!
author: Sharon L.

description: We decided to try something new.  I can't regret a single part of this dining experience.  My gf and I ordered the minced beef, rice noodles with sauce and a noodle dish.  It's a change of pace from fast food and lest authentic locations, but prices were reasonable and the food was delicious.  They have K-pop playing on big screens and alcohol on the menu--a great way to start the night.
author: O M.

description: The waitresses are very obliging!  The 6 year old loved his burger, the beer was good and the atmosphere is relaxed.  Our entrees were good.  K-pop on the wall.
author: Darrin C.

description:
Every foods are very good.
Its taste like a real korean's do (I'm just got from korea)

Soondae bokeum, budae jjigae, rabok-i were good.
But only one loss is hot but no air conditioner (5/14).
author: Junghyun I.

description: This place is okay I guess. They didn't put that much beef in my soup and in the other soup they put SPAM in it? What restaurant even uses spam anymore? Gross.
author: Nicolette A.

description: My wife was distracted by the k pop videos projected on the wall which made conversation hard, but the food has been great.  Everything I have had was quite good, my favorite though is the garlic fried chicken, love it, we will be back many times.
author: Zachary S.

description: Today I got the first dish on the noodle menu (noodles with beef) and kimchi fried rice with chicken to go. We loved the food and finished it all. The noodle dish was very flavorful with garlic, sesame seeds and mushrooms. The kimchi fried rice was really good as well.
author: Olga A.

description:
I had high hopes for this new restaurant on Sutter, but they were a bit dashed. The food was... unexciting, underspiced, overpriced, and undercooked. Me and my and my dining partner's dishes were delivered about 15 minutes apart, which left me with the unfortunate choice of either eating while he waited, or eating cold food 15 minutes later.

The atmosphere was... very interesting. A projector displaying K-Pop music videos 10 feet wide on the wall really makes more sense for a nightclub than an otherwise quiet restaurant. Although watching hilarious K-Pop music videos did help distract us while we were waiting for food to make it out to our table...

I don't think I'll be returning.
author: James B.

description:
Amazing food and fantastic owners.  Definitely my new favorite Korean spot.

Will be going back again soon with a big group!  

Oh yea, and they have K Pop music videos projecting on the wall...  Amazing.
author: Jay S.

description:
I have lived in San Francisco most of my life and i must say, when you think you have found the best of a type of food, a new place like this pops up. 

I have long been a fan of Korean food. When writing this review i am comparing it to likes of Toyose, Tonight souju bar, Manna and Um Ma Son. These 4 places i mentioned have 2 distinct differences. Toyose and Tonight are more of Soju bars with decent korean food while Mana and Um ma Son are more of the traditional Korean Home style restaurants.

Why do i mention this? 707 sutter takes the best of both worlds. You Have the soju bar atmosphere with restaurant quality food and service. 

Atmosphere/service:
This place is huge compared to all the other places i mentioned and is great for big parties. Waitresses are very nice and always ready when you need them. They have a HUGE projector playing Korean music videos that is displayed on a large wall. Sound is very good as well.

Food- 
We ordered the:

Kim Chi Fried Rice: Had to try one of my go-to dishes. We added spam. The texture and amount of sauce is perfect. Not too wet, not too dry. Generous portion of spam and kim chi. I would say that this dish was way better than Tonight Soju Bar and almost as good as Toyose (Very close).

Boo dae jjigae: Enough for 3-4 people. COmes on a hot pot and has a generous portion of ramen, spam, sausage, assorted veggies and a very good soup base. Have had this at many restaurants and this is by far the best.

Soju- For something different try the strawberry. It comes with crushed ice and is perfect with the soups/

Seafood Pancake: just as it sounds. This was perfect.

Overall this is probably one of my new favorites. Super clean, hip, friendly, roomy, well air conditioned, and awesome food. Highly recommend this place!
author: Robin H.

description:
Came by last night with my girlfriend, we normally go down to Sunset for out favorite Korean food, but it was getting late and we wanted to try something closer. 

The decor is standard korean club, with a giant projection of k-pop videos but the seating needs some design work. The tables and chairs just  feel plopped where they are. 

The food was great. The seafood pancake was delicious and crispy. It was creatively served on a wooden pizza  peel. The pig's feet was also really good and served antipasti style. It was huge!! We could only finish about less than half. Perfect snack for watching basketball the next day.

Service was great, the only thing that kept the last star from coming was the Jol Bak noodles (I'm sure I misspelled it) were a little overly salty.

We're definitely coming back and happy to have great Korean food nearby.
author: Mike L.

description: Great food and filled my love of korean food! Loved their Kimchi fried rice and their short beef ribs.
author: E R.

description: Surprised this place is not busier! Glad I have my steaming clay pot of bi bim bap while others are standing in line for the sanraku across the street. Haha- suckers! Good Korean food and reasonable service.
author: Susan A.

description: Very good barbecue chicken. Excellent ban chan (small, traditional Korean side dishes). Pleasant service.
author: Inigo M.

description:
tl;dr: would definitely come back, but probably after a night out next time.

About a year ago, I discovered the wonders of after-drinking Korean food. Spicy, soupy, salty, and satisfying - I'd choose a bowl of Korean soup over a slice of pizza any night. This place definitely delivers in that respect - it's open late, there's ridiculous K-Pop music videos projected on a huge blank wall, there are drinks, and there's spicy, soupy, salty, and satisfying food.

We ordered the bu dae ji gae per Yelp's recommendations and it was just a bit too much food for two. Nothing refined or delicate about this dish - it's a huge kitchen sink bowl of sausage, spam, ramen, rice cakes, and veggies that comes in a bit metal bowl sitting on a burner. You boil it yourself and enjoy the goodies when the noodles are done cooking.

For a regular dinner, I'd rather venture to the Richmond, but next time I'm out late downtown, chances are I'll end my night here.
author: Lisa W.

description: 707 Sutter is a not a place I would ever recommend for Korean food. But I'm not from the area. So this may be the best they have to offer. We were stuck with 707 after walking the whole street and finding out that every place had a wait for at least an hour. So lesson learned - always reserve in SF. To the food. the banchan was tiny and lacked flavor as was the rest of the meal. The flavors that did have flavor, mainly was just spicy. The price, as I've see in SF, was reasonable. Overall, 707 Sutter is not worth it if you want good food. Walk a couple more blocks and look else where.
author: Kevin C.

description:
Good food. Cheap drinks. Korean music videos in the background on a huge projector.

Things to eat (names may be slightly off... just slightly):

Ramen with spam and other things - jiga something
Kimchi fried rice - pretty sure its called kimchi fried rice
BBQ beef - bulgogi
Seafood pancake - Not even the slightest clue but it started with a P

Things to drink:
Yogurt Soju
Lime Soju
author: William L.

description:
My Korean (born & raised) husband loves this restaurant. We tried the seafood pancake, fried octopus, pork feet, and bulgogi. Enjoyed all of them. My husband did give his oral feedback to the server as he thought that the food would be even better if they were slightly less sweet but it is more of a personal preference.

Service was excellent and the owner is especially sweet and beautifful. Will definitely come back for more.
author: Chung T.

description:
The place offers interesting Korean food, that I haven't seen at other places. We ordered pig feet, stir-fried clear noodle and seafood pancake. The food exceeded our expectations. It was delicious, the noodle and pancake arrived hot from the stove and the portions were huge for the price. The pig feet tasted amazing with raw garlic and some Korean sauce.
The place is a little dark, but light from the projector on the wall makes it cozy. It is a nice place to hang out with friends - we have seen a lot of big groups of 6-8 people easily finding seat, and we would have tried more dishes if our group was larger. 
The service was nice. We were seated as soon as a table became available and were attended as needed.
We will definitely go back there again.
author: Didi C.

description: Come here every other week. Everything I've ever had is amazing. Love the chicken wings, corn cheese, bi bim bop and dumpling soup. Reasonable pricing and they have lots of soju flavors that I like. They also stay open late which is great!
author: Rosalva G.

description: Stew with noodles are damn good! The noodles can be refilled if you want more. One stew is good for two ppl. The kimchi noodles are really delicious too with spicy sweet sauce.
author: Kathleen K.

description: Food was great, came to the table piping hot. Ordered pot stickers which were amazing and spicy wings which had a deliciously sweet spicy sauce on them. Ordered the beef as well which was really good as well. Atmosphere is casual and staff very friendly. I will come here again!
author: Erik A.

description:
I had the Soon Doo Boo with vegetables, and it was pretty damn good. 
It also comes with banchan. I absolutely hate the seating at this place- it reminds me a of a Subway restaurant. They really to renovate. However, the food is A-OK.
author: A B.

description:
way better than what I had expected. went in a large party and every dish was above average. I'm asian and I eat a TON of asian food. this is legit. go with friends. order tons of food and alcohol. 

service/ wait time/ seating/ ambiance and decor are pretty great for an asian establishment.
author: Teresa H.

description: Stayed at the Grand Hyatt and wanted Korean food. This place was only 4 blocks (6 min) walk from Stockton. I have to say I was pretty impressed with the La duk boh ki. It was hot yet sweet and the ramen noodles was cooked just perfectly. And the lunch su jeh bee was great. The stock was made from anchovies and was flavored perfectly!
author: Sam B.

description:
Yet another sub-mediocre Korean drinking venue with food that's kind of "meh."

Highlights:
- They project kpop music videos onto a pretty large wall.

Lowlights:
- The food. The soondubu tastes like it's been injected with a generous dose of MSG. The banchan is lackluster, and the kimchi is more than forgettable. The "cream" ddeokbokki is oddly a tad too sweet, in that Splenda/diet drink aftertaste type of way. I guess the dolsot bibimbap was decent. But that's kind of hard to mess up.

I'd rather go to Cocobang one block up - sure, the space is a lot smaller, but the food's a notch higher, the atmosphere's more lively, and you can still get your guilty kpop pleasure served up on a large screen (if that's your thing).
author: Cheri S.

description:
Love the al tang and seafood pancake and Jok bal!!!
They offers great banchan!
Staff are super friendly and very nice. 
You can hang out with friends and have good food and drinks here!
author: Wendy K.

description: We've tried bulgogi, beef skewers, potstickers and seafood pancake-everything tasted great! The portions are pretty generous. One star out for a very small variety of salad plates I am used to getting in all Korean places...
author: Aya J.

description:
We were on the lookout for a sushi restaurant that was about to close in 30mins when we walked past this place. For some reason I always forget that Korean is an option when deciding what to eat, and we all pleasantly realized that it sounded even better than Japanese in that moment. As a bonus, this place was open late and accepted cards. In we went.

I really liked it. Spacious interior with lots of seating and a giant TV that plays K-pop music videos in the background. Friendly service.

Lots of options on the menu. I ordered the BBQ spicy pork (wasn't overly spicy) and we all shared a seafood pancake. I recommend both. The appetizer side dishes (aka. banchan) came in much smaller portions than most other Korean restaurants, but I'm sure they would've obliged refill requests.
author: An Y.

description:
Authentic korean restaurant with decent prices. I'm just not giving 5 stars because the seafood pancake was a bit smaller than other places.

Tofu soup - We got one kimchi and one beef, very authentic tasting, the soup had lots of flavor and almost thickness to it. Good amount of big sized tofu, though personally I like mine with more tofu. This one had more soup than tofu. Kimchi soup is spicier

Seafood pancake - They add carrots and jalepenos which I rarely see, but I must say it was a good addition because the jalapeno brought out that spiciness that I love. There were shrimp, octupus, the usual seafood and the right amount. Sauce was good. The only thing was it came with like 6 pieces I think and it was kinda small. 

The little dishes were also small (you can ask for refill) and with little variety (5 dishes)

Overall, a good new korean place AND they're known for their soju so must come back later for it!!

$25 whole bottle, $15 half soju
author: Emily M.

description: Good Korean food. Not as many little plates as I would like. But it was good!
author: Mark S.

description: My first time trying Korean in SF.... I should have listened to my SF friend and driven further out west. I had been craving soondubu but the one they serve here tastes watered down and almost flavorless. The japchae was better although a bit too sweet, and the kalbi was just ok. The only thing that came out perfect was my lychee martini.
author: Jia H.

description: this place is the closest thing to korea in sf! love it!  my favorite is the chicken wings and flavored soju!
author: Hang Rae C.

description:
decent food
soso service
suitable for large groups

we always get the pot which is good for 2-3 people
i remember the tofu soup is just soso
author: Miffy L.

description: This place is a little bizarre, what with the Korean pop vids being projected on the wall. But that was hands-down the best bibimbob I've had in my life. And the price for what you get is insanely low.
author: Jameson M.

description:
I came here on a Friday afternoon around 5:30 pm and got seated right away
We ordered the soon dae bok kum . It had the right amount of spicy ness but was missing the clear noodles . i guess im used to arang.

Ordered the fish cake soup. It was good

Ordered the rice cake with ramen. The rice cake was kinda to al dente for me.

The service was decent

I would come back if I had a few drinks first and was in the neighborhood.
author: DOM d.

description:
The name is a bit confusing, but the food was great! Me and my girlfriend came to this establishment while spending our holiday vacation. We decided to try the cheese corn that we have heard about from this website, yelp.com. Worth the try! It's creamy and cheesy and has a slight kick from the peppers. We also got some soft tofu soup which was boiling hot, but satisfying. Plenty of spiciness, but not too overwhelming. Filled with kimchi, beef, egg, and delicious tofu. I got the bibimbop in a stone pot (which it should be). Everything component was cooked correctly, the veggies, egg, kimchi, and the rice was crunchy, which made it even more satisfying. 
In general, the ambiance of the restaurant is casual and chill. There are TV screens that play Kpop music videos for your entertainment. We went at night and the place was dark. Probably would be nice if there were some lights. Anyhow, the place is nice and has pretty good Korean food. If you are in Union Square and are craving for Korean food, try this place out.
author: Crane S.

description:
I decided to check this place out based on a write-up in Tasting Table SF, who's judgement I trust. 

It's not what I expected, but the ambiance is pretty nice for a place that has pictures of their food in the window. 

They play awesome Korean music videos and television dramas on one wall with a projector. It gives the place a really interesting vibe. 

 I rarely have Korean food - but love Kimchi - so I ordered the Kimchi fried rice with shrimp. Total disappointment! It lacked completely in flavor, there was barely any shrip, and overall just wasn't good. The sunny side up egg and picked veggies on the saved saved the dish to be edible.

My friend ordered the Jap Chae w Beef, and it was really quite good! It had a slight sweetness to it which made it interesting, and the glass noodles were delish.
